source: Evaluation and cultivation method of high-tech value patents for mechanical products

name: Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
define: A method used to recombine original indicators into a set of independent indicators, reducing the number of indicators while retaining as much information as possible.
source: Evaluation and cultivation method of high-tech value patents for mechanical products

name: Factor Analysis
define: A method applied to give actual physical meaning to the reduced dimensional indicators from PCA, enhancing the operability of the evaluation indicators.
source: Evaluation and cultivation method of high-tech value patents for mechanical products

name: Expert Scoring
define: Scores assigned by experts to patent verification samples based on the evaluation indicators, reflecting the perceived technical value.
source: Evaluation and cultivation method of high-tech value patents for mechanical products

name: Patent Value
define: The calculated value of a patent based on the technical evaluation indicators, weights, and methods such as Evidence Theory and Entropy Method.
source: Evaluation and cultivation method of high-tech value patents for mechanical products

name: Indicator Weights
define: The weights assigned to each technical evaluation indicator, determined by the Entropy Method, reflecting their importance in the overall patent value assessment.
source: Evaluation and cultivation method of high-tech value patents for mechanical products

name: Information Science Evaluation Methods
define: Existing methods for evaluating patent values, used for comparison with the proposed method to demonstrate its effectiveness.
source: Evaluation and cultivation method of high-tech value patents for mechanical products

name: Inventor Distance
define: The average geographic distance between collaborating inventors.
source: Geographic distance and innovation: The impact of distant knowledge acquired on patent value

name: Patent Value Indicators
define: Include Forward Citation Count, Reference Count, Family Size, Litigation Probability, and Claim Count.
source: Geographic distance and innovation: The impact of distant knowledge acquired on patent value

name: Forward Citation Count
define: The number of citations a patent receives from subsequent patents.
source: Geographic distance and innovation: The impact of distant knowledge acquired on patent value

name: Reference Count
define: The number of backward patent references a patent has.
source: Geographic distance and innovation: The impact of distant knowledge acquired on patent value

name: Family Size
define: The number of countries in which protection is sought for a given invention.
source: Geographic distance and innovation: The impact of distant knowledge acquired on patent value

name: Litigation Probability
define: The likelihood of a patent to be litigated.
source: Geographic distance and innovation: The impact of distant knowledge acquired on patent value

name: Claim Count
define: The number of claims a patent has.
source: Geographic distance and innovation: The impact of distant knowledge acquired on patent value

name: Originality Index
define: Measures the diversity of cited previous patent knowledge.
source: Geographic distance and innovation: The impact of distant knowledge acquired on patent value

name: External Collaborator
define: Indicates whether the collaboration is between firms (interfirm) or within a firm.
source: Geographic distance and innovation: The impact of distant knowledge acquired on patent value

name: Inventor Count
define: The number of inventors involved in the development of a patented invention.
source: Geographic distance and innovation: The impact of distant knowledge acquired on patent value

name: Inventor Country Count
define: The number of countries involved in each collaborated patent.
source: Geographic distance and innovation: The impact of distant knowledge acquired on patent value

name: Patent Value
define: Economic value derived from a patent, including factors such as market value, potential licensing revenue, and strategic importance.
source: Managing firm patents: A bibliometric investigation into the state of the art

name: Strategic Exploitation of Patent Value
define: The various ways in which firms can extract value from their patents, including internal use, licensing, and cross-licensing.
source: Managing firm patents: A bibliometric investigation into the state of the art

name: Technological and Competitive Landscape
define: The broader environment in which patents are situated, including technological trends and competitive dynamics.
source: Managing firm patents: A bibliometric investigation into the state of the art

name: Patent Management Process
define: The systematic approach to handling patents within a firm, from application to maintenance and evaluation.
source: Managing firm patents: A bibliometric investigation into the state of the art

name: Firm Size
define: The scale of the firm, which can influence its patent strategy and capabilities.
source: Managing firm patents: A bibliometric investigation into the state of the art

name: Industry Sector
define: The specific industry in which a firm operates, which can affect the value and exploitation of patents.
source: Managing firm patents: A bibliometric investigation into the state of the art

name: Market Location
define: The geographical market in which a firm operates, influencing the relevance of patents.
source: Managing firm patents: A bibliometric investigation into the state of the art

name: Legislation
define: The legal framework governing patents, which can vary by country and affect patent strategy.
source: Managing firm patents: A bibliometric investigation into the state of the art

name: Manager Commitment
define: The level of engagement and attention from management towards patent issues.
source: Managing firm patents: A bibliometric investigation into the state of the art

name: Resource Allocation
define: The distribution of resources within a firm towards patent management activities.
source: Managing firm patents: A bibliometric investigation into the state of the art

name: Degree
define: A centrality measure representing the size of an inventor's personal network.
source: An empirical enquiry into co-patent networks and their stars: The case of cardiac pacemaker technology

name: Betweenness
define: A centrality measure indicating the potential of an inventor to mediate between other inventors.
source: An empirical enquiry into co-patent networks and their stars: The case of cardiac pacemaker technology

name: Closeness
define: A centrality measure reflecting the efficiency with which an inventor can reach other participants in the network.
source: An empirical enquiry into co-patent networks and their stars: The case of cardiac pacemaker technology

name: Entry
define: The year in which the first patent of an inventor was filed, representing their seniority in the network.
source: An empirical enquiry into co-patent networks and their stars: The case of cardiac pacemaker technology

name: Output
define: The total number of patents an inventor has generated.
source: An empirical enquiry into co-patent networks and their stars: The case of cardiac pacemaker technology

name: NetCit
define: The cumulative number of citations an inventor has received from other inventors' patents, minus self-citations.
source: An empirical enquiry into co-patent networks and their stars: The case of cardiac pacemaker technology

name: IPCRange
define: The number of IPC-subclasses in which an inventor's patents were filed, indicating technical diversity.
source: An empirical enquiry into co-patent networks and their stars: The case of cardiac pacemaker technology

name: Colocation
define: The share of foreign inventors among an inventor's collaborators, measured by dissimilar country codes in the inventor addresses.
source: An empirical enquiry into co-patent networks and their stars: The case of cardiac pacemaker technology

name: Innovation Capacity
define: Measured by the count of domestic patents filed in at least one foreign country, indicating the country's ability to innovate and meet global patent standards.
source: International patent inﬂows and innovative capacity in recipient countries: Evidence from the solar photovoltaics (PV) industry

name: International Patent Inflows
define: The number of international patents that flow into each recipient country each year, used to measure the impact on a recipient country's innovation capacity.
source: International patent inﬂows and innovative capacity in recipient countries: Evidence from the solar photovoltaics (PV) industry

name: Import Value
define: The international trade value for solar PV products, considered as a source of technology diffusion.
source: International patent inﬂows and innovative capacity in recipient countries: Evidence from the solar photovoltaics (PV) industry

name: Installed Capacity
define: The market size of solar PV technology, measured by the installed capacity of solar PV technologies.
source: International patent inﬂows and innovative capacity in recipient countries: Evidence from the solar photovoltaics (PV) industry

name: R&D Investment
define: Both general R&D as a percent of GDP and specific R&D investments in the solar PV industry are used to measure their impact on innovation capacity.
source: International patent inﬂows and innovative capacity in recipient countries: Evidence from the solar photovoltaics (PV) industry

name: GDP per Capita
define: A control variable representing the economic status of a country.
source: International patent inﬂows and innovative capacity in recipient countries: Evidence from the solar photovoltaics (PV) industry

name: Leaders
define: Countries with a higher level of technology development in the solar PV industry.
source: International patent inﬂows and innovative capacity in recipient countries: Evidence from the solar photovoltaics (PV) industry

name: Laggards
define: Countries with a lower level of technology development in the solar PV industry.
source: International patent inﬂows and innovative capacity in recipient countries: Evidence from the solar photovoltaics (PV) industry

name: Patenting Activities
define: Activities related to the acquisition of patents, indicating the level of innovation and protection of intellectual property.
source: Nanotechnology Innovation System: An Empirical Analysis of the Emerging Actors and Collaborative Networks

name: Technology Diffusion
define: The spread of technology from its point of origin to other areas, indicating the adoption and integration of new technologies in various sectors.
source: Nanotechnology Innovation System: An Empirical Analysis of the Emerging Actors and Collaborative Networks

name: Collaborative Networks
define: Networks formed by actors for collaboration, indicating the level of partnership and interaction between different entities.
source: Nanotechnology Innovation System: An Empirical Analysis of the Emerging Actors and Collaborative Networks

name: International Collaboration
define: Collaborations across different countries, indicating the global nature of partnerships and knowledge sharing.
source: Nanotechnology Innovation System: An Empirical Analysis of the Emerging Actors and Collaborative Networks

name: New Entrants
define: Newcomers in the field, such as spinoffs and SMEs, indicating the influx of novel ideas and potential innovation drivers.
source: Nanotechnology Innovation System: An Empirical Analysis of the Emerging Actors and Collaborative Networks

name: Public Research Organizations
define: Institutions funded by the public sector, indicating the role of government and public funding in innovation and technology development.
source: Nanotechnology Innovation System: An Empirical Analysis of the Emerging Actors and Collaborative Networks

name: Commercialization
define: The process of turning inventions and ideas into products or services, indicating the transition from research to market application.
source: Nanotechnology Innovation System: An Empirical Analysis of the Emerging Actors and Collaborative Networks

name: Academic Researchers
define: Individuals involved in academic research, indicating the role of academia in driving innovation and technology development.
source: Nanotechnology Innovation System: An Empirical Analysis of the Emerging Actors and Collaborative Networks

name: Large Organizations
define: Established corporations, indicating their role in the adoption and diffusion of new technologies.
source: Nanotechnology Innovation System: An Empirical Analysis of the Emerging Actors and Collaborative Networks

name: Technology Pole
define: A concept within the Techno-Economic Network (TEN) framework, representing the technological aspects and actors within an innovation system.
source: Nanotechnology Innovation System: An Empirical Analysis of the Emerging Actors and Collaborative Networks

name: Science Pole
define: A concept within the TEN framework, representing the scientific aspects and actors within an innovation system.
source: Nanotechnology Innovation System: An Empirical Analysis of the Emerging Actors and Collaborative Networks

name: Market Pole
define: A concept within the TEN framework, representing the market aspects and actors within an innovation system.
source: Nanotechnology Innovation System: An Empirical Analysis of the Emerging Actors and Collaborative Networks

name: Finance Pole
define: A concept within the TEN framework, representing the financial aspects and actors within an innovation system, with indirect links to innovation.
source: Nanotechnology Innovation System: An Empirical Analysis of the Emerging Actors and Collaborative Networks

name: Software Patents
define: Patents that involve a logic algorithm for processing data implemented via stored instructions.
source: Software Patents: A Replication Study

name: Utility Patents
define: Patents granted that may include a variety of technologies, not limited to software.
source: Software Patents: A Replication Study

name: Copyright
define: A form of intellectual property protection for original works of authorship, including software source code.
source: Software Patents: A Replication Study

name: Trade Secrets
define: A form of intellectual property protection where information is kept secret to gain an advantage over competitors.
source: Software Patents: A Replication Study

name: Trademarks
define: Signs, including names and logos, used by companies to identify and protect their products or services.
source: Software Patents: A Replication Study

name: Algorithms
define: A set of rules or processes used in software to perform specific tasks, which can be protected by patents.
source: Software Patents: A Replication Study

name: Legal Changes
define: Changes in laws and court rulings that affect the patentability of software and related technologies.
source: Software Patents: A Replication Study

name: Quality of Patents
define: The degree to which patents meet the criteria of being novel, non-obvious, and utilitarian.
source: Software Patents: A Replication Study

name: Prior-Art
define: Existing knowledge or products that may affect the patentability of an invention by showing it is not novel.
source: Software Patents: A Replication Study

name: Patent Classification
define: The categorization of patents into specific classes or groups based on their technological content.
source: Software Patents: A Replication Study

name: Patent Examination
define: The process by which patent examiners evaluate the patentability of an invention, including the search for prior-art.
source: Software Patents: A Replication Study

name: ln(GDP)
define: The logarithm of a country's Gross Domestic Product, indicating the country's economic scale.
source: Analysis of the Growth in the Number of Patents Granted and Its Effect over the Level of Growth of the Countries: An Econometric Estimation of the Mixed Model Approach

name: ln(GDPpc)
define: The logarithm of GDP per capita, representing the income level of a country.
source: Analysis of the Growth in the Number of Patents Granted and Its Effect over the Level of Growth of the Countries: An Econometric Estimation of the Mixed Model Approach

name: Credit
define: The level of credit as a percentage of GDP, showing the capacity of each country to leverage resources.
source: Analysis of the Growth in the Number of Patents Granted and Its Effect over the Level of Growth of the Countries: An Econometric Estimation of the Mixed Model Approach

name: Education
define: Expenditure on education as a percentage of GDP, indicating the country's policy on educational issues.
source: Analysis of the Growth in the Number of Patents Granted and Its Effect over the Level of Growth of the Countries: An Econometric Estimation of the Mixed Model Approach

name: Trade
define: International trade as a percentage of GDP, representing the level of interaction with other countries.
source: Analysis of the Growth in the Number of Patents Granted and Its Effect over the Level of Growth of the Countries: An Econometric Estimation of the Mixed Model Approach

name: OECD
define: A binary variable indicating membership in the OECD group of countries, reflecting the level of development.
source: Analysis of the Growth in the Number of Patents Granted and Its Effect over the Level of Growth of the Countries: An Econometric Estimation of the Mixed Model Approach

name: ln(Cite)
define: The natural logarithm of the number of citable documents, an approximation of academic activity's effect on innovation.
source: Analysis of the Growth in the Number of Patents Granted and Its Effect over the Level of Growth of the Countries: An Econometric Estimation of the Mixed Model Approach

name: R&D
define: R&D expenditure as a percentage of GDP, indicating the intensity of research and development activities.
source: Analysis of the Growth in the Number of Patents Granted and Its Effect over the Level of Growth of the Countries: An Econometric Estimation of the Mixed Model Approach

name: Geographical Region
define: The geographical area to which a country belongs, which may influence innovation production.
source: Analysis of the Growth in the Number of Patents Granted and Its Effect over the Level of Growth of the Countries: An Econometric Estimation of the Mixed Model Approach

name: ln(Patent)
define: The natural logarithm of the patent number
source: Analysis of the Growth in the Number of Patents Granted and Its Effect over the Level of Growth of the Countries: An Econometric Estimation of the Mixed Model Approach

name: Private Inventors
define: Individuals applying for a patent in their own name, instead of naming a company as an applicant.
source: Patent litigation by private inventors - case Finland

name: Patent Applications
define: The process of filing a patent with the intention to obtain a patent grant.
source: Patent litigation by private inventors - case Finland

name: Patent Grants
define: The successful outcome of a patent application process resulting in a granted patent.
source: Patent litigation by private inventors - case Finland

name: Administrative Hearings
define: Legal proceedings where patent applicants seek to overturn an adverse decision made by the administration.
source: Patent litigation by private inventors - case Finland

name: Opposition Actions
define: Legal actions brought against a patent within a specific time frame, aiming to dispute the patent's validity.
source: Patent litigation by private inventors - case Finland

name: Invalidity Actions
define: Civil litigations filed to seek invalidation of a patent that was not revoked in an opposition hearing.
source: Patent litigation by private inventors - case Finland

name: Infringement Actions
define: Legal actions taken to enforce patent rights or defend against accusations of patent infringement.
source: Patent litigation by private inventors - case Finland

name: Ownership Actions
define: Legal disputes related to the ownership of a patent and the right to financial rewards from the patent right.
source: Patent litigation by private inventors - case Finland

name: Employee Invention Actions
define: Legal actions involving disputes over the rights to an invention made by an employee.
source: Patent litigation by private inventors - case Finland

name: Contract Actions
define: Legal disputes dealing with issues of contract validity and transfer of patent rights.
source: Patent litigation by private inventors - case Finland

name: Patent Subsidy Policy
define: A government policy tool designed to encourage and guide innovation subjects to apply for patents.
source: The Influence of China Regional Patent Subsidy Policy to Patent Application: An Empirical Analysis

name: Patent Application
define: The act of applying for a patent, which can be influenced by various factors including subsidy policies.
source: The Influence of China Regional Patent Subsidy Policy to Patent Application: An Empirical Analysis

name: Invention Patent
define: A type of patent application that may be affected by the patent subsidy policy.
source: The Influence of China Regional Patent Subsidy Policy to Patent Application: An Empirical Analysis

name: Utility Model Patent
define: A type of patent application that may be influenced by the patent subsidy policy.
source: The Influence of China Regional Patent Subsidy Policy to Patent Application: An Empirical Analysis

name: Design Patent
define: A type of patent application that may be influenced by the patent subsidy policy.
source: The Influence of China Regional Patent Subsidy Policy to Patent Application: An Empirical Analysis

name: Total Patent
define: The overall number of patent applications, which can be impacted by the patent subsidy policy.
source: The Influence of China Regional Patent Subsidy Policy to Patent Application: An Empirical Analysis

name: Economic Burden
define: The financial cost associated with applying or maintaining patents, which can be alleviated by subsidy policies.
source: The Influence of China Regional Patent Subsidy Policy to Patent Application: An Empirical Analysis

name: Patent Quality
define: The standard or level of innovation represented by a patent, which may be influenced by the patent subsidy policy.
source: The Influence of China Regional Patent Subsidy Policy to Patent Application: An Empirical Analysis

name: Patent System Reform
define: Changes to the patent system that can affect patent application behavior.
source: The Influence of China Regional Patent Subsidy Policy to Patent Application: An Empirical Analysis

name: R&D Investment
define: Investment in research and development, which can be influenced by patent subsidy policies.
source: The Influence of China Regional Patent Subsidy Policy to Patent Application: An Empirical Analysis

name: Policy Revision
define: The act of updating or modifying existing policies, which can have different effects on patent applications.
source: The Influence of China Regional Patent Subsidy Policy to Patent Application: An Empirical Analysis

name: Stock of Conventional Patents
define: The total number of non-SEP patents held by a country, used as a measure of innovative capacity.
source: Standard essential patents and global ICT value chains with a focus on the catching-up of China

name: Stock of SEPs
define: The total number of Standard Essential Patents held by a country, which are patents declared essential to a technical standard.
source: Standard essential patents and global ICT value chains with a focus on the catching-up of China

name: Exports in the ICT sector
define: The output in the Information and Communication Technology sector of a country, used as a control for the size of the economy.
source: Standard essential patents and global ICT value chains with a focus on the catching-up of China

name: Imports in the ICT sector
define: Imports in the ICT sector
source: Standard essential patents and global ICT value chains with a focus on the catching-up of China

name: Value of SEPs
define: The value attributed to SEPs based on the number of citations they have received, indicating their importance and quality.
source: Standard essential patents and global ICT value chains with a focus on the catching-up of China

name: InnValue
define: The value of university-industry joint innovations, measured by the total number of citations a joint patent received within five years of the issue date.
source: The impact of technological relatedness, prior ties, and geographical distance on university–industry collaborations: A joint-patent analysis

name: TechRel
define: The degree of overlapping between the technology profile of the university and the firm jointly developing a patent.
source: The impact of technological relatedness, prior ties, and geographical distance on university–industry collaborations: A joint-patent analysis

name: PriorTies
define: A binary variable indicating whether the university and the firm have previously registered joint patents in the five years prior to the joint patent under analysis.
source: The impact of technological relatedness, prior ties, and geographical distance on university–industry collaborations: A joint-patent analysis

name: GeoDist
define: The geographical distance between the university and the firm, measured as the spatial distance in kilometers between their location sites.
source: The impact of technological relatedness, prior ties, and geographical distance on university–industry collaborations: A joint-patent analysis

name: FirmSize
define: The size of the firm, measured by the number of full-time employers.
source: The impact of technological relatedness, prior ties, and geographical distance on university–industry collaborations: A joint-patent analysis

name: FirmPatents
define: The technological capital of the firm, measured by the number of patents registered by the firm in the five years prior to the collaboration.
source: The impact of technological relatedness, prior ties, and geographical distance on university–industry collaborations: A joint-patent analysis

name: UnivSize
define: The size of the university, measured by the number of full-time researchers.
source: The impact of technological relatedness, prior ties, and geographical distance on university–industry collaborations: A joint-patent analysis

name: UnivPatents
define: The patenting propensity of the university, measured by the number of patents registered by the university in the five years prior to the collaboration.
source: The impact of technological relatedness, prior ties, and geographical distance on university–industry collaborations: A joint-patent analysis

name: SpinOff
define: A binary variable indicating whether the university has at least one spin-off.
source: The impact of technological relatedness, prior ties, and geographical distance on university–industry collaborations: A joint-patent analysis

name: TTO
define: A binary variable indicating whether the university has a technology transfer office.
source: The impact of technological relatedness, prior ties, and geographical distance on university–industry collaborations: A joint-patent analysis

name: UnivReputation
define: The reputation of the university, measured by its ranking in the Academic Ranking of World Universities.
source: The impact of technological relatedness, prior ties, and geographical distance on university–industry collaborations: A joint-patent analysis

name: Intellectual Property Rights (IPRs)
define: Rights used to create revenue, defend a firm’s competitive position, and signal competitiveness.
source: Intellectual property rights in innovation management research: A review

name: Innovation Management
define: The process of managing and profiting from knowledge and innovation within a firm.
source: Intellectual property rights in innovation management research: A review

name: Patents
define: A type of IPR that is emphasized in most studies and is used as an indicator of firm or country innovativeness.
source: Intellectual property rights in innovation management research: A review

name: Secondary Data
define: Data that is often relied upon in studies, mostly consisting of patent data.
source: Intellectual property rights in innovation management research: A review

name: North American and European Contexts
define: Geographical regions that are heavily emphasized in the content of the articles.
source: Intellectual property rights in innovation management research: A review

name: Research Articles
define: The articles published in leading innovation management journals that were analyzed in the study.
source: Intellectual property rights in innovation management research: A review

name: Theoretical Basis
define: The need for development of coherent constructs and conceptual frameworks in IPR research.
source: Intellectual property rights in innovation management research: A review

name: Coherent Constructs
define: The constructs that need to be developed to strengthen the theoretical basis of IPR research.
source: Intellectual property rights in innovation management research: A review

name: Conceptual Frameworks
define: The frameworks that need to be developed to strengthen the theoretical basis of IPR research.
source: Intellectual property rights in innovation management research: A review

name: Firm-Level Perspective
define: A perspective that focuses on organizational decision-making within a firm, which is often the focus in innovation management literature.
source: Intellectual property rights in innovation management research: A review

name: Macro-Level Perspective
define: A perspective that focuses on broader aspects such as industry or country level, which is common in legal matters and IPR issues.
source: Intellectual property rights in innovation management research: A review

name: Innovation Partnerships
define: A dummy variable representing whether firms cooperated with other organizations on innovation.
source: Exploring the use of patents in a weak institutional environment: The effects of innovation partnerships, firm ownership, and new management practices

name: Firm Ownership
define: A categorical variable with three categories: domestic, foreign, and domestic and foreign ownership.
source: Exploring the use of patents in a weak institutional environment: The effects of innovation partnerships, firm ownership, and new management practices

name: New Management Practices
define: A binary variable indicating whether a firm had implemented new or significant changes in management methods.
source: Exploring the use of patents in a weak institutional environment: The effects of innovation partnerships, firm ownership, and new management practices

name: Propensity to Patent
define: A binary variable extracted from a survey question asking whether firms patented during the 2001–2003 period.
source: Exploring the use of patents in a weak institutional environment: The effects of innovation partnerships, firm ownership, and new management practices

name: Firm Size
define: The logarithm of the number of employees.
source: Exploring the use of patents in a weak institutional environment: The effects of innovation partnerships, firm ownership, and new management practices

name: Innovative Capacity (ex-ante)
define: The logarithm of R&D expenses normalized by firm turnover and the percentage of a firm's staff educated to the degree level or above in science or engineering.
source: Exploring the use of patents in a weak institutional environment: The effects of innovation partnerships, firm ownership, and new management practices

name: Innovative Capacity (ex-post)
define: A dummy variable for whether a firm introduced an innovation new to its national market.
source: Exploring the use of patents in a weak institutional environment: The effects of innovation partnerships, firm ownership, and new management practices

name: Degree of Competition
define: A categorical variable representing the firm’s largest market.
source: Exploring the use of patents in a weak institutional environment: The effects of innovation partnerships, firm ownership, and new management practices

name: Government Support
define: A dummy variable to account for the possibility that a firm received any support from the Government.
source: Exploring the use of patents in a weak institutional environment: The effects of innovation partnerships, firm ownership, and new management practices

name: Industry
define: A series of dummy variables reflecting different market conditions across manufacturing sectors.
source: Exploring the use of patents in a weak institutional environment: The effects of innovation partnerships, firm ownership, and new management practices

name: R&D Expenditure
define: The natural logarithm of real R&D expenditure by the electric utilities, deflated at the 2005 constant price using CPI.
source: Deregulation, market competition, and innovation of utilities: Evidence from Japanese electric sector

name: Patent Quantity
define: The number of patent applications of a utility.
source: Deregulation, market competition, and innovation of utilities: Evidence from Japanese electric sector

name: Patent Quality
define: The average number of citations a patent receives within five years of being granted.
source: Deregulation, market competition, and innovation of utilities: Evidence from Japanese electric sector

name: Deregulation
define: A dummy variable that equals 1 from the start of deregulation in 1995 onwards, capturing the overall impact of deregulation.
source: Deregulation, market competition, and innovation of utilities: Evidence from Japanese electric sector

name: Market Competition
define: Measured by the share of non-utility electricity generated in each region for generation market competition, and the market share of PPSs in the regional retailing market for retail market competition.
source: Deregulation, market competition, and innovation of utilities: Evidence from Japanese electric sector

name: Firm Size
define: Represented by the natural logarithm of firm assets or revenue, indicating the scale of the utility.
source: Deregulation, market competition, and innovation of utilities: Evidence from Japanese electric sector

name: Nuclear Share
define: The share of nuclear power in total power generation capacity.
source: Deregulation, market competition, and innovation of utilities: Evidence from Japanese electric sector

name: Government R&D Spending
define: The natural logarithm of real government energy R&D expenditure, representing government efforts to stimulate private R&D.
source: Deregulation, market competition, and innovation of utilities: Evidence from Japanese electric sector

name: Fukushima Dummy
define: A dummy variable indicating the impact of the Fukushima crisis, equal to 1 after 2011.
source: Deregulation, market competition, and innovation of utilities: Evidence from Japanese electric sector

name: GDP Growth
define: The regional GDP growth rate, used to control for macroeconomic conditions.
source: Deregulation, market competition, and innovation of utilities: Evidence from Japanese electric sector

name: Public R&D Funding
define: The annual amount of public R&D funding in Euro that a firm receives and the percentage of years a firm received at least one public grant.
source: The firm-level innovation impact of public R&D funding: Evidence from the German renewable energy sector

name: Firm's Overall Financial Situation
define: Operationalized by the equity ratio, i.e., the ratio of a firm's equity in Mio Euro and its total assets in Mio Euro.
source: The firm-level innovation impact of public R&D funding: Evidence from the German renewable energy sector

name: Patent Count
define: The number of a firm's patent applications per given year.
source: The firm-level innovation impact of public R&D funding: Evidence from the German renewable energy sector

name: Average Number of Citing Patents per Patent
define: The average number of citing patents per patent, serving as a qualitative indicator of R&D performance.
source: The firm-level innovation impact of public R&D funding: Evidence from the German renewable energy sector

name: Firm's Technology Knowledge Base
define: Reflected in a firm's patent stock, which is the depreciated number of previous patents between 1977 and 2005.
source: The firm-level innovation impact of public R&D funding: Evidence from the German renewable energy sector

name: Firm Size
define: Measured by total assets in Mio Euro, serving as an indicator of physical resources.
source: The firm-level innovation impact of public R&D funding: Evidence from the German renewable energy sector

name: Firm's Age
define: Controlled for as it may have different impacts on patenting activity due to resource constraints and reputation level.
source: The firm-level innovation impact of public R&D funding: Evidence from the German renewable energy sector

name: Sector
define: Controlled for sectoral divergences between the PV and wind sectors using a binary variable.
source: The firm-level innovation impact of public R&D funding: Evidence from the German renewable energy sector

name: Location
define: Controlled for using the first digit of the zip-code to account for structural differences in Germany.
source: The firm-level innovation impact of public R&D funding: Evidence from the German renewable energy sector

name: Legal Form
define: Controlled for due to different stakeholder and shareholder influences, financing opportunities, and legal requirements.
source: The firm-level innovation impact of public R&D funding: Evidence from the German renewable energy sector

name: Publications
define: Articles and research papers published on 5G technology.
source: Development of 5G – Identifying organizations active in publishing, patenting, and standardization

name: Patents
define: Patents filed and declared relevant to the 5G standard.
source: Development of 5G – Identifying organizations active in publishing, patenting, and standardization

name: Standard-Essential Patents (SEPs)
define: Patents that are essential for the implementation of the 5G standard.
source: Development of 5G – Identifying organizations active in publishing, patenting, and standardization

name: Standard Contributions
define: Contributions made to the development of the 5G standard.
source: Development of 5G – Identifying organizations active in publishing, patenting, and standardization

name: FRAND Licensing Conditions
define: Fair, Reasonable, and Non-Discriminatory licensing terms related to standard-essential patents.
source: Development of 5G – Identifying organizations active in publishing, patenting, and standardization

name: Freedom-to-Operate (FTO)
define: The ability to operate freely without infringing on others' patents.
source: Development of 5G – Identifying organizations active in publishing, patenting, and standardization

name: Reputation
define: The standing or prestige of an organization in the field of 5G technology.
source: Development of 5G – Identifying organizations active in publishing, patenting, and standardization

name: Research Grants
define: Funding provided for research activities related to 5G technology.
source: Development of 5G – Identifying organizations active in publishing, patenting, and standardization

name: Cooperation Partners
define: Organizations that collaborate on 5G technology development.
source: Development of 5G – Identifying organizations active in publishing, patenting, and standardization

name: Patent Licensing Agreements
define: Agreements for the use of patents under specific terms and conditions.
source: Development of 5G – Identifying organizations active in publishing, patenting, and standardization

name: Patent Portfolio
define: A collection of patents owned by an organization that are relevant to 5G technology.
source: Development of 5G – Identifying organizations active in publishing, patenting, and standardization

name: Internal Indicators
define: Reflect the characteristics of a patent itself, such as the number of applicants, number of independent claims, number of description words, etc.
source: A transferability evaluation model for intellectual property

name: External Indicators
define: Reflect the characteristics of the technology field a patent belongs to, such as IPC size, IPC activity, and IPC applicants.
source: A transferability evaluation model for intellectual property

name: Patent Transferability
define: The possibility of realizing a patent’s potential through its transaction.
source: A transferability evaluation model for intellectual property

name: Knowledge Depth
define: A measure of a firm's vertical strength in a particular technological domain, representing unique, complex, within-field knowledge content.
source: When to commit more to a technological entry: Evidence of the follow-up patenting action of bearings manufacturers

name: Knowledge Breadth
define: A measure of a firm's horizontal strength, reflecting its coverage of heterogeneous knowledge components.
source: When to commit more to a technological entry: Evidence of the follow-up patenting action of bearings manufacturers

name: Follow-up Patenting
define: The incidence of a second patent granted in a newly entered technological area.
source: When to commit more to a technological entry: Evidence of the follow-up patenting action of bearings manufacturers

name: Competitive Intensity
define: Measured by the time interval between the focal firm's entry patent and the closest date of a competitor's patent granted in the same patent subclass.
source: When to commit more to a technological entry: Evidence of the follow-up patenting action of bearings manufacturers

name: Learning Speed
define: Calculated as the average time delay of the cited patents from the citing patents of the focal firm.
source: When to commit more to a technological entry: Evidence of the follow-up patenting action of bearings manufacturers

name: Entry Patent Impact
define: Measured by the forward citation count of the entry patent, reflecting the importance and extendable nature of the technological entry.
source: When to commit more to a technological entry: Evidence of the follow-up patenting action of bearings manufacturers

name: Entry Patent Scope
define: The number of claims presented by the entry patent, indicating its potential application in multiple technological areas.
source: When to commit more to a technological entry: Evidence of the follow-up patenting action of bearings manufacturers

name: R&D Intensity
define: Measured by the ratio of R&D spending over sales by the focal firm in the year the entry patent was granted.
source: When to commit more to a technological entry: Evidence of the follow-up patenting action of bearings manufacturers

name: Firm Size
define: Defined as the annual sales in the year the entry patent was granted.
source: When to commit more to a technological entry: Evidence of the follow-up patenting action of bearings manufacturers

name: Firm Performance
define: Measured by the returns on equity in the same year the entry patent was granted.
source: When to commit more to a technological entry: Evidence of the follow-up patenting action of bearings manufacturers

name: Firm's Software Patent Stock
define: A measure of the number of software patents a firm holds, which can encapsulate the logic or algorithms responsible for data processing.
source: Strategic utilization of software patents to counteract rival penetration in the IT industry

name: Rivals' Market Value
define: Measured by Tobin's q, which captures the financial market performance of rivals.
source: Strategic utilization of software patents to counteract rival penetration in the IT industry

name: Rivals' R&D Capabilities
define: The efficiency with which a firm transforms its R&D expenditures into patentable outputs, serving as a protective buffer against the negative market repercussions of a focal firm’s software patent.
source: Strategic utilization of software patents to counteract rival penetration in the IT industry

name: Firm's Market Value
define: Measured by Tobin's q, which captures the financial market performance of the firm holding the software patents.
source: Strategic utilization of software patents to counteract rival penetration in the IT industry

name: Firm's Marketing Capability
define: The relative efficiency in transforming marketing inputs into marketing outputs, which can influence the commercialization of software patents.
source: Strategic utilization of software patents to counteract rival penetration in the IT industry

name: Firm's Operations Capability
define: The relative efficiency in transforming operations inputs into operations outputs, which can also influence the commercialization of software patents.
source: Strategic utilization of software patents to counteract rival penetration in the IT industry

name: Rivals' Firm Size
define: Average number of employees in rival firms, used as a control variable.
source: Strategic utilization of software patents to counteract rival penetration in the IT industry

name: Rivals' Firm Age
define: The age of rival firms, used as a control variable.
source: Strategic utilization of software patents to counteract rival penetration in the IT industry

name: Industry Software Patents
define: The total number of software patents in the industry, used as a control variable.
source: Strategic utilization of software patents to counteract rival penetration in the IT industry

name: Industry Tobin’s q
define: The median Tobin’s q for the industry, used as a control variable.
source: Strategic utilization of software patents to counteract rival penetration in the IT industry

name: Market Competition
define: Measured by the log value of the reciprocal of the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI), used as a control variable.
source: Strategic utilization of software patents to counteract rival penetration in the IT industry

name: Technology Cycle Time (TCT)
define: A time-based variable that captures the immediacy of reliance on prior knowledge, indicating the pace of technological progress in a field.
source: Exploring the forward citation patterns of patents based on the evolution of technology fields

name: Potential of Technological Convergence
define: A variable measuring the degree of centrality from an IPC co-occurrence network, reflecting the potential for a technology field to converge with others.
source: Exploring the forward citation patterns of patents based on the evolution of technology fields

name: Popularity of the Technology Field
define: A variable representing the level of interest and development in a technology field, based on the number of patents.
source: Exploring the forward citation patterns of patents based on the evolution of technology fields

name: Technological Novelty
define: A dynamic variable measured by the minimum z-score of patent class combinations, indicating the novelty of combined knowledge in a patent.
source: Exploring the forward citation patterns of patents based on the evolution of technology fields

name: Age of the Patent
define: The time elapsed since the patent was granted, used to model the expected citation pattern with respect to the patent's age.
source: Exploring the forward citation patterns of patents based on the evolution of technology fields

name: Forward Number/Age
define: A ratio of the number of forward citations a patent has received to its age, reflecting the Matthew effect.
source: Exploring the forward citation patterns of patents based on the evolution of technology fields

name: Number of Inventors
define: A count of the inventors involved in a patent application, indicating the heterogeneity of R&D actors.
source: Exploring the forward citation patterns of patents based on the evolution of technology fields

name: Number of IPCs
define: A count of the International Patent Classifications assigned to a patent, controlling for its breadth.
source: Exploring the forward citation patterns of patents based on the evolution of technology fields

name: Number of Applicants
define: A count of the applicants or co-patentees involved in a patent, indicating external research collaborations.
source: Exploring the forward citation patterns of patents based on the evolution of technology fields

name: Number of Claims
define: A count of the patent claims, which is relevant to the legal scope and value of the patent.
source: Exploring the forward citation patterns of patents based on the evolution of technology fields

name: Number of References
define: A count of the references to prior patents, indicating the technological crowdedness of the area.
source: Exploring the forward citation patterns of patents based on the evolution of technology fields

name: Bridging Patents
define: Patents that build bridges between two or more application fields of a technology.
source: Bridge strongly or focus – An analysis of bridging patents in four application fields of carbon fiber reinforcements

name: Non-Bridging Patents
define: Patents that are assigned to only one application field of a technology.
source: Bridge strongly or focus – An analysis of bridging patents in four application fields of carbon fiber reinforcements

name: Forward Citations
define: Citations made to the patents by other patents, used as an indicator of patent quality.
source: Bridge strongly or focus – An analysis of bridging patents in four application fields of carbon fiber reinforcements

name: Claims
define: The section of a patent that defines the scope of the invention and outlines how broad or narrow the invention’s protection is.
source: Bridge strongly or focus – An analysis of bridging patents in four application fields of carbon fiber reinforcements

name: Product and Process Related Terms
define: Terms extracted from patents that are related to products, processes, or components.
source: Bridge strongly or focus – An analysis of bridging patents in four application fields of carbon fiber reinforcements

name: Semantic Similarity
define: A measure of how similar the text of a patent is to the semantic anchor points of different application fields.
source: Bridge strongly or focus – An analysis of bridging patents in four application fields of carbon fiber reinforcements

name: Patent Scope
define: The breadth of the protection offered by a patent, which can be influenced by the number of application fields bridged by the patent.
source: Bridge strongly or focus – An analysis of bridging patents in four application fields of carbon fiber reinforcements

name: Citation Value
define: The value of a patent based on the number of citations it receives, which can be adjusted for time lags.
source: Bridge strongly or focus – An analysis of bridging patents in four application fields of carbon fiber reinforcements

name: Technology Convergence
define: The movement of different knowledge elements, technologies, applications, and industries toward each other, blurring their former boundaries.
source: Bridge strongly or focus – An analysis of bridging patents in four application fields of carbon fiber reinforcements

name: Patent Examination Process
define: The process involving patent attorneys and examiners that determines the scope of a patent's protection.
source: Bridge strongly or focus – An analysis of bridging patents in four application fields of carbon fiber reinforcements

name: Innovation Genes
define: Elements controlling target attributes and stipulating the basic function of the provisions of the artificial system, structure, environment properties, and its characteristic of the life cycle stages.
source: The empirical research for taking technology innovation genes and forming chromosomes based on coal-bed gas mining

name: Patent Analysis
define: The process of extracting innovation genes from patent documents, which are a primary source of technical knowledge.
source: The empirical research for taking technology innovation genes and forming chromosomes based on coal-bed gas mining

name: K-means Clustering Algorithm
define: A method used for clustering innovation genes into different dimensions or categories.
source: The empirical research for taking technology innovation genes and forming chromosomes based on coal-bed gas mining

name: Technical Keywords
define: High-frequency words used in patent retrieval strategy to identify and extract related concepts, terminology, and attribute knowledge units.
source: The empirical research for taking technology innovation genes and forming chromosomes based on coal-bed gas mining

name: Patent Retrieval Strategy
define: A process of using keywords to retrieve patent documents, which is essential for collecting technological innovation elements.
source: The empirical research for taking technology innovation genes and forming chromosomes based on coal-bed gas mining

name: Innovation Chromosome Formation
define: The result of clustering innovation genes into a form that represents a combination of different innovation genes.
source: The empirical research for taking technology innovation genes and forming chromosomes based on coal-bed gas mining

name: CBM (Coal-Bed Methane) Mining Technology
define: A specific application area where the innovation gene and chromosome concept is applied to analyze technology innovation paths.
source: The empirical research for taking technology innovation genes and forming chromosomes based on coal-bed gas mining

name: Technology Innovation Path
define: The trajectory of technological development formed by the combination of different attributes of innovation genes.
source: The empirical research for taking technology innovation genes and forming chromosomes based on coal-bed gas mining

name: Patent Document Text
define: The textual form in which patents are usually presented, requiring analysis to extract technical information.
source: The empirical research for taking technology innovation genes and forming chromosomes based on coal-bed gas mining

name: Intellectual Property Classification (IPC)
define: A system used for subdividing technology areas, which can influence the selection of keywords and clustering of innovation genes.
source: The empirical research for taking technology innovation genes and forming chromosomes based on coal-bed gas mining

name: Interdisciplinarity (IDR)
define: A concept that integrates knowledge from multiple disciplines for fundamental understanding or problem solving.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: Variety
define: The number of scientific fields a paper cites, indicating the diversity of disciplines it draws upon.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: Balance
define: A measure of how evenly a paper cites references from different scientific fields, reflecting the distribution of interdisciplinary knowledge.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: Disparity
define: A measure of the relatedness or distance between the scientific fields a paper cites, indicating the cognitive distance of interdisciplinary integration.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: Rao-Stirling Index (RS)
define: An integrated metric of interdisciplinarity, combining variety, balance, and disparity.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: Patent Citations
define: The number of times a scientific paper is cited by patents, signaling its technological impact and relevance to patent development.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: Citations in 5, 10, and 15 Years
define: Binary variables indicating whether a paper has been cited by patents within different time windows after publication.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: Number of Citing Patents
define: The raw count of patents that cite a paper within a given time window.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: Weighted Patent Citations
define: The count of citing patents weighted by the impact of those patents themselves, reflecting the quality-adjusted impact.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: Journal Impact Factor (JIF)
define: A measure of the average number of citations a journal receives, used as a control variable for the prestige or visibility of the journal where the paper was published.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) Terms
define: Controlled vocabularies used to indicate the topics of a paper, serving as a control for topic diversity.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: Number of Authors
define: A count of authors on a paper, used as a control variable for the collaborative nature of the research.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: International Collaboration
define: A binary variable indicating whether a paper involves international collaboration, used as a control for the potential impact of global research networks.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: Year of Publication
define: A control variable to account for time-dependent factors in patent citations and scientific impact.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: Field of Research
define: A control variable representing the specific scientific field of the paper, to account for field-specific tendencies to be cited by patents.
source: Interdisciplinary research and technological impact: Evidence from biomedicine

name: Technological Innovation
define: A multi-faceted construct referring to the introduction of new or improved products or processes within an organization's operations.
source: Technological Innovation, Firm Performance, and Institutional Context: A Meta-Analysis

name: Firm Performance
define: The outcome of a firm's operations, often measured using objective measures like market share, ROA, ROS, or subjective measures from surveys.
source: Technological Innovation, Firm Performance, and Institutional Context: A Meta-Analysis

name: Capital Market Regulation
define: The level of financial development and market regulation in a nation, often measured using the Credit Information Index (CII).
source: Technological Innovation, Firm Performance, and Institutional Context: A Meta-Analysis

name: Patent Protection
define: The strength of intellectual property rights protection in a nation, measured using the Patent Protection Index (PPI).
source: Technological Innovation, Firm Performance, and Institutional Context: A Meta-Analysis

name: Individualism vs. Collectivism (IDV)
define: A cultural dimension measuring the degree of individualism in a nation's culture.
source: Technological Innovation, Firm Performance, and Institutional Context: A Meta-Analysis

name: Uncertainty Avoidance (UAI)
define: A cultural dimension measuring the degree of discomfort with uncertainty and ambiguity in a nation's culture.
source: Technological Innovation, Firm Performance, and Institutional Context: A Meta-Analysis

name: Artifact Interactions
define: A measure of how design changes in one component of an artifact influence others, quantified through the use of keywords in patent texts.
source: Artifact interactions retard technological improvement: An empirical study

name: Improvement Rates
define: The annual performance improvement rates of technological domains, derived from the slope of a linear curve fitted to log of the performance metric versus time.
source: Artifact interactions retard technological improvement: An empirical study

name: Keyword Count
define: The total count of specific keywords in patent texts that signal artifact interactions, normalized by the total word count in each domain's patent set.
source: Artifact interactions retard technological improvement: An empirical study

name: Technological Domains
define: Defined as a set of designed artifacts that utilize a recognized body of knowledge to achieve a specific generic function.
source: Artifact interactions retard technological improvement: An empirical study

name: Tacit Knowledge
define: The unspoken, uncodified knowledge that is embedded in the researchers and is critical to the commercialization of biotechnology.
source: University–Industry Linkages in the Support of Biotechnology Discoveries

name: Star Scientists
define: Scientists with significant contributions and expertise in their field, essential for the development and commercialization of biotechnology.
source: University–Industry Linkages in the Support of Biotechnology Discoveries

name: Bayh–Dole Act
define: A legislation that allows universities to retain ownership of patents and provides incentives for cooperation in development and commercialization.
source: University–Industry Linkages in the Support of Biotechnology Discoveries

name: University–Industry Linkages
define: Formal and informal collaborations between universities and industries, including patent licenses, research alliances, joint research, copublication, and consulting.
source: University–Industry Linkages in the Support of Biotechnology Discoveries

name: Commercial Applications
define: The practical use of biotechnology in trades or industries, facilitated by the transfer of knowledge from universities.
source: University–Industry Linkages in the Support of Biotechnology Discoveries

name: Innovation and Patenting
define: The process of creating new inventions and securing intellectual property rights, which is significantly influenced by university–industry linkages.
source: University–Industry Linkages in the Support of Biotechnology Discoveries

name: Knowledge Transfer
define: The process of moving knowledge from universities to practical applications in the private sector, a key aspect of biotechnology development.
source: University–Industry Linkages in the Support of Biotechnology Discoveries

name: Firm Absorptive Capacity
define: The ability of a firm to comprehend and utilize new knowledge, which affects the success of technology transfer from universities.
source: University–Industry Linkages in the Support of Biotechnology Discoveries

name: Regional Clusters
define: Geographic concentrations of businesses and research institutions in biotechnology, which can influence the success of knowledge transfer and commercialization.
source: University–Industry Linkages in the Support of Biotechnology Discoveries

name: Public Science
define: Research conducted in the public domain, which biotechnology firms depend on heavily, as indicated by McMillan et al. (2000).
source: University–Industry Linkages in the Support of Biotechnology Discoveries

name: Agricultural Biotechnology
define: A specific application of biotechnology in agriculture, which has seen extensive consolidation and is distinct from other biotechnology sectors.
source: University–Industry Linkages in the Support of Biotechnology Discoveries

name: Number of Claims
define: A measure of the legal definition of the invention and its validity.
source: Applying Multidimensional Quality Module and Hotelling’s T2 to Investigate Competitive Advantages of Digital Versatile Disc Patent Pools

name: Number of Independent Claims
define: A measure of innovative content, exclusivity, and patent quality.
source: Applying Multidimensional Quality Module and Hotelling’s T2 to Investigate Competitive Advantages of Digital Versatile Disc Patent Pools

name: Prior Citations Made
define: A measure of a patent’s likely validity based on references cited in a patent.
source: Applying Multidimensional Quality Module and Hotelling’s T2 to Investigate Competitive Advantages of Digital Versatile Disc Patent Pools

name: Number of Citations Received
define: A measure of the relative significance of a patent based on references made by subsequent patents.
source: Applying Multidimensional Quality Module and Hotelling’s T2 to Investigate Competitive Advantages of Digital Versatile Disc Patent Pools

name: DVD 3C Patents
define: A categorical variable representing patents included in the DVD 3C patent pool.
source: Applying Multidimensional Quality Module and Hotelling’s T2 to Investigate Competitive Advantages of Digital Versatile Disc Patent Pools

name: DVD 6C Patents
define: A categorical variable representing patents included in the DVD 6C patent pool.
source: Applying Multidimensional Quality Module and Hotelling’s T2 to Investigate Competitive Advantages of Digital Versatile Disc Patent Pools

name: T2 Control Chart
define: A statistical tool used to detect shifts in the process of patent quality performance.
source: Applying Multidimensional Quality Module and Hotelling’s T2 to Investigate Competitive Advantages of Digital Versatile Disc Patent Pools

name: Composite Score
define: A standardized score derived from the multidimensional patent quality module.
source: Applying Multidimensional Quality Module and Hotelling’s T2 to Investigate Competitive Advantages of Digital Versatile Disc Patent Pools

name: Year of DVD 3C Formation
define: A time variable representing the year when the DVD 3C patent pool was formed.
source: Applying Multidimensional Quality Module and Hotelling’s T2 to Investigate Competitive Advantages of Digital Versatile Disc Patent Pools

name: Year of DVD 6C Formation
define: A time variable representing the year when the DVD 6C patent pool was formed.
source: Applying Multidimensional Quality Module and Hotelling’s T2 to Investigate Competitive Advantages of Digital Versatile Disc Patent Pools

name: Academic Inventors
define: A sample group of professors who have applied for at least one patent.
source: Patents and scientific publications: an empirical analysis of the Italian system of academic professor recruitment

name: Academic Non-Inventors
define: A sample group of professors who have never filed any patents about their academic scientific research.
source: Patents and scientific publications: an empirical analysis of the Italian system of academic professor recruitment

name: Number of Publications
define: The total number of scientific publications produced by each professor during the period 1997-2012.
source: Patents and scientific publications: an empirical analysis of the Italian system of academic professor recruitment

name: Number of Patents
define: The total number of patents held by each professor.
source: Patents and scientific publications: an empirical analysis of the Italian system of academic professor recruitment

name: Number of Patent Applications
define: The total number of patent applications made by each professor.
source: Patents and scientific publications: an empirical analysis of the Italian system of academic professor recruitment

name: Scientific Sector
define: The specific scientific sector in which the professors operate, such as 'Applied Biology', 'Molecular Biology', 'Applied Physics', 'Chemical Sciences and Inorganic Systems', 'General and Clinical Pathology'.
source: Patents and scientific publications: an empirical analysis of the Italian system of academic professor recruitment

name: Patent Portfolio
define: A collection of patents owned by a firm, representing its technological capabilities.
source: Building Core Technological Competence: Patent Portfolio Perspective

name: Core Technological Competence (CTC)
define: The long-term accumulation of technical resources and competencies within a firm.
source: Building Core Technological Competence: Patent Portfolio Perspective

name: Patent Family
define: A group of patents sharing a common priority claim, indicating the development path of related technologies.
source: Building Core Technological Competence: Patent Portfolio Perspective

name: Patent Priority Approach (PPA)
define: A method to analyze a firm's patent portfolio strategy based on the priority claims of patents.
source: Building Core Technological Competence: Patent Portfolio Perspective

name: Patent Priority Network (PPN)
define: A network structure where nodes represent patents and arrows represent the priority claim relationships between them.
source: Building Core Technological Competence: Patent Portfolio Perspective

name: Litigation Value
define: The value of a patent that has been through a litigation stage, often considered more valuable.
source: Building Core Technological Competence: Patent Portfolio Perspective

name: Patent Chain
define: A series of patents connected by priority claims, representing the development path of a technology.
source: Building Core Technological Competence: Patent Portfolio Perspective

name: Critical Chain
define: The portfolio of all priorities within a patent family with the most priority claims, indicating the longest history and deepest technological extensibility.
source: Building Core Technological Competence: Patent Portfolio Perspective

name: Significant Chain
define: Patents with the highest ranking in terms of the total number of repeated priority claims, indicating their impact on the development of other patents.
source: Building Core Technological Competence: Patent Portfolio Perspective

name: Core Patent Candidates
define: Patents with potential to become part of the development or portfolio strategy of the company, based on the number of repeated priority claims.
source: Building Core Technological Competence: Patent Portfolio Perspective

name: Patent Eligibility
define: A binary variable indicating whether the invention is eligible for patent protection.
source: Capsule Based Neural Network Architecture to perform completeness check for Patent Eligibility Process

name: Invention Disclosure Form (IDF)
define: A document submitted by the inventor containing all the necessary aspects of the invention and the novel contributions made by the inventor.
source: Capsule Based Neural Network Architecture to perform completeness check for Patent Eligibility Process

name: Technical Write-up
define: A document shared by the inventors containing the details of their invention.
source: Capsule Based Neural Network Architecture to perform completeness check for Patent Eligibility Process

name: Sentence Classification
define: A task of categorizing sentences into predefined classes based on their content.
source: Capsule Based Neural Network Architecture to perform completeness check for Patent Eligibility Process

name: Dilated LSTM
define: A type of recurrent neural network layer that uses dilated convolution to capture long-term dependencies in the input data.
source: Capsule Based Neural Network Architecture to perform completeness check for Patent Eligibility Process

name: Capsule-based Neural Network
define: A neural network architecture that uses capsules to identify discriminative phrases and capture local order of words and their semantic representations.
source: Capsule Based Neural Network Architecture to perform completeness check for Patent Eligibility Process

name: Long-term Dependencies
define: The relationships between elements in a sequence that are far apart from each other in the input data.
source: Capsule Based Neural Network Architecture to perform completeness check for Patent Eligibility Process

name: Out Of Vocabulary (OOV) Words
define: Words that are not included in the predefined vocabulary of the model.
source: Capsule Based Neural Network Architecture to perform completeness check for Patent Eligibility Process

name: Training Data
define: The data used to train the neural network model to identify the key ingredients for patent eligibility.
source: Capsule Based Neural Network Architecture to perform completeness check for Patent Eligibility Process

name: Taxonomy of Necessary Ingredients
define: A classification system designed to categorize the key elements required for checking patent eligibility.
source: Capsule Based Neural Network Architecture to perform completeness check for Patent Eligibility Process

name: Industrial Policy
define: A set of government policies and measures aimed at promoting the development of specific industries.
source: Empirical insights into industrial policy’s influence on phytoprotection innovation

name: Invention Patent Applications
define: The number of applications for invention patents in the field of intelligent phytoprotection technology.
source: Empirical insights into industrial policy’s influence on phytoprotection innovation

name: Strategic Emerging Industries
define: A group of industries identified by the Chinese government as strategic emerging industries, including the new generation of information technology and high-end equipment manufacturing.
source: Empirical insights into industrial policy’s influence on phytoprotection innovation

name: Government Subsidies
define: Financial support provided by the government to encourage innovation and development in certain industries.
source: Empirical insights into industrial policy’s influence on phytoprotection innovation

name: Digital Economy
define: An economic system that is based on digital technologies and includes intelligent phytoprotection as one of its components.
source: Empirical insights into industrial policy’s influence on phytoprotection innovation

name: Smart Agriculture
define: Agricultural practices that integrate modern information technologies, such as IoT, big data, and the internet, to improve efficiency and sustainability.
source: Empirical insights into industrial policy’s influence on phytoprotection innovation

name: IPC Main Groups
define: International Patent Classification (IPC) main groups related to intelligent phytoprotection technology.
source: Empirical insights into industrial policy’s influence on phytoprotection innovation

name: Research and Development Initiatives
define: Innovative activities undertaken by enterprises, research institutes, and individuals in the field of intelligent phytoprotection.
source: Empirical insights into industrial policy’s influence on phytoprotection innovation

name: Academic Research
define: Scholarly work and publications in the field of intelligent phytoprotection, focusing on areas like artificial intelligence, remote sensing technology, and computer vision technology.
source: Empirical insights into industrial policy’s influence on phytoprotection innovation

name: Patent Technology Classification
define: The classification of patents based on their technological attributes and fields of application.
source: Empirical insights into industrial policy’s influence on phytoprotection innovation

name: Innovation
define: Measured by the number of patent applications, representing regional innovation capacity.
source: Innovation and Green Total Factor Productivity in China: A Linear and Nonlinear Investigation

name: Green Total Factor Productivity (GTFP)
define: A composite indicator that incorporates energy consumption and pollutant emissions, reflecting the economic efficiency considering environmental factors.
source: Innovation and Green Total Factor Productivity in China: A Linear and Nonlinear Investigation

name: Human Capital
define: Average schooling years of residents in each province, reflecting the knowledge and skills of the local labor force.
source: Innovation and Green Total Factor Productivity in China: A Linear and Nonlinear Investigation

name: Knowledge Stock
define: Measured by patent stock per 100,000 population in each province, representing the level of knowledge accumulation in a region.
source: Innovation and Green Total Factor Productivity in China: A Linear and Nonlinear Investigation

name: Financial Development
define: A composite index reflecting the scale, efficiency, and structure of the financial system in each province.
source: Innovation and Green Total Factor Productivity in China: A Linear and Nonlinear Investigation

name: Environmental Regulation
define: A composite index reflecting the intensity of environmental regulations in each region.
source: Innovation and Green Total Factor Productivity in China: A Linear and Nonlinear Investigation

name: Openness Degree
define: The ratio of total imports and exports to GDP in each province, reflecting the level of economic openness.
source: Innovation and Green Total Factor Productivity in China: A Linear and Nonlinear Investigation

name: Industry Structure
define: The share of value added of secondary industry to GDP in each province, representing the industrial composition of the region.
source: Innovation and Green Total Factor Productivity in China: A Linear and Nonlinear Investigation

name: Property Rights Structure
define: The proportion of non-state-owned investment to fixed assets investment in each province, indicating the degree of marketization and allocative efficiency.
source: Innovation and Green Total Factor Productivity in China: A Linear and Nonlinear Investigation

name: Patent Applications Quantity
define: The number of patent applications filed for a particular technology.
source: Evaluation Frame of Technological Developing Trend Based on Patent Information

name: Issued Patents Quantity
define: The number of patents issued for a particular technology.
source: Evaluation Frame of Technological Developing Trend Based on Patent Information

name: Backward Citations
define: The number of prior patents cited by a particular patent.
source: Evaluation Frame of Technological Developing Trend Based on Patent Information

name: Forward Citations
define: The number of citations received by a particular patent from later patents.
source: Evaluation Frame of Technological Developing Trend Based on Patent Information

name: IPC Categories
define: The International Patent Classification categories assigned to patents.
source: Evaluation Frame of Technological Developing Trend Based on Patent Information

name: Technology Life Cycle Stage
define: The stage in the life cycle of a technology, such as introduction, growth, maturity, or decline.
source: Evaluation Frame of Technological Developing Trend Based on Patent Information

name: Number of Concurrent Voice Communications Tasks
define: The number of simultaneous voice communications tasks an individual Navy watchstander must handle.
source: Facilitating the Watchstander’s Voice Communications Task in Future Navy Operations

name: Speech Rate Acceleration
define: The use of technology to increase the speed of speech without a meaningful decline in intelligibility.
source: Facilitating the Watchstander’s Voice Communications Task in Future Navy Operations

name: Serialized Communications Monitoring
define: A method of monitoring voice communications in a serialized manner, one after another, rather than concurrently.
source: Facilitating the Watchstander’s Voice Communications Task in Future Navy Operations

name: Attention
define: A performance measure related to how well listeners can focus on the auditory information presented to them.
source: Facilitating the Watchstander’s Voice Communications Task in Future Navy Operations

name: Comprehension
