source: Does Institutional Distance Affect Transnational Knowledge Spillovers Between Countries?

name: Imports
define: Used as a control variable to measure its impact on regional innovation performance.
source: Does Institutional Distance Affect Transnational Knowledge Spillovers Between Countries?

name: Exports
define: Used as a control variable to measure its impact on regional innovation performance.
source: Does Institutional Distance Affect Transnational Knowledge Spillovers Between Countries?

name: R&D Investment
define: Used as a control variable to measure its impact on regional innovation performance.
source: Does Institutional Distance Affect Transnational Knowledge Spillovers Between Countries?

name: Human Capital
define: Used as a control variable to measure its impact on regional innovation performance.
source: Does Institutional Distance Affect Transnational Knowledge Spillovers Between Countries?

name: Regional Economic Level
define: Used as a control variable to measure its impact on regional innovation performance.
source: Does Institutional Distance Affect Transnational Knowledge Spillovers Between Countries?

name: Academic Inventors
define: Researchers who are both authors of scientific publications and inventors on patents.
source: Do academic inventors have diverse interests?

name: Research Interests
define: The topics or areas that researchers focus on, as measured by the diversity of their work.
source: Do academic inventors have diverse interests?

name: Degree Centrality
define: A measure of the number of direct connections a researcher has in a network, indicating their sociability.
source: Do academic inventors have diverse interests?

name: Normalized Betweenness Centrality
define: A measure of how often a researcher lies on the shortest path between any two other researchers in a network.
source: Do academic inventors have diverse interests?

name: Closeness Centrality
define: A measure of how close a researcher is to all other researchers in a network, in terms of the shortest path distances.
source: Do academic inventors have diverse interests?

name: Constraint
define: A measure of the extent to which a researcher is invested in those nodes that are themselves invested in the neighbors of the researcher.
source: Do academic inventors have diverse interests?

name: Interest Diversity
define: The variety and balance of research interests of a researcher, as measured by indicators such as Rao-Stirling and DIV.
source: Do academic inventors have diverse interests?

name: Network Position
define: The role and influence of a researcher within a network, determined by centrality measures.
source: Do academic inventors have diverse interests?

name: Science-Technology Interactions
define: The connections and interactions between scientific research and technological development, often facilitated by academic inventors.
source: Do academic inventors have diverse interests?

name: Author Interest Discovery Model
define: A model used to identify and measure the research interests of authors, incorporating credit allocation schemes.
source: Do academic inventors have diverse interests?

name: IP Management Strategy
define: A categorical variable representing the level of IP management within a firm, categorized into five subsets.
source: Do IP Management Strategies Spur Innovative Outputs and Firm's Performance?: Evidence from Korean Manufacturing Industries

name: Innovative Outputs
define: A composite variable including patents, trademarks, and industrial designs as measures of innovation.
source: Do IP Management Strategies Spur Innovative Outputs and Firm's Performance?: Evidence from Korean Manufacturing Industries

name: Financial Performance
define: Dependent variables including value-added and revenue as indicators of a firm's financial health.
source: Do IP Management Strategies Spur Innovative Outputs and Firm's Performance?: Evidence from Korean Manufacturing Industries

name: R&D Inputs
define: Variables representing research and development investments and human resources, including R&D intensity and R&D employees.
source: Do IP Management Strategies Spur Innovative Outputs and Firm's Performance?: Evidence from Korean Manufacturing Industries

name: IP Function
define: A binary variable indicating the existence of an exclusive IP management division within a firm.
source: Do IP Management Strategies Spur Innovative Outputs and Firm's Performance?: Evidence from Korean Manufacturing Industries

name: IP Compensation
define: A binary variable indicating whether a firm has an official monetary compensation policy or in-service inventions by their employees.
source: Do IP Management Strategies Spur Innovative Outputs and Firm's Performance?: Evidence from Korean Manufacturing Industries

name: IP Expert
define: A count variable representing the number of IP management experts in a firm.
source: Do IP Management Strategies Spur Innovative Outputs and Firm's Performance?: Evidence from Korean Manufacturing Industries

name: Conglomerate
define: A binary variable indicating whether a firm is part of a conglomerate.
source: Do IP Management Strategies Spur Innovative Outputs and Firm's Performance?: Evidence from Korean Manufacturing Industries

name: Large Firm
define: A binary variable indicating whether a firm is considered large in size.
source: Do IP Management Strategies Spur Innovative Outputs and Firm's Performance?: Evidence from Korean Manufacturing Industries

name: Time Dummies
define: Control variables representing the different years of the study to account for global economic conditions.
source: Do IP Management Strategies Spur Innovative Outputs and Firm's Performance?: Evidence from Korean Manufacturing Industries

name: Intellectual Property Rights (IPRs)
define: Legal rights that grant exclusive rights to patent holders for a period of 20 years.
source: TRIPS to Where? A Narrative Review of the Empirical Literature on Intellectual Property Licensing Models to Promote Global Diffusion of Essential Medicines

name: Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS)
define: An international agreement administered by the WTO that sets minimum standards for the regulation of intellectual property.
source: TRIPS to Where? A Narrative Review of the Empirical Literature on Intellectual Property Licensing Models to Promote Global Diffusion of Essential Medicines

name: Compulsory Licensing (CLs)
define: A TRIPS flexibility that allows countries to license a patented product without the consent of the patent holder for public health reasons.
source: TRIPS to Where? A Narrative Review of the Empirical Literature on Intellectual Property Licensing Models to Promote Global Diffusion of Essential Medicines

name: Parallel Import
define: The practice of importing a product from a country where it is sold at a lower price, and selling it in a higher-priced market.
source: TRIPS to Where? A Narrative Review of the Empirical Literature on Intellectual Property Licensing Models to Promote Global Diffusion of Essential Medicines

name: Low- and Middle-Income Countries (LMICs)
define: Countries with lower economic status that often face challenges in accessing expensive patented medicines.
source: TRIPS to Where? A Narrative Review of the Empirical Literature on Intellectual Property Licensing Models to Promote Global Diffusion of Essential Medicines

name: Generic Manufacturers
define: Producers of generic versions of patented drugs, often at a lower cost.
source: TRIPS to Where? A Narrative Review of the Empirical Literature on Intellectual Property Licensing Models to Promote Global Diffusion of Essential Medicines

name: Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs)
define: Collaborative arrangements between government agencies and private-sector companies to finance and produce public goods and services.
source: TRIPS to Where? A Narrative Review of the Empirical Literature on Intellectual Property Licensing Models to Promote Global Diffusion of Essential Medicines

name: Voluntary Licensing
define: An agreement where the patent holder voluntarily grants a license to another party, usually under certain conditions, to produce and sell the patented product.
source: TRIPS to Where? A Narrative Review of the Empirical Literature on Intellectual Property Licensing Models to Promote Global Diffusion of Essential Medicines

name: Medicines Patent Pool (MPP)
define: A mechanism that facilitates the licensing of patents for essential medicines to increase their availability in LMICs.
source: TRIPS to Where? A Narrative Review of the Empirical Literature on Intellectual Property Licensing Models to Promote Global Diffusion of Essential Medicines

name: Access to Medicines
define: The ability of patients to obtain and afford necessary medicines, which can be influenced by factors such as price, availability, and intellectual property regulations.
source: TRIPS to Where? A Narrative Review of the Empirical Literature on Intellectual Property Licensing Models to Promote Global Diffusion of Essential Medicines

name: Exports (EXP)
define: The ratio of exports divided by GDP, representing a country's export activity.
source: Globalization and Knowledge Spillover: International Direct Investment, Exports and Patents

name: Outward Direct Investment (ODI)
define: The ratio of outward direct investment divided by GDP, indicating a country's outward investment activity.
source: Globalization and Knowledge Spillover: International Direct Investment, Exports and Patents

name: Inward Direct Investment (IDI)
define: The ratio of inward direct investment divided by GDP, indicating a country's inward investment activity.
source: Globalization and Knowledge Spillover: International Direct Investment, Exports and Patents

name: Cross-Border Mergers and Acquisitions (M&A_SALE)
define: The ratio of inward cross-border mergers and acquisitions divided by GDP, representing a part of inward direct investment.
source: Globalization and Knowledge Spillover: International Direct Investment, Exports and Patents

name: Other Direct Investment (PRIVATE)
define: The variable 'IDI' minus the variable 'M&A_SALE', representing other forms of direct investment.
source: Globalization and Knowledge Spillover: International Direct Investment, Exports and Patents

name: Gross Domestic Expenditure on R&D (GERD)
define: The ratio of gross domestic expenditure on R&D by GDP, representing a country's R&D investment.
source: Globalization and Knowledge Spillover: International Direct Investment, Exports and Patents

name: Expenditure on R&D in the Business Enterprise Sector (BERD)
define: The ratio of expenditure on R&D in the business enterprise sector by GDP, representing business sector R&D investment.
source: Globalization and Knowledge Spillover: International Direct Investment, Exports and Patents

name: Triadic Patents (TRI_PATENT)
define: The number of triadic patent families, serving as a proxy for innovation.
source: Globalization and Knowledge Spillover: International Direct Investment, Exports and Patents

name: European Patent Office Patents (EPO_PATENT)
define: The number of patent applications to the EPO, serving as a comparison to triadic patents.
source: Globalization and Knowledge Spillover: International Direct Investment, Exports and Patents

name: R&D Expenditure
define: A variable representing the expenditure on research and development in a country.
source: Empirical Study of the Factors which Have an Impact on University Performance in EU Countries, Reflected by the Shanghai Ranking

name: Public Expenditure on Education
define: A variable representing the public spending on education in a country.
source: Empirical Study of the Factors which Have an Impact on University Performance in EU Countries, Reflected by the Shanghai Ranking

name: Graduated Students
define: A variable representing the number of graduates aged 30-34 years.
source: Empirical Study of the Factors which Have an Impact on University Performance in EU Countries, Reflected by the Shanghai Ranking

name: International Students
define: A variable representing the number of international students in tertiary education.
source: Empirical Study of the Factors which Have an Impact on University Performance in EU Countries, Reflected by the Shanghai Ranking

name: Patent Stock
define: A variable representing the stock of patents in a country.
source: Empirical Study of the Factors which Have an Impact on University Performance in EU Countries, Reflected by the Shanghai Ranking

name: Lifelong Learning
define: A variable representing the participation in lifelong learning activities.
source: Empirical Study of the Factors which Have an Impact on University Performance in EU Countries, Reflected by the Shanghai Ranking

name: Shanghai Scores
define: A variable representing the scores of a country's universities in the Shanghai Ranking.
source: Empirical Study of the Factors which Have an Impact on University Performance in EU Countries, Reflected by the Shanghai Ranking

name: R&D Investment
define: The scale and intensity of investment in research and development activities.
source: Empirical Study on the R&D Spillover Effect among Regional Industries

name: Innovation Outcomes
define: The outputs generated from R&D activities, such as new technologies, products, or processes.
source: Empirical Study on the R&D Spillover Effect among Regional Industries

name: Economic Growth
define: The increase in the overall economic activity and market value of a region or industry.
source: Empirical Study on the R&D Spillover Effect among Regional Industries

name: TFP (Total Factor Productivity)
define: A measure of the efficiency with which resources are used in production, indicating the contribution of technological progress and innovation to output.
source: Empirical Study on the R&D Spillover Effect among Regional Industries

name: Beneficiary Effect
define: The extent to which a sector benefits from R&D spillover effects from other sectors.
source: Empirical Study on the R&D Spillover Effect among Regional Industries

name: Contributor Effect
define: The extent to which a sector contributes R&D spillover effects to other sectors.
source: Empirical Study on the R&D Spillover Effect among Regional Industries

name: Scientific Researching Cause
define: A sector involved in systematic and creative activities to increase knowledge and develop new applications.
source: Empirical Study on the R&D Spillover Effect among Regional Industries

name: Industrial Structure
define: The composition and organization of the industries within a region or economy.
source: Empirical Study on the R&D Spillover Effect among Regional Industries

name: Tertiary Industry
define: Service-providing industries, which are part of the economic sector that includes services such as education, health care, and retail.
source: Empirical Study on the R&D Spillover Effect among Regional Industries

name: Capital Input
define: The amount of capital resources invested in the production process.
source: Empirical Study on the R&D Spillover Effect among Regional Industries

name: R&D Investment
define: A continuous variable representing the research and development expenditure of the companies.
source: Marginal Effect of R&D Investment and Impact of Market Reforms—An Empirical Analysis of Japanese Electric Power Companies

name: Patent Applications
define: A count variable representing the number of published unexamined patent applications of the companies.
source: Marginal Effect of R&D Investment and Impact of Market Reforms—An Empirical Analysis of Japanese Electric Power Companies

name: Market Liberalization
define: Categorical variable with three levels: DEREG1 (extra-high voltage consumers liberalization), DEREG2 (high voltage consumers liberalization), and DEREG3 (electricity system reforms post-Fukushima disaster).
source: Marginal Effect of R&D Investment and Impact of Market Reforms—An Empirical Analysis of Japanese Electric Power Companies

name: Number of Employees
define: A continuous variable representing the number of employees in the companies.
source: Marginal Effect of R&D Investment and Impact of Market Reforms—An Empirical Analysis of Japanese Electric Power Companies

name: Operating Expenses
define: A continuous variable representing the operating expenses of the companies.
source: Marginal Effect of R&D Investment and Impact of Market Reforms—An Empirical Analysis of Japanese Electric Power Companies

name: Ratio of Joint Application
define: A ratio variable representing the proportion of joint patent applications to total applications.
source: Marginal Effect of R&D Investment and Impact of Market Reforms—An Empirical Analysis of Japanese Electric Power Companies

name: Marshallian Spillovers
define: A measure of knowledge spillovers within the same technology sector, affecting job creation negatively.
source: The Effect of Marshallian and Jacobian Knowledge Spillovers on Jobs in the Solar, Wind and Energy Efficiency Sector

name: Jacobian Spillovers
define: A measure of knowledge spillovers across different technology sectors, potentially affecting job creation positively.
source: The Effect of Marshallian and Jacobian Knowledge Spillovers on Jobs in the Solar, Wind and Energy Efficiency Sector

name: Technical Efficiency
define: Evaluated through data envelopment analysis (DEA), based on the Malmquist productivity index.
source: The Effect of Marshallian and Jacobian Knowledge Spillovers on Jobs in the Solar, Wind and Energy Efficiency Sector

name: Job Creation
define: The number of jobs created in related fields to green energy and jobs pushed away in other sectors.
source: The Effect of Marshallian and Jacobian Knowledge Spillovers on Jobs in the Solar, Wind and Energy Efficiency Sector

name: Innovation in Green Energy Technologies
define: Advances in green energy technologies that may create new jobs in other sectors or reduce them.
source: The Effect of Marshallian and Jacobian Knowledge Spillovers on Jobs in the Solar, Wind and Energy Efficiency Sector

name: Production Efficiency
define: In terms of jobs and job spillovers from inventions in solar, wind, and energy efficiency, explored through DEA.
source: The Effect of Marshallian and Jacobian Knowledge Spillovers on Jobs in the Solar, Wind and Energy Efficiency Sector

name: Firm's Efficiency Score
define: A measure of how close a firm is to the production frontier, used in tobit regression analysis.
source: The Effect of Marshallian and Jacobian Knowledge Spillovers on Jobs in the Solar, Wind and Energy Efficiency Sector

name: R&D Capital Stock
define: A firm's investment in research and development, used to measure the diversity degree between the firms.
source: The Effect of Marshallian and Jacobian Knowledge Spillovers on Jobs in the Solar, Wind and Energy Efficiency Sector

name: Sales
define: Used as an output variable in the efficiency process, measured as the ratio between sales and the number of employees.
source: The Effect of Marshallian and Jacobian Knowledge Spillovers on Jobs in the Solar, Wind and Energy Efficiency Sector

name: Number of Employees
define: Used as an input variable in the efficiency process, indicating the labor component of the production.
source: The Effect of Marshallian and Jacobian Knowledge Spillovers on Jobs in the Solar, Wind and Energy Efficiency Sector

name: Gross Domestic Product (GDP)
define: A measure of economic performance in USD trillion.
source: The Impact of Economic, Energy, and Environmental Factors on the Development of the Hydrogen Economy

name: Population
define: The number of people in a country in millions.
source: The Impact of Economic, Energy, and Environmental Factors on the Development of the Hydrogen Economy

name: Total Final Energy Consumption (TFC)
define: The total amount of energy consumed, including transport and industry, in Mtoe.
source: The Impact of Economic, Energy, and Environmental Factors on the Development of the Hydrogen Economy

name: Renewable Energy Share (RES)
define: The proportion of the total primary energy supply that is renewable, in %.
source: The Impact of Economic, Energy, and Environmental Factors on the Development of the Hydrogen Economy

name: CO2 Emissions
define: Total carbon dioxide emissions, including transport and industry, in Mt.
source: The Impact of Economic, Energy, and Environmental Factors on the Development of the Hydrogen Economy

name: Hydrogen Production Volume (HPV)
define: The volume of hydrogen production in billion m3.
source: The Impact of Economic, Energy, and Environmental Factors on the Development of the Hydrogen Economy

name: Number of Patents (PAT)
define: The number of patents for hydrogen production and fuel cells.
source: The Impact of Economic, Energy, and Environmental Factors on the Development of the Hydrogen Economy

name: Energy R&D Budget (RDD)
define: The budget allocated for research, development, and demonstration in the energy sector, in USD million.
source: The Impact of Economic, Energy, and Environmental Factors on the Development of the Hydrogen Economy

name: PatH2FC
define: The number of patents on hydrogen and fuel cells, used as a proxy for green technological change.
source: Lock-In Effects on the Energy Sector: Evidence from Hydrogen Patenting Activities

name: FEEDintariff
define: Mean feed-in tariff for power generation, a policy instrument for renewable energy investments.
source: Lock-In Effects on the Energy Sector: Evidence from Hydrogen Patenting Activities

name: FFsupport
define: Total fossil fuel support as a percentage of total tax revenues, indicating government intervention in brown energy technologies.
source: Lock-In Effects on the Energy Sector: Evidence from Hydrogen Patenting Activities

name: GDPppp
define: GDP per capita in terms of purchasing power parity, a macroeconomic control variable.
source: Lock-In Effects on the Energy Sector: Evidence from Hydrogen Patenting Activities

name: Unempl
define: Unemployment rate, a macroeconomic control variable.
source: Lock-In Effects on the Energy Sector: Evidence from Hydrogen Patenting Activities

name: entrep
define: Cost of starting a business as a percentage of income per capita, a proxy for entrepreneurship.
source: Lock-In Effects on the Energy Sector: Evidence from Hydrogen Patenting Activities

name: INT
define: Interest rates on bank credit to the private sector, a proxy for financing constraints.
source: Lock-In Effects on the Energy Sector: Evidence from Hydrogen Patenting Activities

name: GOVdebt
define: Government debt as a percentage of GDP, a measure of public investment in policies.
source: Lock-In Effects on the Energy Sector: Evidence from Hydrogen Patenting Activities

name: GINI
define: Gini income inequality index, a control variable for societal factors.
source: Lock-In Effects on the Energy Sector: Evidence from Hydrogen Patenting Activities

name: GDP
define: Gross Domestic Product per capita, used as a measure of economic activity.
source: The Impact of Technology and Government Policies on OECD Carbon Dioxide Emissions

name: Fossil Fuel Consumption
define: The percentage of total energy consumption from fossil fuels.
source: The Impact of Technology and Government Policies on OECD Carbon Dioxide Emissions

name: Industrialisation
define: The value added by the industry sector, including construction, as a percentage of GDP.
source: The Impact of Technology and Government Policies on OECD Carbon Dioxide Emissions

name: Urbanisation
define: The percentage of the total population living in urban areas.
source: The Impact of Technology and Government Policies on OECD Carbon Dioxide Emissions

name: Environmental Patents
define: Patents on Environment Technologies as a percentage of Total Patents.
source: The Impact of Technology and Government Policies on OECD Carbon Dioxide Emissions

name: Environmental Tax Revenue
define: Environmental Tax Revenue as a percentage of GDP and as a percentage of total taxation.
source: The Impact of Technology and Government Policies on OECD Carbon Dioxide Emissions

name: Government Subsidies
define: A continuous variable representing the amount of financial support provided by the government to enterprises in the new energy vehicle industry.
source: Industrial Policy and Technological Innovation of New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Technological Innovation Quantity
define: A composite measure including the number of total patents, invention patents, and utility model patents.
source: Industrial Policy and Technological Innovation of New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Technological Innovation Quality
define: A measure based on patent knowledge width, reflecting the complexity and universality of the knowledge contained in patents.
source: Industrial Policy and Technological Innovation of New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: R&D Capital Investment
define: A continuous variable representing the annual R&D expenditure of an enterprise.
source: Industrial Policy and Technological Innovation of New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: External Financing
define: A continuous variable measured by the ratio of net cash flow from financing activities to total assets.
source: Industrial Policy and Technological Innovation of New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: External Attention
define: A continuous variable represented by the number of analysts making profit forecasts for enterprises each year.
source: Industrial Policy and Technological Innovation of New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Enterprise Size
define: A categorical variable distinguishing between large and small enterprises.
source: Industrial Policy and Technological Innovation of New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Industrial Chain Position
define: A categorical variable classifying enterprises into upstream, midstream, and downstream of the industrial chain.
source: Industrial Policy and Technological Innovation of New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Capital Structure
define: A control variable represented by the asset-liability ratio.
source: Industrial Policy and Technological Innovation of New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Profitability
define: A control variable represented by the net interest rate of total assets.
source: Industrial Policy and Technological Innovation of New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Enterprise Growth Ability
define: A control variable represented by the year-on-year growth rate of operating revenue.
source: Industrial Policy and Technological Innovation of New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Innovation
define: A variable that encompasses the development and adoption of new ideas, processes, or products in the mining sector.
source: Innovation and Climate Change Mitigation Technology in the Asian and African Mining Sector: Empirical Analysis Using the LMDI Method

name: Climate Change Mitigation Technology (CCMT)
define: Technologies that are aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions or enhancing carbon sinks in the mining sector.
source: Innovation and Climate Change Mitigation Technology in the Asian and African Mining Sector: Empirical Analysis Using the LMDI Method

name: Patents
define: A measure of innovative output in the form of patent applications filed in the mining sector.
source: Innovation and Climate Change Mitigation Technology in the Asian and African Mining Sector: Empirical Analysis Using the LMDI Method

name: Research and Development (R&D)
define: Investments in the creation of new knowledge and technologies, including funding and human resources allocated to R&D activities.
source: Innovation and Climate Change Mitigation Technology in the Asian and African Mining Sector: Empirical Analysis Using the LMDI Method

name: Economic Growth
define: The overall growth of a country's economy, which can be influenced by various factors including innovation and technology adoption.
source: Innovation and Climate Change Mitigation Technology in the Asian and African Mining Sector: Empirical Analysis Using the LMDI Method

name: Environmental Stability
define: The state of maintaining a balance in the environment, which can be affected by the adoption of CCMT.
source: Innovation and Climate Change Mitigation Technology in the Asian and African Mining Sector: Empirical Analysis Using the LMDI Method

name: Policy and Regulation
define: Government actions and rules that can influence the direction and pace of innovation and technology adoption in the mining sector.
source: Innovation and Climate Change Mitigation Technology in the Asian and African Mining Sector: Empirical Analysis Using the LMDI Method

name: Technological Advancement
define: The progress in technology, which can be a result of R&D investments and can enable the development of CCMT.
source: Innovation and Climate Change Mitigation Technology in the Asian and African Mining Sector: Empirical Analysis Using the LMDI Method

name: Mining Activity
define: The level of mining operations, which can be a driver for innovation and technology adoption to improve efficiency and reduce environmental impact.
source: Innovation and Climate Change Mitigation Technology in the Asian and African Mining Sector: Empirical Analysis Using the LMDI Method

name: International Collaboration
define: The extent of cooperation between countries, which can facilitate the transfer of technology and knowledge in the mining sector.
source: Innovation and Climate Change Mitigation Technology in the Asian and African Mining Sector: Empirical Analysis Using the LMDI Method

name: EPLI
define: A dummy variable representing whether a listed company or its subsidiary has purchased environmental pollution liability insurance.
source: Environmental pollution liability insurance and green innovation of enterprises: Incentive tools or self-interest means?

name: Green Innovation
define: Measured by the natural logarithm of the number of green patent applications plus 1.
source: Environmental pollution liability insurance and green innovation of enterprises: Incentive tools or self-interest means?

name: Financing Constraints
define: Measured by the SA index, which is calculated using enterprise size and age.
source: Environmental pollution liability insurance and green innovation of enterprises: Incentive tools or self-interest means?

name: Agency Costs
define: Measured by the administrative expense rate, the proportion of administrative expenses to operating revenue.
source: Environmental pollution liability insurance and green innovation of enterprises: Incentive tools or self-interest means?

name: Enterprise Size
define: The natural logarithm of total assets of the company.
source: Environmental pollution liability insurance and green innovation of enterprises: Incentive tools or self-interest means?

name: Enterprise Age
define: The natural logarithm of the number of years since the company was founded.
source: Environmental pollution liability insurance and green innovation of enterprises: Incentive tools or self-interest means?

name: Capital Structure
define: Total liabilities divided by total assets.
source: Environmental pollution liability insurance and green innovation of enterprises: Incentive tools or self-interest means?

name: Solvency
define: Liquid assets divided by liquid liabilities.
source: Environmental pollution liability insurance and green innovation of enterprises: Incentive tools or self-interest means?

name: Growth
define: The increase in operating revenue for the period divided by operating revenue for the previous period.
source: Environmental pollution liability insurance and green innovation of enterprises: Incentive tools or self-interest means?

name: Cash Flow
define: The net cash flow from operating activities divided by total assets.
source: Environmental pollution liability insurance and green innovation of enterprises: Incentive tools or self-interest means?

name: R&D Investment
define: The actual annual R&D capital input reflecting the innovation competitiveness of software enterprises.
source: Evaluation Model and Empirical Study for Innovation Efficiency of Software Industry

name: Enterprises' Scale
define: The number of employees, which is chosen as the input index to reflect the size and R&D strength of software enterprises.
source: Evaluation Model and Empirical Study for Innovation Efficiency of Software Industry

name: Number of Licensed Patents
define: The output index measuring the innovation performance and output of inventions, especially commercially valuable patents.
source: Evaluation Model and Empirical Study for Innovation Efficiency of Software Industry

name: Innovation Efficiency
define: The overall efficiency of software enterprises' innovation processes, combining technical and scale efficiency.
source: Evaluation Model and Empirical Study for Innovation Efficiency of Software Industry

name: Technical Efficiency
define: The measure of how close outputs are to their maximum relative to inputs, indicating the best practice level.
source: Evaluation Model and Empirical Study for Innovation Efficiency of Software Industry

name: Scale Efficiency
define: The measure of returns to scale, indicating whether the enterprise operates at an optimal scale.
source: Evaluation Model and Empirical Study for Innovation Efficiency of Software Industry

name: Service Software Enterprises
define: A category of software enterprises focused on computer services, distinguished from product software enterprises.
source: Evaluation Model and Empirical Study for Innovation Efficiency of Software Industry

name: Product Software Enterprises
define: A category of software enterprises focused on software products, distinguished from service software enterprises.
source: Evaluation Model and Empirical Study for Innovation Efficiency of Software Industry

name: Corporate Innovation
define: A variable representing a firm's innovation activities, operationalized through the number of patents filed and the cumulative number of patents.
source: Curvilinear Relationship between Corporate Innovation and Environmental Sustainability

name: Environmental Performance
define: A variable representing a firm's involvement in environmental sustainability, measured by the degree to which a firm addresses environmental concerns arising from its operations.
source: Curvilinear Relationship between Corporate Innovation and Environmental Sustainability

name: Trade-off Costs
define: A conceptual variable representing the costs associated with the allocation of resources between innovation and environmental sustainability activities.
source: Curvilinear Relationship between Corporate Innovation and Environmental Sustainability

name: Resource Allocation Approach
define: A theoretical framework suggesting a negative relationship between a firm's innovation and its environmental performance due to budget constraints.
source: Curvilinear Relationship between Corporate Innovation and Environmental Sustainability

name: Eco-Innovation Approach
define: A theoretical framework proposing that higher-quality innovation leads to better environmental performance, suggesting a positive relationship between innovation and environmental sustainability.
source: Curvilinear Relationship between Corporate Innovation and Environmental Sustainability

name: Firm Size
define: A control variable representing the size of the firm, measured by the number of employees and the value of total assets.
source: Curvilinear Relationship between Corporate Innovation and Environmental Sustainability

name: Industry Asset Intensity
define: A control variable representing the barrier to exit in studying diversification strategies, measured by aggregating total assets for firms with the given 3-digit SIC code.
source: Curvilinear Relationship between Corporate Innovation and Environmental Sustainability

name: Prior Environmental Performance
define: A control variable representing the firm's environmental performance in the previous year.
source: Curvilinear Relationship between Corporate Innovation and Environmental Sustainability

name: Prior Financial Performance
define: A control variable measured by return-on-assets (ROA), adjusted by industry-level ROA.
source: Curvilinear Relationship between Corporate Innovation and Environmental Sustainability

name: Number of Executives
define: A control variable representing the influence of the upper-echelon's decision-making on environmental performance.
source: Curvilinear Relationship between Corporate Innovation and Environmental Sustainability

name: Marketing Intensity
define: A control variable measured with the ratio of administrative expenditures to R&D expenditures.
source: Curvilinear Relationship between Corporate Innovation and Environmental Sustainability

name: Technological Relatedness (ωi,α,t)
define: A measure of the proportion of related technologies already existing in a firm.
source: Factors That Affect the Technological Transition of Firms Toward the Industry 4.0 Technologies

name: Technological Complexity (TCIα,t)
define: A measure used to capture the structural characteristics of a technology and a firm's technological capability.
source: Factors That Affect the Technological Transition of Firms Toward the Industry 4.0 Technologies

name: Government R&D Support (Govi,α,t)
define: A binary variable indicating whether a firm received government support for developing a specific technology.
source: Factors That Affect the Technological Transition of Firms Toward the Industry 4.0 Technologies

name: Firm Age (Agei,t)
define: The tenure of a firm since its inception.
source: Factors That Affect the Technological Transition of Firms Toward the Industry 4.0 Technologies

name: Number of Employees (num_employeei,t)
define: A measure of the size of the firm.
source: Factors That Affect the Technological Transition of Firms Toward the Industry 4.0 Technologies

name: Profit Ratio (Profit_ratioi,t)
define: A measure of profit-to-sales ratio of a firm.
source: Factors That Affect the Technological Transition of Firms Toward the Industry 4.0 Technologies

name: Debt Ratio (Debt_ratioi,t)
define: A measure of total liabilities to total assets of a firm.
source: Factors That Affect the Technological Transition of Firms Toward the Industry 4.0 Technologies

name: Number of Revealed Technological Advantages (num_RTAi,t)
define: A measure of the number of technologies that offer an advantage within a firm.
source: Factors That Affect the Technological Transition of Firms Toward the Industry 4.0 Technologies

name: Number of Competitors (num_competitorα,t)
define: The number of firms that have a comparative advantage in a specific technology.
source: Factors That Affect the Technological Transition of Firms Toward the Industry 4.0 Technologies

name: Green Innovation (GI)
define: The output of green innovation, measured by the number of green innovation patents.
source: Assessing the Impact of Green Innovation on Corporate Sustainable Development

name: Corporate Sustainable Development Ability (SGR and SUS)
define: The long-term profitability and lasting competitiveness of enterprises, measured by the sustainable growth ratio (SGR) and another index (SUS).
source: Assessing the Impact of Green Innovation on Corporate Sustainable Development

name: Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)
define: The overall performance of the listed companies' CSR, measured by the CSR score.
source: Assessing the Impact of Green Innovation on Corporate Sustainable Development

name: Scientific Research Ability (HIGHTECH)
define: A binary variable indicating whether a company belongs to one of the six high-tech industries.
source: Assessing the Impact of Green Innovation on Corporate Sustainable Development

name: Invention Patents (GI-INVENTION)
define: The number of green invention patents authorized.
source: Assessing the Impact of Green Innovation on Corporate Sustainable Development

name: Non-Invention Patents (GI-OTHER)
define: The number of green utility model patents and green appearance patents authorized.
source: Assessing the Impact of Green Innovation on Corporate Sustainable Development

name: State-Owned Enterprises (SOE)
define: A binary variable indicating whether a company is state-owned.
source: Assessing the Impact of Green Innovation on Corporate Sustainable Development

name: Property Rights
define: The nature of property rights, which may influence the relationship between green innovation and corporate sustainable development.
source: Assessing the Impact of Green Innovation on Corporate Sustainable Development

name: Patent Applications (GI_Application)
define: The number of green patent applications as an alternative measure for green innovation.
source: Assessing the Impact of Green Innovation on Corporate Sustainable Development

name: Green Patent Applications
define: A count variable representing the number of green patent applications, used to indicate green technology innovation.
source: How Does Government Policy Improve Green Technology Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Policy Quantity
define: A variable representing the sum of comprehensive policy quantity in the research period, reflecting the cumulative effect of policies on green technology innovation.
source: How Does Government Policy Improve Green Technology Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Policy Effectiveness
define: A variable representing the score of green technology innovation policy effectiveness, based on the level of policy promulgation.
source: How Does Government Policy Improve Green Technology Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Policy Executive Force
define: A variable representing the score of green technology innovation policy executive force, based on the level of policy promulgation.
source: How Does Government Policy Improve Green Technology Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Enterprise Innovation Vitality
define: A variable measured by the new product sales revenue of industrial enterprises, indicating the ability to develop and adopt new products and process technologies.
source: How Does Government Policy Improve Green Technology Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Industry-University-Research Cooperation
define: A variable measured by the sum of the investment in research institutes and universities of industrial enterprises' R&D external expenditures.
source: How Does Government Policy Improve Green Technology Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Degree of Fiscal Attention
define: A variable measured by the ratio of local fiscal expenditure on science, technology, and environment to local fiscal expenditure on the general budget.
source: How Does Government Policy Improve Green Technology Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Degree of Openness
define: A variable represented by foreign direct investment in various provinces.
source: How Does Government Policy Improve Green Technology Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Technology Environment
define: A variable expressed by employees of science and technology and environment units in various provinces.
source: How Does Government Policy Improve Green Technology Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Economic Development
define: A variable measured by the per capita GDP in various provinces.
source: How Does Government Policy Improve Green Technology Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Deleveraging Policy
define: A policy issued by the State Council of China in 2016 aimed at reducing enterprise leverage and optimizing capital structure.
source: Research on the Impact of Deleveraging Policy on Enterprise Green Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Enterprise Green Innovation
define: New technologies or processes that help reduce pollution and save resources, measured by the number of green patent applications.
source: Research on the Impact of Deleveraging Policy on Enterprise Green Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Equity Financing
define: A method of financing where enterprises issue shares to raise funds, used to measure the change in owner's equity.
source: Research on the Impact of Deleveraging Policy on Enterprise Green Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Ownership Concentration
define: Measured by the shareholding ratio of the top five shareholders, indicating the level of internal supervision.
source: Research on the Impact of Deleveraging Policy on Enterprise Green Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Green Invention Patents
define: A type of green patent with higher technological content, attracting more investors sensitive to green innovation.
source: Research on the Impact of Deleveraging Policy on Enterprise Green Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Green Utility Model Patents
define: A type of green patent with lower technological content compared to invention patents.
source: Research on the Impact of Deleveraging Policy on Enterprise Green Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Enterprise Size
define: A categorical variable dividing enterprises into large-scale and small-scale based on operating income and number of employees.
source: Research on the Impact of Deleveraging Policy on Enterprise Green Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Property Right
define: A dummy variable indicating whether the enterprise is state-owned or non-state-owned.
source: Research on the Impact of Deleveraging Policy on Enterprise Green Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Industry Characteristics
define: A dummy variable for technology-intensive enterprises versus other types of enterprises.
source: Research on the Impact of Deleveraging Policy on Enterprise Green Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Financial Development Level
define: A dummy variable indicating whether the region is financially developed or undeveloped based on the marketization index.
source: Research on the Impact of Deleveraging Policy on Enterprise Green Innovation: An Empirical Study in China

name: Special Economic Zones (SEZs)
define: A policy initiative aimed at promoting regional economic growth and development.
source: Can the Special Economic Zones Promote the Green Technology Innovation of Enterprises? An Evidence From China

name: Green Technology Innovation
define: The process of creating and developing new technologies that are environmentally friendly and sustainable.
source: Can the Special Economic Zones Promote the Green Technology Innovation of Enterprises? An Evidence From China

name: Green Patent Applications
define: The number of applications for patents related to green technology innovations.
source: Can the Special Economic Zones Promote the Green Technology Innovation of Enterprises? An Evidence From China

name: Preferential Policy Subsidies
define: Financial incentives provided by the government to encourage certain activities or behaviors, such as green technology innovation.
source: Can the Special Economic Zones Promote the Green Technology Innovation of Enterprises? An Evidence From China

name: Agglomeration Effect
define: The economic benefits that arise when similar or related industries cluster together, often leading to increased productivity and innovation.
source: Can the Special Economic Zones Promote the Green Technology Innovation of Enterprises? An Evidence From China

name: Enterprise Ownership
define: The type of ownership of an enterprise, which can influence its access to resources and its strategic decisions.
source: Can the Special Economic Zones Promote the Green Technology Innovation of Enterprises? An Evidence From China

name: Regional Level
define: The geographical scope or tier of the region, which can affect the implementation and impact of policies like SEZs.
source: Can the Special Economic Zones Promote the Green Technology Innovation of Enterprises? An Evidence From China

name: Innovation Efficiency
define: A measure of the effectiveness of innovation activities, often related to the output of patents per unit of R&D input.
source: Can the Special Economic Zones Promote the Green Technology Innovation of Enterprises? An Evidence From China

name: R&D Expenditure
define: The amount of money spent on research and development activities by an enterprise.
source: Can the Special Economic Zones Promote the Green Technology Innovation of Enterprises? An Evidence From China

name: Enterprise Characteristics
define: Attributes of an enterprise, such as its size, age, and industry, which can influence its innovation capabilities.
source: Can the Special Economic Zones Promote the Green Technology Innovation of Enterprises? An Evidence From China

name: Economic Complexity Index (ECI)
define: A measure of the capacity of an economy to connect locations to the economic activities present in them.
source: How Green is the Economic Complexity in the Central and Eastern European Union Countries?

name: Green Openness Index (GOP)
define: The share of the total present value of exported and imported green goods as a percentage of GDP.
source: How Green is the Economic Complexity in the Central and Eastern European Union Countries?

name: Financial Development Index (FinDev)
define: An aggregate of Financial Institutions index and Financial Markets Index.
source: How Green is the Economic Complexity in the Central and Eastern European Union Countries?

name: Research and Development Expenditures (R&D)
define: Research and development expenditures as a percentage of GDP.
source: How Green is the Economic Complexity in the Central and Eastern European Union Countries?

name: Total Patents (PT)
define: Patent applications filed through the Patent Cooperation Treaty procedure or with a national patent office.
source: How Green is the Economic Complexity in the Central and Eastern European Union Countries?

name: Human Capital (HC)
define: Human Capital Index, based on years of schooling and returns to education.
source: How Green is the Economic Complexity in the Central and Eastern European Union Countries?

name: Gross Capital Formation (GCF)
define: Share of Gross Capital formation in GDP.
source: How Green is the Economic Complexity in the Central and Eastern European Union Countries?

name: Foreign Direct Investment (FDI)
define: Foreign Direct Investment net inflows as a percentage of GDP.
source: How Green is the Economic Complexity in the Central and Eastern European Union Countries?

name: Corporate Green Innovation
define: Measured by the application and authorization volume of green patents.
source: The impact of ESG ratings under market soft regulation on corporate green innovation: an empirical study from informal environmental governance

name: ESG Ratings
define: A method for assessing a company’s performance in the areas of environment, social responsibility, and governance.
source: The impact of ESG ratings under market soft regulation on corporate green innovation: an empirical study from informal environmental governance

name: Financing Constraints
define: Challenges that companies face during financing, potentially leading to capital shortages and restrictions on investments.
source: The impact of ESG ratings under market soft regulation on corporate green innovation: an empirical study from informal environmental governance

name: Return on Assets
define: Net profit of enterprise / Average value of total assets of Enterprise.
source: The impact of ESG ratings under market soft regulation on corporate green innovation: an empirical study from informal environmental governance

name: Debt to Assets Ratio
define: Total liabilities / Total Assets.
source: The impact of ESG ratings under market soft regulation on corporate green innovation: an empirical study from informal environmental governance

name: Firm Age
define: Natural logarithm of the year minus the year the company went public plus one.
source: The impact of ESG ratings under market soft regulation on corporate green innovation: an empirical study from informal environmental governance

name: Revenue Growth Rate
define: (Current period operating income - Previous period operating income) / Previous Period operating income.
source: The impact of ESG ratings under market soft regulation on corporate green innovation: an empirical study from informal environmental governance

name: Equity Concentration
define: Largest shareholder shareholding / total shares.
source: The impact of ESG ratings under market soft regulation on corporate green innovation: an empirical study from informal environmental governance

name: Capital Intensity
define: Natural logarithm of net fixed assets / Total number of employees.
source: The impact of ESG ratings under market soft regulation on corporate green innovation: an empirical study from informal environmental governance

name: Employee Labor Productivity
define: Natural logarithm of revenue / Total number of employees.
source: The impact of ESG ratings under market soft regulation on corporate green innovation: an empirical study from informal environmental governance

name: CEO-Chairperson Duality
define: A binary variable where the value is 1 if the chairman and the general manager are the same person, otherwise it is 0.
source: The impact of ESG ratings under market soft regulation on corporate green innovation: an empirical study from informal environmental governance

name: Proportion of Independent Directors
define: Number of independent directors / Number of board members.
source: The impact of ESG ratings under market soft regulation on corporate green innovation: an empirical study from informal environmental governance

name: National High-Tech Zone Policy Implementation
define: A policy dummy variable indicating the establishment of national high-tech zones.
source: Achieving carbon neutrality: How does the construction of national high-tech zones affect the green innovation of enterprises? Based on quasi-natural experiments in pilot areas in China

name: Enterprise Green Innovation
define: A variable measured by the number of green patents, including green invention patents and green utility model patents.
source: Achieving carbon neutrality: How does the construction of national high-tech zones affect the green innovation of enterprises? Based on quasi-natural experiments in pilot areas in China

name: Factor Agglomeration Effect
define: The effect of improving the agglomeration of talent, capital, and other resources to boost regional technological growth.
source: Achieving carbon neutrality: How does the construction of national high-tech zones affect the green innovation of enterprises? Based on quasi-natural experiments in pilot areas in China

name: Innovation-Driving Effect
define: The effect of promoting innovation and development in high-tech industries and surrounding linked firms.
source: Achieving carbon neutrality: How does the construction of national high-tech zones affect the green innovation of enterprises? Based on quasi-natural experiments in pilot areas in China

name: Institutional Environmental Effect
define: The effect of improving the regional institutional environment, reducing business transaction costs and production costs.
source: Achieving carbon neutrality: How does the construction of national high-tech zones affect the green innovation of enterprises? Based on quasi-natural experiments in pilot areas in China

name: Economic Development Strength
define: A categorical variable representing the level of economic development in different regions, such as first- and second-tier cities, and third-tier cities and below.
source: Achieving carbon neutrality: How does the construction of national high-tech zones affect the green innovation of enterprises? Based on quasi-natural experiments in pilot areas in China

name: Enterprise Ownership
define: A categorical variable representing the ownership structure of enterprises, such as state-owned and non-state-owned enterprises.
source: Achieving carbon neutrality: How does the construction of national high-tech zones affect the green innovation of enterprises? Based on quasi-natural experiments in pilot areas in China

name: Industry Type
define: A categorical variable representing whether the industry is high-tech or non-high-tech.
source: Achieving carbon neutrality: How does the construction of national high-tech zones affect the green innovation of enterprises? Based on quasi-natural experiments in pilot areas in China

name: Spatial Position
define: The physical location of an individual on a campus, potentially influencing collaboration patterns.
source: An exploration of collaborative scientific production at MIT through spatial organization and institutional affiliation

name: Academic Output
define: Includes papers and patents produced by faculty at MIT, serving as a measure of research productivity.
source: An exploration of collaborative scientific production at MIT through spatial organization and institutional affiliation

name: Organizational Structures
define: Involves institutional affiliation and spatial configuration of faculty members at MIT.
source: An exploration of collaborative scientific production at MIT through spatial organization and institutional affiliation

name: Collaboration Patterns
define: Includes the network topology, community structure, and trends in team composition over time.
source: An exploration of collaborative scientific production at MIT through spatial organization and institutional affiliation

name: Proximity
define: The physical distance between researchers, found to have a relationship with the intensity of collaboration.
source: An exploration of collaborative scientific production at MIT through spatial organization and institutional affiliation

name: Cross-Disciplinary Collaboration
define: The extent of collaboration across different disciplines, with different patterns observed for papers and patents.
source: An exploration of collaborative scientific production at MIT through spatial organization and institutional affiliation

name: Institutional Collaboration
define: The level of collaboration within institutional boundaries, showing different trends for papers and patents.
source: An exploration of collaborative scientific production at MIT through spatial organization and institutional affiliation

name: Community Structure
define: The organization of collaborative groups within the network, revealing spatial versus institutional collaboration bias.
source: An exploration of collaborative scientific production at MIT through spatial organization and institutional affiliation

name: Network Topology
define: The structure of the network of authors, showing significant features of collaboration on campus.
source: An exploration of collaborative scientific production at MIT through spatial organization and institutional affiliation

name: Exponential Decay Model
define: A model that describes the relationship between physical proximity and collaboration intensity.
source: An exploration of collaborative scientific production at MIT through spatial organization and institutional affiliation

name: SHII
define: International collaboration level, measured by the share of patents with a foreign resident as a co-inventor in the population of patents with a domestic inventor.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE International Collaboration Patterns and Effecting Factors of Emerging Technologies

name: GPC
define: Gross Domestic Product per capita, representing a country’s advanced degree.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE International Collaboration Patterns and Effecting Factors of Emerging Technologies

name: RDE
define: R&D Expenditure per capita, representing a country’s R&D level.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE International Collaboration Patterns and Effecting Factors of Emerging Technologies

name: FTE
define: Full-time equivalent in R&D, indicating the number of inventors participating in research activities.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE International Collaboration Patterns and Effecting Factors of Emerging Technologies

name: GEO
define: Geographical proximity, calculated as the average space distance between one country and other countries.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE International Collaboration Patterns and Effecting Factors of Emerging Technologies

name: FDI
define: Flows of foreign direct investment, considering outflows as they reflect the international collaboration capability of a country.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE International Collaboration Patterns and Effecting Factors of Emerging Technologies

name: ETV
define: Export of global trade value, proxying for the international trade situation.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE International Collaboration Patterns and Effecting Factors of Emerging Technologies

name: DEG
define: Degree centrality, a network analysis indicator measuring the importance of nodes in the network structure.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE International Collaboration Patterns and Effecting Factors of Emerging Technologies

name: BET
define: Betweenness centrality, a network analysis indicator elaborating the ability of a node to control interactions between pairs of other nodes.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE International Collaboration Patterns and Effecting Factors of Emerging Technologies

name: CLO
define: Closeness centrality, a network analysis indicator describing the degree to which a node is not subject to any other node’s control.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE International Collaboration Patterns and Effecting Factors of Emerging Technologies

name: Component Growth
define: Measured by the count of the number of patents that enter the focal components.
source: The Population Ecology of Technology: An Empirical Study of US Biotechnology Patents from 1976 to 2003

name: Component Density
define: A count of the total number of patents in the focal component prior to the date of measurement of the dependent variable.
source: The Population Ecology of Technology: An Empirical Study of US Biotechnology Patents from 1976 to 2003

name: System Density
define: A count of the total number of patents within the domain of biotechnology prior to the date of measurement of the dependent variable.
source: The Population Ecology of Technology: An Empirical Study of US Biotechnology Patents from 1976 to 2003

name: Component Diversity
define: Measured via the distribution of patents across sub-components in the focal component over the previous twelve months.
source: The Population Ecology of Technology: An Empirical Study of US Biotechnology Patents from 1976 to 2003

name: Component Status
define: Based on the patent citations received by the focal component, used to measure the status of the component.
source: The Population Ecology of Technology: An Empirical Study of US Biotechnology Patents from 1976 to 2003

name: Local Crowding
define: Refers to the overlap of the focal components using the same antecedent inventions within the technological system.
source: The Population Ecology of Technology: An Empirical Study of US Biotechnology Patents from 1976 to 2003

name: Global Crowding
define: Measures the overlap of the focal components with non-focal technological components outside the technological system.
source: The Population Ecology of Technology: An Empirical Study of US Biotechnology Patents from 1976 to 2003

name: Organizational Density
define: A count of the number of organizations active in the technological component in the twelve months prior to the month of observation of the dependent variable.
source: The Population Ecology of Technology: An Empirical Study of US Biotechnology Patents from 1976 to 2003

name: Fintech Development
define: The annual data on the level of fintech development in the city where the company is located, including aspects such as fintech coverage, depth of use, and degree of digitization.
source: Fintech Development and Firm Technological Innovation Efficiency: Empirical Findings in China

name: Firm Technological Innovation Efficiency (FTIE)
define: The ability of a firm to maximize innovation output using given R&D investment, measured by the number of invention patents applied for and granted per unit of R&D investment.
source: Fintech Development and Firm Technological Innovation Efficiency: Empirical Findings in China

name: Risk Transmission
define: The acceleration of financial risk transmission due to the development of fintech, reflected in the stock market through the annual turnover rate of listed company stocks.
source: Fintech Development and Firm Technological Innovation Efficiency: Empirical Findings in China

name: Debt Pressure
define: The debt-to-asset ratio of a firm, indicating the level of debt pressure that can affect the firm's financial stability and innovation efficiency.
source: Fintech Development and Firm Technological Innovation Efficiency: Empirical Findings in China

name: Firm Growth
define: The growth rate of total assets at the end of the year.
source: Fintech Development and Firm Technological Innovation Efficiency: Empirical Findings in China

name: Firm Size
define: The logarithmic value of the firm size.
source: Fintech Development and Firm Technological Innovation Efficiency: Empirical Findings in China

name: Board Independence
define: The ratio of the number of independent directors to the total number of board members.
source: Fintech Development and Firm Technological Innovation Efficiency: Empirical Findings in China

name: Fixed Asset Ratio
define: The ratio of total fixed assets to total assets.
source: Fintech Development and Firm Technological Innovation Efficiency: Empirical Findings in China

name: Capital Concentration Level
define: The level of capital concentration, measured by the purchase and construction of fixed assets, intangible assets, and other long-term assets paid in cash per year-end total assets.
source: Fintech Development and Firm Technological Innovation Efficiency: Empirical Findings in China

name: Asset-Liability Ratio
define: The ratio of year-end liabilities to year-end total assets.
source: Fintech Development and Firm Technological Innovation Efficiency: Empirical Findings in China

name: CDt index
define: A measure that quantifies the extent to which an invention consolidates or destabilizes the subsequent use of the components on which it builds.
source: A Dynamic Network Measure of Technological Change

name: mCDt index
define: A measure that combines the CDt index with an impact weight, characterizing the magnitude of an invention’s consolidation or destabilization of the status quo.
source: A Dynamic Network Measure of Technological Change

name: Federal Research Funding
define: A variable representing the level of financial support from federal sources for academic research.
source: A Dynamic Network Measure of Technological Change

name: Commercial Ties
define: A variable representing the level of engagement of universities with commercial entities.
source: A Dynamic Network Measure of Technological Change

name: Patent Impact
define: A measure of how much a patent is cited by subsequent patents, indicating its influence in the field.
source: A Dynamic Network Measure of Technological Change

name: Government Interest
define: A dummy variable indicating whether a patent declares a government interest, implying research leading to the patent was supported by federal grants.
source: A Dynamic Network Measure of Technological Change

name: Assignee Type
define: A categorical variable representing the type of organization to which a patent is assigned, such as a firm, university, or government entity.
source: A Dynamic Network Measure of Technological Change

name: Team Structure
define: Variables related to the structure of the team that creates a new technology, including the geographic proximity of inventors and the experience of the team.
source: A Dynamic Network Measure of Technological Change

name: Examiner Characteristics
define: Variables related to the experience and workload of the patent examiners, which may influence the importance of a patent.
source: A Dynamic Network Measure of Technological Change

name: Patent Characteristics
define: Variables such as the number of claims, distinctiveness of the invention, and citations of nonpatent literature that may affect a patent's impact and its ability to consolidate or destabilize existing technology.
source: A Dynamic Network Measure of Technological Change

name: Acquisition Likelihood
define: The dependent variable, estimated as the hazard rate of the high-tech venture being acquired.
source: High-Tech Ventures and Industry Incumbents: Knowledge Partnerships, Technological Knowhow, and Acquisition Likelihood

name: Technological Knowhow
define: Captured by patents assigned to a biotech venture, reflecting the firm's technological capabilities and innovative productivity.
source: High-Tech Ventures and Industry Incumbents: Knowledge Partnerships, Technological Knowhow, and Acquisition Likelihood

name: Knowledge Partnerships
define: Computed as the number of alliances a knowledge-intensive biotech venture is engaged in for knowledge exploration or exploitation.
source: High-Tech Ventures and Industry Incumbents: Knowledge Partnerships, Technological Knowhow, and Acquisition Likelihood

name: Explorative Partnerships
define: Operationalized as the number of upstream alliances between the high-tech venture and universities.
source: High-Tech Ventures and Industry Incumbents: Knowledge Partnerships, Technological Knowhow, and Acquisition Likelihood

name: Exploitative Partnerships
define: Counted as the number of downstream alliances between the high-tech venture and pharmaceutical companies.
source: High-Tech Ventures and Industry Incumbents: Knowledge Partnerships, Technological Knowhow, and Acquisition Likelihood

name: Firm Age
define: Control variable, measured as the number of years since the founding of the high-tech venture.
source: High-Tech Ventures and Industry Incumbents: Knowledge Partnerships, Technological Knowhow, and Acquisition Likelihood

name: Firm Size
define: Control variable, measured as the log of the number of employees in the high-tech venture.
source: High-Tech Ventures and Industry Incumbents: Knowledge Partnerships, Technological Knowhow, and Acquisition Likelihood

name: Horizontal Alliance Experience
define: Control variable, operationalized by counting the number of alliances between a focal biotech firm and its competitors.
source: High-Tech Ventures and Industry Incumbents: Knowledge Partnerships, Technological Knowhow, and Acquisition Likelihood

name: Product Technology Specialization
define: Control variable, measured by counting the number of product technologies in a firm's alliances and categorizing the firm in the product type dummy in which it had the maximum number of total alliances.
source: High-Tech Ventures and Industry Incumbents: Knowledge Partnerships, Technological Knowhow, and Acquisition Likelihood

name: Year Dummies
define: Control variable to account for the rate of acquisitions varying during the time period of the study due to industry trends or economic conditions.
source: High-Tech Ventures and Industry Incumbents: Knowledge Partnerships, Technological Knowhow, and Acquisition Likelihood

name: Second Use Drugs
define: Drugs which have had new effects discovered after their original use, different from the original effects, and can be patented as use claims.
source: How Can We Specify the Second Use Drugs from Patent Information?: R&D on the Second Use Drugs May Lead to Further Development of Pharmaceutical Industries

name: Patent Claims
define: Legal claims defining the scope of the invention for which a patent is sought, which can indicate the second use of a drug.
source: How Can We Specify the Second Use Drugs from Patent Information?: R&D on the Second Use Drugs May Lead to Further Development of Pharmaceutical Industries

name: Inventive Step
define: A requirement for patentability that the invention must be non-obvious to a person skilled in the art.
source: How Can We Specify the Second Use Drugs from Patent Information?: R&D on the Second Use Drugs May Lead to Further Development of Pharmaceutical Industries

name: R&D Strategy
define: The approach taken by a company, such as Takeda, to balance the development of new drugs and the second use of existing drugs.
source: How Can We Specify the Second Use Drugs from Patent Information?: R&D on the Second Use Drugs May Lead to Further Development of Pharmaceutical Industries

name: Patent Information
define: Data collected from patents, including IPC codes, claim descriptions, and joint applicants, used to identify second use drugs.
source: How Can We Specify the Second Use Drugs from Patent Information?: R&D on the Second Use Drugs May Lead to Further Development of Pharmaceutical Industries

name: IPC Codes
define: International Patent Classification codes used to categorize patents, with variations indicating potential second use drugs.
source: How Can We Specify the Second Use Drugs from Patent Information?: R&D on the Second Use Drugs May Lead to Further Development of Pharmaceutical Industries

name: Joint Applicants
define: Multiple entities applying for a patent together, which may indicate collaboration in discovering a drug's second use.
source: How Can We Specify the Second Use Drugs from Patent Information?: R&D on the Second Use Drugs May Lead to Further Development of Pharmaceutical Industries

name: Registration Rate
define: The percentage of patent applications that are successfully registered, indicating the novelty and inventive step of the second use drugs.
source: How Can We Specify the Second Use Drugs from Patent Information?: R&D on the Second Use Drugs May Lead to Further Development of Pharmaceutical Industries

name: Cancer
define: A specific field of drug development, used as a case study in the paper to identify second use drugs.
source: How Can We Specify the Second Use Drugs from Patent Information?: R&D on the Second Use Drugs May Lead to Further Development of Pharmaceutical Industries

name: Takeda Pharmaceutical Company Limited
define: A pharmaceutical company used as a case study to analyze R&D strategy and the identification of second use drugs.
source: How Can We Specify the Second Use Drugs from Patent Information?: R&D on the Second Use Drugs May Lead to Further Development of Pharmaceutical Industries

name: External Knowledge Sourcing (EKS)
define: A variable that includes three types of external knowledge sources: scientific partners, institutional partners, and indirect partners.
source: How Does External Knowledge Sourcing Affect Business Performance in Large-Scale Firms? The Mediating Role of Open Technology Strategies

name: Open Technology Strategies (OTS)
define: A variable that encompasses technology acquisition and coupled strategy, focusing on the implementation level of OTS.
source: How Does External Knowledge Sourcing Affect Business Performance in Large-Scale Firms? The Mediating Role of Open Technology Strategies

name: Business Performance (BP)
define: A dependent variable measured by three dimensions: financial performance, new product development performance, and open innovation performance.
source: How Does External Knowledge Sourcing Affect Business Performance in Large-Scale Firms? The Mediating Role of Open Technology Strategies

name: Ownership Type (OWN)
define: A control variable that differentiates between Turkish domestic companies and subsidiaries of multinational corporations.
source: How Does External Knowledge Sourcing Affect Business Performance in Large-Scale Firms? The Mediating Role of Open Technology Strategies

name: Industry Type (IND)
define: A control variable that classifies industries into low and high-technology based on the OECD's classification.
source: How Does External Knowledge Sourcing Affect Business Performance in Large-Scale Firms? The Mediating Role of Open Technology Strategies

name: Company Age (AGE)
define: A control variable that categorizes companies into young, middle-aged, and mature based on the number of years operational.
source: How Does External Knowledge Sourcing Affect Business Performance in Large-Scale Firms? The Mediating Role of Open Technology Strategies

name: Company Size (SIZE)
define: A control variable based on the number of employees in five categories.
source: How Does External Knowledge Sourcing Affect Business Performance in Large-Scale Firms? The Mediating Role of Open Technology Strategies

name: Ownership Structure (STR)
define: A control variable that distinguishes between listed and unlisted firms based on whether their shares are quoted in Borsa Istanbul (BIST).
source: How Does External Knowledge Sourcing Affect Business Performance in Large-Scale Firms? The Mediating Role of Open Technology Strategies

name: Patent Reference
define: The number of prior patents cited by a patent.
source: How to Analyze Technology Life Cycle from the Perspective of Patent Characteristics?

name: Non-Patent Reference
define: The number of non-patent literatures cited by a patent.
source: How to Analyze Technology Life Cycle from the Perspective of Patent Characteristics?

name: Foreign Reference
define: The number of foreign references cited by a patent.
source: How to Analyze Technology Life Cycle from the Perspective of Patent Characteristics?

name: Patent Citation Received
define: The number of citations a patent has received.
source: How to Analyze Technology Life Cycle from the Perspective of Patent Characteristics?

name: IPC (International Patent Classification)
define: The number of IPC classifications a patent is categorized into.
source: How to Analyze Technology Life Cycle from the Perspective of Patent Characteristics?

name: UPC (Universal Patent Classification)
define: The number of UPC classifications a patent is categorized into.
source: How to Analyze Technology Life Cycle from the Perspective of Patent Characteristics?

name: Number of Claims
define: The number of claims a patent contains.
source: How to Analyze Technology Life Cycle from the Perspective of Patent Characteristics?

name: Technology Life Cycle Stage
define: The stage of the technology life cycle, categorized as Introduction, Growth, Maturity, and Decline.
source: How to Analyze Technology Life Cycle from the Perspective of Patent Characteristics?

name: Assignee
define: An entity to whom a patent is assigned.
source: How to Analyze Technology Life Cycle from the Perspective of Patent Characteristics?

name: Inventor
define: An individual listed on a patent as the creator of the invention.
source: How to Analyze Technology Life Cycle from the Perspective of Patent Characteristics?

name: Private Equity
define: A variable representing the involvement of private equity in enterprises.
source: Private Equity and the Competitiveness of Enterprises (Based on Polish Cases)

name: Competitiveness of Enterprises
define: A variable measuring the competitive strength of enterprises.
source: Private Equity and the Competitiveness of Enterprises (Based on Polish Cases)

name: Polish Cases
define: A categorical variable indicating the specific cases studied in Poland.
source: Private Equity and the Competitiveness of Enterprises (Based on Polish Cases)

name: Innovation Efficiency (UIE)
define: A measure of the input-output ratio of innovative behavior, calculated using the DEA method.
source: Is Improvement of Innovation Efficiency Conducive to Haze Governance? Empirical Evidence from 283 Chinese Cities

name: Haze Pollution
