define: Measured by the annual average concentration of PM2.5.
source: Is Improvement of Innovation Efficiency Conducive to Haze Governance? Empirical Evidence from 283 Chinese Cities

name: Economic Development Level
define: Represented by the average night light brightness, used as a threshold variable.
source: Is Improvement of Innovation Efficiency Conducive to Haze Governance? Empirical Evidence from 283 Chinese Cities

name: Industrial Structure
define: Measured by the output value of the secondary industry as a proportion of GDP.
source: Is Improvement of Innovation Efficiency Conducive to Haze Governance? Empirical Evidence from 283 Chinese Cities

name: Technological Progress
define: Measured by the number of patent licenses per 100 scientific research practitioners.
source: Is Improvement of Innovation Efficiency Conducive to Haze Governance? Empirical Evidence from 283 Chinese Cities

name: Energy Conservation
define: Measured by the total annual liquefied petroleum gas supply.
source: Is Improvement of Innovation Efficiency Conducive to Haze Governance? Empirical Evidence from 283 Chinese Cities

name: Population Agglomeration
define: Measured by the number of people per unit area.
source: Is Improvement of Innovation Efficiency Conducive to Haze Governance? Empirical Evidence from 283 Chinese Cities

name: Fiscal Expenditure
define: Measured by the number of local government budgetary fiscal expenditures.
source: Is Improvement of Innovation Efficiency Conducive to Haze Governance? Empirical Evidence from 283 Chinese Cities

name: Transportation
define: Measured by the total annual passenger transport of public cars.
source: Is Improvement of Innovation Efficiency Conducive to Haze Governance? Empirical Evidence from 283 Chinese Cities

name: Trade Openness
define: Measured by the amount of foreign direct investment actually utilized.
source: Is Improvement of Innovation Efficiency Conducive to Haze Governance? Empirical Evidence from 283 Chinese Cities

name: Divisive Faultlines
define: A measure of the internal differentiation tendency of a network due to differences in the degree of shared experience among members during interactive innovations.
source: Divisive Faultlines and Knowledge Search in Technological Innovation Network: An Empirical Study of Global Biopharmaceutical Firms

name: Knowledge Search Depth
define: The degree of focus or specialization of knowledge, measured by the average number of times companies reused knowledge in patent applications.
source: Divisive Faultlines and Knowledge Search in Technological Innovation Network: An Empirical Study of Global Biopharmaceutical Firms

name: Knowledge Search Breadth
define: The range or diversification of knowledge, measured by the number of IPC categories contained in the patents filed by the firm.
source: Divisive Faultlines and Knowledge Search in Technological Innovation Network: An Empirical Study of Global Biopharmaceutical Firms

name: Structural Holes
define: The voids between unconnected actors in a network, with firms occupying structural holes having information and control advantages.
source: Divisive Faultlines and Knowledge Search in Technological Innovation Network: An Empirical Study of Global Biopharmaceutical Firms

name: Network Size
define: The number of members directly related to the firm in the technological innovation network.
source: Divisive Faultlines and Knowledge Search in Technological Innovation Network: An Empirical Study of Global Biopharmaceutical Firms

name: Network Density
define: The ratio of the actual relationship number to all possible relationship numbers in the network.
source: Divisive Faultlines and Knowledge Search in Technological Innovation Network: An Empirical Study of Global Biopharmaceutical Firms

name: Betweenness Centrality
define: The importance of a firm's position in the network, indicating its control over surrounding firms.
source: Divisive Faultlines and Knowledge Search in Technological Innovation Network: An Empirical Study of Global Biopharmaceutical Firms

name: Knowledge Base
define: The richness of a firm's knowledge elements, measured by the types of patent applications by the firm.
source: Divisive Faultlines and Knowledge Search in Technological Innovation Network: An Empirical Study of Global Biopharmaceutical Firms

name: Technological R&D Capability
define: The ability of a firm to create new knowledge, measured by the total amount of patents accumulated by the firm.
source: Divisive Faultlines and Knowledge Search in Technological Innovation Network: An Empirical Study of Global Biopharmaceutical Firms

name: Digital Financial Inclusion (Dindex)
define: A measure of the development degree of digital financial inclusion based on the China Digital Financial Inclusion Index.
source: Can Digital Financial Inclusion Promote Green Innovation in Heavily Polluting Companies?

name: Green Innovation (Patent)
define: A measure of green innovation of enterprises, calculated by adding 1 to the number of green patent applications in the current year.
source: Can Digital Financial Inclusion Promote Green Innovation in Heavily Polluting Companies?

name: Financing Constraints (Sa)
define: A measure of the financing constraints faced by firms, calculated using the Sa index based on the scale and age of the enterprise.
source: Can Digital Financial Inclusion Promote Green Innovation in Heavily Polluting Companies?

name: Financial Mismatch (Fm)
define: A measure of the degree of deviation from the industry average cost of capital, indicating the misallocation of financial resources.
source: Can Digital Financial Inclusion Promote Green Innovation in Heavily Polluting Companies?

name: Enterprise Scale (Size)
define: The natural logarithm of the total assets of the enterprise.
source: Can Digital Financial Inclusion Promote Green Innovation in Heavily Polluting Companies?

name: Asset-Liability Ratio (Lev)
define: The ratio of total liabilities to total assets.
source: Can Digital Financial Inclusion Promote Green Innovation in Heavily Polluting Companies?

name: Return on Assets (Roa)
define: The ratio of net profit to total assets.
source: Can Digital Financial Inclusion Promote Green Innovation in Heavily Polluting Companies?

name: Fixed Asset Ratio (Ppe)
define: The ratio of net fixed assets to total assets.
source: Can Digital Financial Inclusion Promote Green Innovation in Heavily Polluting Companies?

name: Dual
define: A binary variable indicating whether the chairman and the general manager are the same person.
source: Can Digital Financial Inclusion Promote Green Innovation in Heavily Polluting Companies?

name: Management Shareholding (Msh)
define: The ratio of the number of shares held by management to the total number of shares.
source: Can Digital Financial Inclusion Promote Green Innovation in Heavily Polluting Companies?

name: Shareholding Concentration Ratio (Top)
define: The sum of the shareholding ratios of the top ten shareholders of the enterprise.
source: Can Digital Financial Inclusion Promote Green Innovation in Heavily Polluting Companies?

name: Shareholding Balance Ratio (Balance)
define: The ratio of the sum of the shareholding ratios of the second-largest shareholder to the tenth largest shareholder and the shareholding ratio of the first largest shareholder.
source: Can Digital Financial Inclusion Promote Green Innovation in Heavily Polluting Companies?

name: Green Technology Transfer (GTT)
define: The number of green technology patents transferred, indicating the level of green technology transfer.
source: Green Technology Transfer, Environmental Regulation, and Regional Green Development Chasm: Based on the Empirical Evidence from Yangtze River Delta

name: Environmental Regulation (ER)
define: A composite index reflecting the intensity of environmental regulations, including various indicators such as industrial sulfur dioxide emissions per unit of industrial added value.
source: Green Technology Transfer, Environmental Regulation, and Regional Green Development Chasm: Based on the Empirical Evidence from Yangtze River Delta

name: Green Development Gap Index (GDG)
define: The economic scale created by unit carbon emissions, used to measure the level of green economic development.
source: Green Technology Transfer, Environmental Regulation, and Regional Green Development Chasm: Based on the Empirical Evidence from Yangtze River Delta

name: GDP per capita (PGDP)
define: A control variable representing the level of economic development.
source: Green Technology Transfer, Environmental Regulation, and Regional Green Development Chasm: Based on the Empirical Evidence from Yangtze River Delta

name: Technology Absorptive Capacity (TAC)
define: A control variable characterized by the stock of green technology patents, indicating the ability to identify, absorb, and utilize knowledge.
source: Green Technology Transfer, Environmental Regulation, and Regional Green Development Chasm: Based on the Empirical Evidence from Yangtze River Delta

name: Industrial Structure (IS)
define: A control variable representing the proportion of the secondary industry, which is considered the main source of carbon emissions.
source: Green Technology Transfer, Environmental Regulation, and Regional Green Development Chasm: Based on the Empirical Evidence from Yangtze River Delta

name: Government Science and Technology Investment (GSTI)
define: A control variable reflecting the proportion of government investment in science and technology to fiscal expenditure, indicating government support for technological innovation.
source: Green Technology Transfer, Environmental Regulation, and Regional Green Development Chasm: Based on the Empirical Evidence from Yangtze River Delta

name: Energy Consumption (EC)
define: A control variable representing total electricity consumption, used as a measure of energy consumption and its impact on green development.
source: Green Technology Transfer, Environmental Regulation, and Regional Green Development Chasm: Based on the Empirical Evidence from Yangtze River Delta

name: Inter-regional Networks
define: The connections between different regions that facilitate knowledge exchange.
source: An Empirical Agent-Based Model for Regional Knowledge Creation in Europe

name: Agglomeration Factors
define: The factors that contribute to the clustering of knowledge creation activities in certain regions.
source: An Empirical Agent-Based Model for Regional Knowledge Creation in Europe

name: Region-Internal Characteristics
define: The specific features within a region that influence knowledge creation.
source: An Empirical Agent-Based Model for Regional Knowledge Creation in Europe

name: Region-External R&D Collaboration Linkages
define: The R&D collaborations that a region engages in with other regions.
source: An Empirical Agent-Based Model for Regional Knowledge Creation in Europe

name: Knowledge Spillovers
define: The unintended sharing of knowledge that can influence knowledge creation.
source: An Empirical Agent-Based Model for Regional Knowledge Creation in Europe

name: Spatial Proximity
define: The geographical closeness that can affect the ease of knowledge exchange.
source: An Empirical Agent-Based Model for Regional Knowledge Creation in Europe

name: Non-spatial Forms of Proximity
define: Forms of proximity other than geographical, such as institutional or cultural, that can influence knowledge creation.
source: An Empirical Agent-Based Model for Regional Knowledge Creation in Europe

name: Research Strategy
define: The approach taken by agents in the model for knowledge creation, either exploitative or explorative.
source: An Empirical Agent-Based Model for Regional Knowledge Creation in Europe

name: Collaboration Memory
define: The record of past collaboration successes or failures that influence future collaboration decisions.
source: An Empirical Agent-Based Model for Regional Knowledge Creation in Europe

name: Network Position
define: The position of an agent within the network of collaborations, indicating external networking capability.
source: An Empirical Agent-Based Model for Regional Knowledge Creation in Europe

name: Peer M&A
define: The number of mergers and acquisitions performed by peer firms in a given firm year.
source: Impacts of Peers’ Mergers and Acquisitions on Firm Innovation

name: R&D Intensity
define: A firm’s research and development expenditure divided by its annual sales.
source: Impacts of Peers’ Mergers and Acquisitions on Firm Innovation

name: Market Competition
define: Measured using one minus the Herfindahl–Hirschman Index of core business revenue.
source: Impacts of Peers’ Mergers and Acquisitions on Firm Innovation

name: Analyst Coverage
define: The average number of analysts who have conducted an analysis of the focal firm each year.
source: Impacts of Peers’ Mergers and Acquisitions on Firm Innovation

name: CEO Power
define: A dummy variable that equals 1 if the CEO also serves as the board chairperson, and 0 otherwise.
source: Impacts of Peers’ Mergers and Acquisitions on Firm Innovation

name: CEO Age
define: The age of the CEO.
source: Impacts of Peers’ Mergers and Acquisitions on Firm Innovation

name: Firm Size
define: The natural logarithm of the total assets of each firm.
source: Impacts of Peers’ Mergers and Acquisitions on Firm Innovation

name: Firm Performance
define: Measured by returns on assets.
source: Impacts of Peers’ Mergers and Acquisitions on Firm Innovation

name: Financial Leverage
define: Measured by long-term debt divided by total assets.
source: Impacts of Peers’ Mergers and Acquisitions on Firm Innovation

name: Peer Firm Size
define: The size of peer firms.
source: Impacts of Peers’ Mergers and Acquisitions on Firm Innovation

name: Peer Financial Leverage
define: The financial leverage of peer firms.
source: Impacts of Peers’ Mergers and Acquisitions on Firm Innovation

name: ICT R&D Productivity
define: A measure of the outcome of a patent according to R&D expenditure, indicating the efficiency of R&D activities in the ICT industry.
source: Impact Analysis of Economic Contributors on Knowledge Creation Activity by Using the Symmetric Decomposition Method

name: ICT R&D Intensity
define: A measure of R&D expenditure on the value-added sub-sector i in the ICT industry, representing the investment in R&D.
source: Impact Analysis of Economic Contributors on Knowledge Creation Activity by Using the Symmetric Decomposition Method

name: Industrial Structure
define: A measure of the proportion of value added for sub-sector i in the whole ICT industry, indicating the structural effect within the ICT industry.
source: Impact Analysis of Economic Contributors on Knowledge Creation Activity by Using the Symmetric Decomposition Method

name: Industry Scale
define: A measure of the entire ICT industry’s value-added effect on the overall manufacturing industry, representing the scale effect.
source: Impact Analysis of Economic Contributors on Knowledge Creation Activity by Using the Symmetric Decomposition Method

name: Manufacturing Activity
define: A measure of the overall economic performance, specifically the volume effect of manufacturing during which R&D is implemented.
source: Impact Analysis of Economic Contributors on Knowledge Creation Activity by Using the Symmetric Decomposition Method

name: ICT Patent Applications
define: The total number of patent applications in the ICT industry, serving as a proxy for knowledge creation activity.
source: Impact Analysis of Economic Contributors on Knowledge Creation Activity by Using the Symmetric Decomposition Method

name: Patent Protection System
define: An index indicating the strength of the patent protection system, which can affect patenting activities and innovation.
source: Impact Analysis of Economic Contributors on Knowledge Creation Activity by Using the Symmetric Decomposition Method

name: SAO Semantic Structure
define: A method of extracting and representing the semantic relationships between concepts in a patent document.
source: Improved Technology Similarity Measurement in the Medical Field based on Subject-Action-Object Semantic Structure: A Case Study of Alzheimer’s Disease

name: Technology Feature Weights (TFW)
define: A measure representing the importance of technology information in a patent, calculated using the TF-IDF method.
source: Improved Technology Similarity Measurement in the Medical Field based on Subject-Action-Object Semantic Structure: A Case Study of Alzheimer’s Disease

name: Patent Vector
define: A vector constructed for each patentee based on the SAO semantic structure and weight information.
source: Improved Technology Similarity Measurement in the Medical Field based on Subject-Action-Object Semantic Structure: A Case Study of Alzheimer’s Disease

name: Technology Similarity
define: A measure of the degree of similarity between the technologies of different patentees, calculated using the cosine similarity method.
source: Improved Technology Similarity Measurement in the Medical Field based on Subject-Action-Object Semantic Structure: A Case Study of Alzheimer’s Disease

name: International Patent Classification (IPC)
define: A traditional method of categorizing patents based on a hierarchical system of codes.
source: Improved Technology Similarity Measurement in the Medical Field based on Subject-Action-Object Semantic Structure: A Case Study of Alzheimer’s Disease

name: Keywords
define: Traditional text features of patent datasets used to measure technology similarity.
source: Improved Technology Similarity Measurement in the Medical Field based on Subject-Action-Object Semantic Structure: A Case Study of Alzheimer’s Disease

name: Alzheimer’s Disease
define: The specific medical field and case study used to illustrate the methodology.
source: Improved Technology Similarity Measurement in the Medical Field based on Subject-Action-Object Semantic Structure: A Case Study of Alzheimer’s Disease

name: Metathesaurus of UMLS
define: A resource used to evaluate the similarity between the SAO semantic structures.
source: Improved Technology Similarity Measurement in the Medical Field based on Subject-Action-Object Semantic Structure: A Case Study of Alzheimer’s Disease

name: Unified Medical Language System (UMLS)
define: A database system used for biomedical research, providing semantic networks and other knowledge sources.
source: Improved Technology Similarity Measurement in the Medical Field based on Subject-Action-Object Semantic Structure: A Case Study of Alzheimer’s Disease

name: Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF)
define: A weighting technique used to calculate the feature weights of the SAO semantic structure.
source: Improved Technology Similarity Measurement in the Medical Field based on Subject-Action-Object Semantic Structure: A Case Study of Alzheimer’s Disease

name: Demand-pull Forces
define: Market-wide and targeted interventions that create a market for innovations.
source: Induced innovation in energy technologies and systems: a review of evidence and potential implications for CO2 mitigation

name: Patents
define: Indicators of innovation, primarily used as a measure of innovation activity.
source: Induced innovation in energy technologies and systems: a review of evidence and potential implications for CO2 mitigation

name: Technology Costs
define: Costs associated with energy technologies, with a focus on cost reduction.
source: Induced innovation in energy technologies and systems: a review of evidence and potential implications for CO2 mitigation

name: Cumulative Investment
define: The total investment made in a technology over time, related to cost reduction through experience curves.
source: Induced innovation in energy technologies and systems: a review of evidence and potential implications for CO2 mitigation

name: Policy Diversity
define: The variety of policies implemented to encourage innovation.
source: Induced innovation in energy technologies and systems: a review of evidence and potential implications for CO2 mitigation

name: Econometric Studies
define: Studies that use statistical methods to analyze the relationship between variables.
source: Induced innovation in energy technologies and systems: a review of evidence and potential implications for CO2 mitigation

name: Qualitative and Mixed-methods Studies
define: Studies that use non-numerical and combination of methods to understand innovation processes.
source: Induced innovation in energy technologies and systems: a review of evidence and potential implications for CO2 mitigation

name: Energy Prices
define: Market-wide drivers that influence innovation activities.
source: Induced innovation in energy technologies and systems: a review of evidence and potential implications for CO2 mitigation

name: Carbon Prices
define: Market-wide drivers related to carbon emissions, influencing innovation activities.
source: Induced innovation in energy technologies and systems: a review of evidence and potential implications for CO2 mitigation

name: Targeted Interventions
define: Specific policies and instruments aimed at promoting innovation in certain areas.
source: Induced innovation in energy technologies and systems: a review of evidence and potential implications for CO2 mitigation

name: Technology Diffusion (TD)
define: A variable representing the strength of 3D printing technology diffusion across industries, measured through patent citation data.
source: Influencing Factors Analysis of 3D Printing Technology Diffusion Across Industries

name: R&D Investment (RI)
define: A variable indicating the amount of investment in research and development within the industry.
source: Influencing Factors Analysis of 3D Printing Technology Diffusion Across Industries

name: R&D Organization (RO)
define: A variable representing the number of R&D organizations involved in the industry.
source: Influencing Factors Analysis of 3D Printing Technology Diffusion Across Industries

name: R&D Staff (RS)
define: A variable indicating the number of R&D staff within the industry.
source: Influencing Factors Analysis of 3D Printing Technology Diffusion Across Industries

name: Market Scale (MS)
define: A variable representing the size of the market relevant to the industry.
source: Influencing Factors Analysis of 3D Printing Technology Diffusion Across Industries

name: Engagement in a lead firm’s GVC
define: A binary variable indicating whether a supplier is part of a lead firm's Global Value Chain (GVC).
source: Interfirm Transformative Capacity Within Global Value Chains

name: Supplier Types
define: A categorical variable differentiating suppliers into modular suppliers and integrator suppliers.
source: Interfirm Transformative Capacity Within Global Value Chains

name: Structural Holes
define: A measure of the extent to which a firm's network is directly or indirectly concentrated in a single contact, calculated using the 'constraint' formula.
source: Interfirm Transformative Capacity Within Global Value Chains

name: Network Centrality
define: A measure of connectedness in the network, calculated using closeness centrality.
source: Interfirm Transformative Capacity Within Global Value Chains

name: Innovation Impact
define: The number of citations from subsequent patents of any firm that cited the focal firm's patents in a given year.
source: Interfirm Transformative Capacity Within Global Value Chains

name: R&D
define: The log of a firm's R&D expenditure.
source: Interfirm Transformative Capacity Within Global Value Chains

name: Cash
define: The log of a firm's cash amount.
source: Interfirm Transformative Capacity Within Global Value Chains

name: Fortune 500
define: A binary variable indicating whether the firm is listed in the Fortune Global 500.
source: Interfirm Transformative Capacity Within Global Value Chains

name: Direct Knowledge Flows (DIR)
define: The count of patent coinvention events between a firm and a research institute in every observed year.
source: Interorganizational Knowledge Flows in Academia–Industry Collaboration: The Economic Impacts of Science-Based Firm Innovation

name: Indirect Knowledge Flows (IND)
define: The count of other firms with which a focal firm has common research institute partner(s) but without direct collaboration in the observed and previous years.
source: Interorganizational Knowledge Flows in Academia–Industry Collaboration: The Economic Impacts of Science-Based Firm Innovation

name: Technological Originality
define: The technological class dispersion in the backward citations of a patent, indicating the degree of knowledge recombination leading to the patent.
source: Interorganizational Knowledge Flows in Academia–Industry Collaboration: The Economic Impacts of Science-Based Firm Innovation

name: Technological Generality
define: The technological class dispersion of patent forward citations, indicating the degree of technological application and the patent’s foundational status.
source: Interorganizational Knowledge Flows in Academia–Industry Collaboration: The Economic Impacts of Science-Based Firm Innovation

name: Economic Impact of Firm Innovation
define: The present value of a patent’s monopoly rent empirically estimated from the firm stock price movement caused by the issuance announcement of each given patent.
source: Interorganizational Knowledge Flows in Academia–Industry Collaboration: The Economic Impacts of Science-Based Firm Innovation

name: Multidisciplinarity (MDR)
define: A continuous variable measured with the Rao-Stirling diversity index of the disciplines represented among a paper’s author addresses in the WoS.
source: Impact of multidisciplinary research on innovation

name: Cited in Patent
define: A binary indicator, computed at the paper level, with a value of 1 if the publication is cited in the patent literature and 0 otherwise.
source: Impact of multidisciplinary research on innovation

name: Number of Authors
define: A count variable representing the number of contributing authors on a paper.
source: Impact of multidisciplinary research on innovation

name: Number of Countries
define: A count variable representing the number of contributing countries on a paper.
source: Impact of multidisciplinary research on innovation

name: Subfield
define: A categorical variable representing the scientific subfield of an article.
source: Impact of multidisciplinary research on innovation

name: Scholarly Publications
define: The number of research publications related to the ubiquitin system.
source: The discovery of 'the ubiquitin-mediated proteolytic system': An example of revolutionary science? (RIP)

name: Patent Publications
define: The number of patent publications related to ubiquitin.
source: The discovery of 'the ubiquitin-mediated proteolytic system': An example of revolutionary science? (RIP)

name: Multidisciplinarity
define: The number of different Thomson Reuters' Journal Categories related to the ubiquitin system.
source: The discovery of 'the ubiquitin-mediated proteolytic system': An example of revolutionary science? (RIP)

name: Breakthrough Concept
define: A concept that signifies a sudden change in the general pattern of knowledge creation processes.
source: The discovery of 'the ubiquitin-mediated proteolytic system': An example of revolutionary science? (RIP)

name: Paradigm Shift
define: A fundamental change in approach or underlying assumptions in a scientific field.
source: The discovery of 'the ubiquitin-mediated proteolytic system': An example of revolutionary science? (RIP)

name: Research and Development (R&D) Dynamics
define: The evolution of scientific discoveries and their transformation into technological applications.
source: The discovery of 'the ubiquitin-mediated proteolytic system': An example of revolutionary science? (RIP)

name: Ubiquitin System
define: A process crucial in the functioning of living cells, specifically Eukaryotic cells.
source: The discovery of 'the ubiquitin-mediated proteolytic system': An example of revolutionary science? (RIP)

name: Nobel Prize Committee
define: An authoritative body that provides judgment and contextualization of the importance of a discovery.
source: The discovery of 'the ubiquitin-mediated proteolytic system': An example of revolutionary science? (RIP)

name: Early Indicator of Breakthroughs
define: A bibliometric indicator that can identify a scientific breakthrough at an early stage.
source: The discovery of 'the ubiquitin-mediated proteolytic system': An example of revolutionary science? (RIP)

name: Type of Discovery
define: Classification of discoveries into 'charge', 'challenge', and 'chance' based on Koshland's theory.
source: The discovery of 'the ubiquitin-mediated proteolytic system': An example of revolutionary science? (RIP)

name: Imitation Strategy
define: A measure of how a firm follows the practices of industry leaders, indicated by patent citation information.
source: Is an Imitation Strategy an Enabler or a Hindrance for Exploitative or Exploratory Innovation?—The Moderating Effect of Embeddedness in Knowledge Networks

name: Exploitative Innovation
define: Innovations that deepen a firm's existing knowledge base, measured by the number of four-digit IPC classes entered by a firm in which it had previously patented.
source: Is an Imitation Strategy an Enabler or a Hindrance for Exploitative or Exploratory Innovation?—The Moderating Effect of Embeddedness in Knowledge Networks

name: Exploratory Innovation
define: Innovations that create new knowledge beyond a firm's existing knowledge base, measured by the number of four-digit IPC classes entered by a firm in which it had not previously patented.
source: Is an Imitation Strategy an Enabler or a Hindrance for Exploitative or Exploratory Innovation?—The Moderating Effect of Embeddedness in Knowledge Networks

name: Knowledge Network Centrality
define: A measure of a firm's position in a knowledge network, indicating the degree to which a firm's knowledge is linked to other firms.
source: Is an Imitation Strategy an Enabler or a Hindrance for Exploitative or Exploratory Innovation?—The Moderating Effect of Embeddedness in Knowledge Networks

name: Knowledge Network Structural Holes
define: A measure of the lack of connection between different parts of a firm's knowledge network, indicating the potential for novel combinations of knowledge.
source: Is an Imitation Strategy an Enabler or a Hindrance for Exploitative or Exploratory Innovation?—The Moderating Effect of Embeddedness in Knowledge Networks

name: Firm Size
define: Measured as the natural logarithm of the total number of employees.
source: Is an Imitation Strategy an Enabler or a Hindrance for Exploitative or Exploratory Innovation?—The Moderating Effect of Embeddedness in Knowledge Networks

name: R&D Intensity
define: The ratio of R&D costs divided by revenues.
source: Is an Imitation Strategy an Enabler or a Hindrance for Exploitative or Exploratory Innovation?—The Moderating Effect of Embeddedness in Knowledge Networks

name: Firm Performance
define: Measured by the return on assets, the ratio of net income divided by total assets.
source: Is an Imitation Strategy an Enabler or a Hindrance for Exploitative or Exploratory Innovation?—The Moderating Effect of Embeddedness in Knowledge Networks

name: Ownership
define: The share of state-owned equity in a firm.
source: Is an Imitation Strategy an Enabler or a Hindrance for Exploitative or Exploratory Innovation?—The Moderating Effect of Embeddedness in Knowledge Networks

name: Proportion of Independent Directors
define: Reflecting the company governance structure.
source: Is an Imitation Strategy an Enabler or a Hindrance for Exploitative or Exploratory Innovation?—The Moderating Effect of Embeddedness in Knowledge Networks

name: Pre-shock Strategic Emphasis on Innovation
define: A composite measure of a firm's focus on innovation before a systemic shock, including R&D intensity, patent count, patent quality, new product introductions, and top management's focus on innovation.
source: Building a resilient organization through a pre-shock strategic emphasis on innovation

name: Organizational Resilience
define: The ability of an organization to endure and recover from a systemic shock, measured by stability and flexibility.
source: Building a resilient organization through a pre-shock strategic emphasis on innovation

name: Stability
define: A component of organizational resilience, reflecting the severity of loss in stock price during a shock.
source: Building a resilient organization through a pre-shock strategic emphasis on innovation

name: Flexibility
define: A component of organizational resilience, reflecting the time taken for a firm's stock price to recover to pre-shock levels.
source: Building a resilient organization through a pre-shock strategic emphasis on innovation

name: R&D Intensity
define: A measure of a firm's investment in research and development activities.
source: Building a resilient organization through a pre-shock strategic emphasis on innovation

name: Patent Count
define: A measure of the number of patents a firm has accumulated.
source: Building a resilient organization through a pre-shock strategic emphasis on innovation

name: Patent Quality
define: A measure of the quality of a firm's patents, based on forward citations.
source: Building a resilient organization through a pre-shock strategic emphasis on innovation

name: New Product Introductions
define: A measure of the number of new products a firm has introduced to the market.
source: Building a resilient organization through a pre-shock strategic emphasis on innovation

name: Top Management's Focus on Innovation
define: A measure of the extent to which top management prioritizes innovation in their strategies and decisions.
source: Building a resilient organization through a pre-shock strategic emphasis on innovation

name: Pre-shock Firm Profitability
define: A measure of a firm's profitability before the onset of a systemic shock, used as a moderating variable.
source: Building a resilient organization through a pre-shock strategic emphasis on innovation

name: Bibliometric Data
define: Data used for the quantitative analysis of output from scientific research.
source: Japanese government project on innovation database platform - As an infrastructure for improving quality of science, technology and innovation policy

name: R&D and Research Funding Data
define: Data on research and development activities and their funding.
source: Japanese government project on innovation database platform - As an infrastructure for improving quality of science, technology and innovation policy

name: Patent Data
define: Data on patents, including the original applicant name and the total number of patents applied for by a firm.
source: Japanese government project on innovation database platform - As an infrastructure for improving quality of science, technology and innovation policy

name: Corporate Data
define: Data on companies, including their innovation activities, investments in R&D, and intangible assets.
source: Japanese government project on innovation database platform - As an infrastructure for improving quality of science, technology and innovation policy

name: Data Cleansing
define: The process of organizing and standardizing data, such as patent data, to make it usable for analysis.
source: Japanese government project on innovation database platform - As an infrastructure for improving quality of science, technology and innovation policy

name: Name Harmonization
define: The process of standardizing names in databases to ensure consistency and accurate linkage between data sets.
source: Japanese government project on innovation database platform - As an infrastructure for improving quality of science, technology and innovation policy

name: Vertical Linkage
define: The connection between different levels of data, such as macro, mezzo, and micro.
source: Japanese government project on innovation database platform - As an infrastructure for improving quality of science, technology and innovation policy

name: Horizontal Linkage
define: The connection between different types of data, such as bibliometric and non-bibliometric data.
source: Japanese government project on innovation database platform - As an infrastructure for improving quality of science, technology and innovation policy

name: Policy Research
define: The use of the database for analyzing and assessing the impact of policies on innovation and R&D.
source: Japanese government project on innovation database platform - As an infrastructure for improving quality of science, technology and innovation policy

name: Innovation Activities
define: The various activities related to innovation, including industry-university cooperation and government policy.
source: Japanese government project on innovation database platform - As an infrastructure for improving quality of science, technology and innovation policy

name: Intellectual Property Right (IPR) Activities
define: Activities related to the protection and management of intellectual property rights.
source: Japanese government project on innovation database platform - As an infrastructure for improving quality of science, technology and innovation policy

name: Primary Technologies
define: Technologies predicted to be promising, extracted from the business reports of the prime contractor.
source: Recommending blue ocean technologies for subcontractors: A framework based on business reports of prime contractors and patents

name: Sub-technologies
define: Technologies selected through a patent-based search using keywords and International Patent Classification codes of the primary technologies.
source: Recommending blue ocean technologies for subcontractors: A framework based on business reports of prime contractors and patents

name: Blue Ocean Technologies
define: Technologies proposed by optimizing the weighted mean of market value, degree of competition, and subcontractors’ potential technological capabilities.
source: Recommending blue ocean technologies for subcontractors: A framework based on business reports of prime contractors and patents

name: Market Value
define: Calculated using the patent quality index (PQI), which shows the comprehensive economic and technological value of patents.
source: Recommending blue ocean technologies for subcontractors: A framework based on business reports of prime contractors and patents

name: Degree of Competition
define: Calculated as the average of the normalized components, including the number of applied patents, number of companies that applied those patents, and the ratio of the number of the sub-technology’s patents to the number of patents with the same classification code.
source: Recommending blue ocean technologies for subcontractors: A framework based on business reports of prime contractors and patents

name: Subcontractors’ Potential Technological Capabilities
define: Calculated using a cosine similarity between the subcontractor’s patent document abstracts and those of individual sub-technology, summarized using the term frequency-inverse document frequency (TF-IDF) technique.
source: Recommending blue ocean technologies for subcontractors: A framework based on business reports of prime contractors and patents

name: Weighted Mean
define: The weighted sum of the market value, degree of competition, and subcontractors’ potential technological capabilities, used to optimize the selection of blue ocean technologies.
source: Recommending blue ocean technologies for subcontractors: A framework based on business reports of prime contractors and patents

name: Prime Contractors' Business Reports
define: Reports containing future plans and promising technologies of prime contractors.
source: Recommending blue ocean technologies for subcontractors: A framework based on business reports of prime contractors and patents

name: Patent Data
define: Data comprising a collection of the technical capabilities and expertise in new technology, used for technology forecasting and innovation performance measurement.
source: Recommending blue ocean technologies for subcontractors: A framework based on business reports of prime contractors and patents

name: Subcontractors' Technological Followership
define: The ability of subcontractors to keep pace with new technology demands and its trend in line with the interests of prime contractors.
source: Recommending blue ocean technologies for subcontractors: A framework based on business reports of prime contractors and patents

name: Off-patent Registered Prescription Medicines
define: Medications that are no longer patent protected and have lost market exclusivity due to the availability of generic versions.
source: The extent to which off-patent registered prescription medicines are used for off-label indications in Australia: A scoping review

name: Off-label Indications
define: The use of prescription medicines beyond the limits of their registration or for purposes other than those approved by the regulatory authority.
source: The extent to which off-patent registered prescription medicines are used for off-label indications in Australia: A scoping review

name: Australian Clinical Settings
define: Public hospitals, community and primary healthcare settings in Australia where off-patent registered prescription medicines are used.
source: The extent to which off-patent registered prescription medicines are used for off-label indications in Australia: A scoping review

name: State-wide Medicine Formularies
define: Official lists of medicines approved for use in specific Australian states, including approved off-label indications.
source: The extent to which off-patent registered prescription medicines are used for off-label indications in Australia: A scoping review

name: Equity of Access
define: The fairness of access to medicines, highlighting disparities that may exist in the availability of off-patent registered prescription medicines for off-label indications across Australia.
source: The extent to which off-patent registered prescription medicines are used for off-label indications in Australia: A scoping review

name: PBS Subsidisation
define: Subsidies provided by the Australian Government via the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) for medicines that are included in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG).
source: The extent to which off-patent registered prescription medicines are used for off-label indications in Australia: A scoping review

name: Cost Burden on Patients
define: The financial burden on patients who must pay the full price for off-label medicines not covered by PBS subsidisation or state-wide formularies.
source: The extent to which off-patent registered prescription medicines are used for off-label indications in Australia: A scoping review

name: Regulatory Reform
define: Changes in the regulatory policies and practices that may be required to improve the registration and use of off-patent registered prescription medicines for off-label indications.
source: The extent to which off-patent registered prescription medicines are used for off-label indications in Australia: A scoping review

name: Empirical Data
define: Data derived from practical experience or observation, in this case, from the Queensland and South Australian state-wide medicine formularies.
source: The extent to which off-patent registered prescription medicines are used for off-label indications in Australia: A scoping review

name: Published Literature
define: Academic and grey literature that has been published on the topic of off-patent registered prescription medicines used for off-label indications in Australia.
source: The extent to which off-patent registered prescription medicines are used for off-label indications in Australia: A scoping review

name: Filing Ratio
define: The ratio of the number of patent applications divided by the total number of new invention disclosures in a given fiscal year.
source: Exploring the role of R&D collaborations and non-patent IP policies in government technology transfer performance: Evidence from U.S. federal agencies (1999–2016)

name: Transfer Rate
define: The ratio of the number of newly granted patent licenses over the total number of filed patent applications in a given fiscal year.
source: Exploring the role of R&D collaborations and non-patent IP policies in government technology transfer performance: Evidence from U.S. federal agencies (1999–2016)

name: Licensing Success Rate
define: The number of licenses granted out of the total number of invention disclosures received by an agency’s Technology Transfer Office (TTO) in a given fiscal year.
source: Exploring the role of R&D collaborations and non-patent IP policies in government technology transfer performance: Evidence from U.S. federal agencies (1999–2016)

name: License Income (log)
define: The base 10 logarithm of the annual dollar amount of licensing income.
source: Exploring the role of R&D collaborations and non-patent IP policies in government technology transfer performance: Evidence from U.S. federal agencies (1999–2016)

name: Portfolio Exclusivity
define: The total annual amount of active exclusive licenses divided by total active income bearing licenses.
source: Exploring the role of R&D collaborations and non-patent IP policies in government technology transfer performance: Evidence from U.S. federal agencies (1999–2016)

name: FFRDC Utilization (%)
define: The percentage of FFRDCs utilized by a given agency in a given year.
source: Exploring the role of R&D collaborations and non-patent IP policies in government technology transfer performance: Evidence from U.S. federal agencies (1999–2016)

name: Traditional CRADAs (log)
define: The base 10 logarithm of an agency’s number of traditional CRADAs.
source: Exploring the role of R&D collaborations and non-patent IP policies in government technology transfer performance: Evidence from U.S. federal agencies (1999–2016)

name: Other R&D Collaborations (log)
define: The base 10 logarithm of the number of other collaborative R&D relationships that are not part of traditional CRADAs.
source: Exploring the role of R&D collaborations and non-patent IP policies in government technology transfer performance: Evidence from U.S. federal agencies (1999–2016)

name: Copyright Policy
define: A binary variable, which is 1 if the federal agency adopted copyright IP policy as a mechanism for technology transfer, and 0 otherwise.
source: Exploring the role of R&D collaborations and non-patent IP policies in government technology transfer performance: Evidence from U.S. federal agencies (1999–2016)

name: Materials Transfer Policy
define: A binary variable, which is 1 if the federal agency adopted MTAs as a mechanism for technology transfer, and 0 otherwise.
source: Exploring the role of R&D collaborations and non-patent IP policies in government technology transfer performance: Evidence from U.S. federal agencies (1999–2016)

name: Green Technological Innovation (GTI)
define: Measured by the number of green patent applications plus one, followed by logarithm.
source: Have environmental regulations promoted green technological innovation in cities? Evidence from China’s green patents

name: Environmental Regulation (ER)
define: Measured by a comprehensive score using the entropy method, reflecting the implementation of environmental regulations.
source: Have environmental regulations promoted green technological innovation in cities? Evidence from China’s green patents

name: Foreign Direct Investment (FDI)
define: Represented by the logarithm of the amount of foreign capital investment actually utilized.
source: Have environmental regulations promoted green technological innovation in cities? Evidence from China’s green patents

name: Government Technology Input (GOT)
define: Measured by the ratio of science and technology expenditure to GDP.
source: Have environmental regulations promoted green technological innovation in cities? Evidence from China’s green patents

name: Economic Development (ED)
define: Measured by the logarithm of per capita GDP.
source: Have environmental regulations promoted green technological innovation in cities? Evidence from China’s green patents

name: Industrial Structure (IS)
define: Measured by the ratio of the output value of secondary industry to regional GDP.
source: Have environmental regulations promoted green technological innovation in cities? Evidence from China’s green patents

name: Resource Endowments (RE)
define: Measured by the ratio of the number of people in the extractive industry to the total number of employees.
source: Have environmental regulations promoted green technological innovation in cities? Evidence from China’s green patents

name: Government Intervention (GI)
define: Measured by the ratio of public finance expenditure to regional GDP.
source: Have environmental regulations promoted green technological innovation in cities? Evidence from China’s green patents

name: Education Level (EL)
define: Measured by a comprehensive index based on the number of students at different education levels.
source: Have environmental regulations promoted green technological innovation in cities? Evidence from China’s green patents

name: Transportation Infrastructure Construction (TIC)
define: Measured by the total freight volume.
source: Have environmental regulations promoted green technological innovation in cities? Evidence from China’s green patents

name: ESG Score
define: A composite score and its sub-scores (Environmental E, Social S, and Corporate Governance G) that reflect a company's performance in environmental, social, and governance aspects.
source: Do environmental, social, and governance scores improve green innovation? Empirical evidence from Chinese-listed companies

name: Green Innovation
define: Measured by the number of green patents granted (GI) and the number of green patent citations (GC), representing the quantity and quality of a firm's green innovation.
source: Do environmental, social, and governance scores improve green innovation? Empirical evidence from Chinese-listed companies

name: Investment Efficiency
define: Measured by the absolute value of the residuals from a regression model, indicating the proportion of inefficient investment in the total investment.
source: Do environmental, social, and governance scores improve green innovation? Empirical evidence from Chinese-listed companies

name: Government Subsidies
define: Normalized government subsidies received by a firm, reflecting the relationship between the firm and the government.
source: Do environmental, social, and governance scores improve green innovation? Empirical evidence from Chinese-listed companies

name: Black Attributes
define: Include regional, industry, and company pollution attributes, measured by dummy variables for high pollution region (HPP), high pollution industry (HPI), and high pollution company (HPC).
source: Do environmental, social, and governance scores improve green innovation? Empirical evidence from Chinese-listed companies

name: Green Attributes
define: Include provincial, city, and firm environmental attributes, measured by green finance index (DGF), city green innovation (DGI), and corporate environmental disclosure (EDG).
source: Do environmental, social, and governance scores improve green innovation? Empirical evidence from Chinese-listed companies

name: Firm Characteristics
define: Control variables such as firm age (Age), leverage (Leverage), return on total assets (ROA), Tobin's Q (Q), net cash from investing activities (ICF), fixed assets (Fix), foreign ownership (QFII), dual employment (Dual), and audit opinion (Opinion).
source: Do environmental, social, and governance scores improve green innovation? Empirical evidence from Chinese-listed companies

name: Corporate Green Technology Innovation (GTI)
define: Measured by the number of applications for green invention patents and green utility model patents.
source: Environmental regulation effect on the different technology innovation-based the empirical analysis

name: Command Based Environmental Regulation (ER1)
define: Mandatory policies implemented by administrative departments.
source: Environmental regulation effect on the different technology innovation-based the empirical analysis

name: Market Oriented Environmental Regulation (ER2)
define: Based on market mechanisms and economic incentives.
source: Environmental regulation effect on the different technology innovation-based the empirical analysis

name: Voluntary Environmental Regulation (ER3)
define: Relies on public participation and supervision for implementation.
source: Environmental regulation effect on the different technology innovation-based the empirical analysis

name: R&D Investment
define: Corporate investment in research and development.
source: Environmental regulation effect on the different technology innovation-based the empirical analysis

name: Government Support
define: Support from the government for green innovation.
source: Environmental regulation effect on the different technology innovation-based the empirical analysis

name: Enterprise Size
define: The size of the company.
source: Environmental regulation effect on the different technology innovation-based the empirical analysis

name: Capital Intensity
define: The intensity of capital usage in the company.
source: Environmental regulation effect on the different technology innovation-based the empirical analysis

name: Returns
define: The financial returns of the company.
source: Environmental regulation effect on the different technology innovation-based the empirical analysis

name: Board Governance
define: The governance structure of the company's board.
source: Environmental regulation effect on the different technology innovation-based the empirical analysis

name: Company Maturity
define: The maturity level of the company.
source: Environmental regulation effect on the different technology innovation-based the empirical analysis

name: Analyst Coverage
define: A proxy variable for analyst coverage, measured using the natural logarithm of the number of analysts tracking the target firm plus one.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyst coverage and manufacturing enterprise green transition: An empirical study based on Chinese enterprises

name: Enterprise Green Transition (EGT)
define: A composite index focusing on green innovation, green production, green governance performance, and social responsibility.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyst coverage and manufacturing enterprise green transition: An empirical study based on Chinese enterprises

name: Information Transparency
define: Measured using the information quality evaluation grade disclosed by the Shenzhen Stock Exchange.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyst coverage and manufacturing enterprise green transition: An empirical study based on Chinese enterprises

name: Principal-Agent Conflict
define: Measured using the management expense ratio (MER).
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyst coverage and manufacturing enterprise green transition: An empirical study based on Chinese enterprises

name: Environmental Legitimacy Pressure (ELP)
define: Measured using the convergence of public media coverage.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyst coverage and manufacturing enterprise green transition: An empirical study based on Chinese enterprises

name: Profitability
define: Measured as net profit/total assets.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyst coverage and manufacturing enterprise green transition: An empirical study based on Chinese enterprises

name: Ownership Form
define: A binary variable indicating state-owned enterprise or not.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyst coverage and manufacturing enterprise green transition: An empirical study based on Chinese enterprises

name: Enterprise Age
define: Measured as the natural logarithm of the establishment period of the enterprise.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyst coverage and manufacturing enterprise green transition: An empirical study based on Chinese enterprises

name: Rights of Shareholders
define: Measured as the shareholding ratio of the top ten shareholders.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyst coverage and manufacturing enterprise green transition: An empirical study based on Chinese enterprises

name: Board Size
define: Measured as the number of board members.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyst coverage and manufacturing enterprise green transition: An empirical study based on Chinese enterprises

name: Fixed Assets Ratio
define: Measured as fixed assets/total assets.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyst coverage and manufacturing enterprise green transition: An empirical study based on Chinese enterprises

name: Growth Capability
define: Measured as the growth rate of revenue.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyst coverage and manufacturing enterprise green transition: An empirical study based on Chinese enterprises

name: Cash Flow Level
define: Measured as net cash flow from operating activities/total assets.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyst coverage and manufacturing enterprise green transition: An empirical study based on Chinese enterprises

name: Book-to-Market Ratio
define: Measured as net assets/market value of the company.
source: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyst coverage and manufacturing enterprise green transition: An empirical study based on Chinese enterprises

name: Green Innovation Performance (GIP)
define: The count of patent applications for green inventions, measured by the total quantity of green patents.
source: Green R&D investment, ESG reporting, and corporate green innovation performance

name: Green Research & Development (R&D)
define: The aggregate value of R&D expenditures, computed by combining both Green R&D and generic R&D expenditures.
source: Green R&D investment, ESG reporting, and corporate green innovation performance

name: Environmental Social & Governance (ESG)
define: ESG information serves as a proxy for ESG and is quantified as a score ranging from 1 to 100, assigned by a ranking agency to a specific business each year.
source: Green R&D investment, ESG reporting, and corporate green innovation performance

name: State Owned Enterprise (SOEs)
define: A dummy variable equivalent to 1 if the local or regional government is the dominant owner, and 0 otherwise.
source: Green R&D investment, ESG reporting, and corporate green innovation performance

name: Tobin Q
define: The market value of a firm’s outstanding shares to the replacement cost of its tangible assets.
source: Green R&D investment, ESG reporting, and corporate green innovation performance

name: Firm Age (FA)
define: The duration of the firm’s existence was used to establish its age.
source: Green R&D investment, ESG reporting, and corporate green innovation performance

name: Return of Assets (ROA)
define: A factor affecting the proportion of total profits to total assets.
source: Green R&D investment, ESG reporting, and corporate green innovation performance

name: Financial Leverage (FLever)
define: The asset-liability ratio, calculated as total liabilities divided by the total number of assets (total resources as an average).
source: Green R&D investment, ESG reporting, and corporate green innovation performance

name: CEO Duality (CEOD)
define: A binary variable, with 1 representing 'duality' when an individual holds the positions of Chairman and CEO simultaneously, and 0 representing 'non-duality'.
source: Green R&D investment, ESG reporting, and corporate green innovation performance

name: Firm Size (FS)
define: The total assets at the end of the fiscal year represent the aggregate value of all assets held by a company.
source: Green R&D investment, ESG reporting, and corporate green innovation performance

name: Ownership Concentration (OC)
define: The distribution of ownership stakes among shareholders in a company.
source: Green R&D investment, ESG reporting, and corporate green innovation performance

name: Investment Opportunities (IO)
define: Assets that offer the potential for financial gain or return on investment.
source: Green R&D investment, ESG reporting, and corporate green innovation performance

name: Growth Opportunity (GO)
define: Characterized as the pace of expansion in a company’s main source of income.
source: Green R&D investment, ESG reporting, and corporate green innovation performance

name: Year and Industry (YI)
define: In all regression analyses, Industry dummies are incorporated to manage the influences of both time (year) and specific firm characteristics.
source: Green R&D investment, ESG reporting, and corporate green innovation performance

name: TMT R&D Experience
define: A variable measuring the proportion of top management team members with prior work experience in R&D-related functions.
source: Top management team’s innovation-related characteristics and the ﬁrm’s explorative R&D: an analysis based on patent data

name: TMT Eng/Sci Education
define: A variable measuring the proportion of top management team members with a degree in engineering or science-related fields.
source: Top management team’s innovation-related characteristics and the ﬁrm’s explorative R&D: an analysis based on patent data

name: TMT Average Tenure
define: A variable measuring the average time in years that the top management team members have served in their positions.
source: Top management team’s innovation-related characteristics and the ﬁrm’s explorative R&D: an analysis based on patent data

name: Explorative R&D Activities
define: A variable measured using patent citations, patent classes, and non-patent references to indicate the firm's focus on explorative R&D.
source: Top management team’s innovation-related characteristics and the ﬁrm’s explorative R&D: an analysis based on patent data

name: R&D Intensity
define: A control variable representing the proportion of a firm's R&D expenses relative to its sales.
source: Top management team’s innovation-related characteristics and the ﬁrm’s explorative R&D: an analysis based on patent data

name: Firm Size
define: A control variable representing the volume of sales, log transformed, to account for differentiated innovation activities and performances between organizations of different sizes.
source: Top management team’s innovation-related characteristics and the ﬁrm’s explorative R&D: an analysis based on patent data

name: Firm Innovation Experience
define: A control variable using the number of granted patents applied for in the past three years before the focal year to proxy for innovation experience, log transformed.
source: Top management team’s innovation-related characteristics and the ﬁrm’s explorative R&D: an analysis based on patent data

name: Technological Diversity
define: A control variable calculated using the Herfindahl index to measure the diversity of patent classes in which each firm applied for ultimately granted patents during the past three years.
source: Top management team’s innovation-related characteristics and the ﬁrm’s explorative R&D: an analysis based on patent data

name: TMT Average Age
define: A control variable representing the average age of all the members in each firm’s top management team, standardized.
source: Top management team’s innovation-related characteristics and the ﬁrm’s explorative R&D: an analysis based on patent data

name: Heterogeneity of the TMT
define: A control variable measuring the diversity of the top management team members' educational and functional backgrounds using the Herfindahl index.
source: Top management team’s innovation-related characteristics and the ﬁrm’s explorative R&D: an analysis based on patent data

name: Design Experience Breadth [creator]
define: A measure of the variety of design fields a creator has experience in.
source: Linking Product Design and Technology: An Empirical Study on Performance and Experience in Novel Product Development Teams

name: Average Design Experience Breadth [colleagues]
define: The average variety of design fields experienced by a creator's colleagues.
source: Linking Product Design and Technology: An Empirical Study on Performance and Experience in Novel Product Development Teams

name: Design Experience Depth [creator]
define: A measure of the depth of experience in design fields for a creator.
source: Linking Product Design and Technology: An Empirical Study on Performance and Experience in Novel Product Development Teams

name: Average Design Experience Depth [colleagues]
define: The average depth of design experience among a creator's colleagues.
source: Linking Product Design and Technology: An Empirical Study on Performance and Experience in Novel Product Development Teams

name: Inventing Experience Breadth [creator]
define: A measure of the variety of technology fields a creator has invented in.
source: Linking Product Design and Technology: An Empirical Study on Performance and Experience in Novel Product Development Teams

name: Average Inventing Experience Breadth [colleagues]
define: The average variety of technology fields experienced in inventing by a creator's colleagues.
source: Linking Product Design and Technology: An Empirical Study on Performance and Experience in Novel Product Development Teams

name: Inventing Experience Depth [creator]
define: A measure of the depth of experience in technology fields for a creator.
source: Linking Product Design and Technology: An Empirical Study on Performance and Experience in Novel Product Development Teams

name: Average Inventing Experience Depth [colleagues]
define: The average depth of experience in technology fields among a creator's colleagues.
source: Linking Product Design and Technology: An Empirical Study on Performance and Experience in Novel Product Development Teams

name: Years in Office of Design Section Chief
define: A proxy for the degree of autonomy of the design section within an organization.
source: Linking Product Design and Technology: An Empirical Study on Performance and Experience in Novel Product Development Teams

name: Design Career [creator]
define: The number of years since a creator's first design application.
source: Linking Product Design and Technology: An Empirical Study on Performance and Experience in Novel Product Development Teams

name: Number of Colleagues in Designing
define: The number of colleagues working in the design field.
source: Linking Product Design and Technology: An Empirical Study on Performance and Experience in Novel Product Development Teams

name: Years in Office of CEO
define: A proxy to check the leadership effect on design activities.
source: Linking Product Design and Technology: An Empirical Study on Performance and Experience in Novel Product Development Teams

name: Production
define: A factor representing the economic activity level, measured by GDP.
source: A novel decomposition analysis of green patent applications for the evaluation of R&D efforts to reduce CO2 emissions from fossil fuel energy consumption

name: Energy Intensity
define: A factor indicating the ratio of total energy consumption to GDP.
source: A novel decomposition analysis of green patent applications for the evaluation of R&D efforts to reduce CO2 emissions from fossil fuel energy consumption

name: Fuel Mix
define: A factor indicating the proportion of fossil fuel energy in total energy consumption.
source: A novel decomposition analysis of green patent applications for the evaluation of R&D efforts to reduce CO2 emissions from fossil fuel energy consumption

name: CO2 Emission Coefficient
define: A factor arising from fossil fuel energy use, indicating the amount of CO2 emitted per unit of energy consumption.
source: A novel decomposition analysis of green patent applications for the evaluation of R&D efforts to reduce CO2 emissions from fossil fuel energy consumption

name: R&D Reaction
define: A factor indicating the ratio of R&D expenditures to CO2 emissions.
source: A novel decomposition analysis of green patent applications for the evaluation of R&D efforts to reduce CO2 emissions from fossil fuel energy consumption

name: R&D Efficiency
define: A factor indicating the efficiency of green patent generation based on R&D expenditures.
source: A novel decomposition analysis of green patent applications for the evaluation of R&D efforts to reduce CO2 emissions from fossil fuel energy consumption

name: Green Patent Applications
define: The number of patent applications related to green technologies improving the efficiency of fossil fuel energy.
source: A novel decomposition analysis of green patent applications for the evaluation of R&D efforts to reduce CO2 emissions from fossil fuel energy consumption

name: Inter-regional Investment
define: The sum of parent company’s investment in the subsidiary’s location for the year, used as a key independent variable.
source: Does inter-regional investment by publicly listed companies promote local green total factor productivity? A study of the mediation effects of green patents in China

name: Green Total Factor Productivity (GTFP)
define: The dependent variable, estimated by the Global-SBM-Luenberger model, incorporating resource and environmental constraints.
source: Does inter-regional investment by publicly listed companies promote local green total factor productivity? A study of the mediation effects of green patents in China

name: Green Invention Patents (GIP)
define: Mediating variable indicated by the number of green invention patents granted, further divided into seven categories according to WIPO’s IPC Green Inventory.
source: Does inter-regional investment by publicly listed companies promote local green total factor productivity? A study of the mediation effects of green patents in China

name: Green Utility Models (GUM)
define: Mediating variable indicated by the number of green utility models granted.
source: Does inter-regional investment by publicly listed companies promote local green total factor productivity? A study of the mediation effects of green patents in China

name: High-Speed Rail (HSR)
define: Policy factor used as an instrumental variable for inter-regional investment, a dummy variable indicating the opening of HSR links.
source: Does inter-regional investment by publicly listed companies promote local green total factor productivity? A study of the mediation effects of green patents in China

name: GDP per Capita
define: Control variable representing the natural logarithm of real GDP per capita for the year, deflated by 2008 as the base period.
source: Does inter-regional investment by publicly listed companies promote local green total factor productivity? A study of the mediation effects of green patents in China

name: Tertiary Sector Share
define: Control variable representing the share of tertiary sector value-added in GDP.
source: Does inter-regional investment by publicly listed companies promote local green total factor productivity? A study of the mediation effects of green patents in China

name: Foreign Direct Investment (FDI)
define: Control variable representing the natural logarithm of the actual amount of foreign investment utilized for the year.
source: Does inter-regional investment by publicly listed companies promote local green total factor productivity? A study of the mediation effects of green patents in China

name: Road Length
define: Control variable representing the natural logarithm of the road length for the year.
source: Does inter-regional investment by publicly listed companies promote local green total factor productivity? A study of the mediation effects of green patents in China

name: Education and Science Technology Expenditure
define: Control variable representing the natural logarithm of expenditure on science, technology, and education for the year.
source: Does inter-regional investment by publicly listed companies promote local green total factor productivity? A study of the mediation effects of green patents in China

name: Environmental Regulation
define: Control variable representing the degree of environmental regulations, measured by the proportion of environment-related terms in each city’s annual government bulletin.
source: Does inter-regional investment by publicly listed companies promote local green total factor productivity? A study of the mediation effects of green patents in China

name: Market Segmentation
define: Control variable representing market segmentation, a dummy variable for cities with multiple dialect areas.
source: Does inter-regional investment by publicly listed companies promote local green total factor productivity? A study of the mediation effects of green patents in China

name: Alliance Portfolio Partner Diversity (APPD)
define: A measure of the variety of partner types in a firm's alliance portfolio.
source: Alliance portfolio diversity, radical and incremental innovation: The moderating role of technology management

name: Technology Management Tools (TM-tools)
define: Managerial routines used for identifying, selecting, and combining relevant technologies from external partners.
source: Alliance portfolio diversity, radical and incremental innovation: The moderating role of technology management

name: Incremental Innovation Outcomes
define: The proportion of sales from products or services that are technologically improved versions of existing ones.
source: Alliance portfolio diversity, radical and incremental innovation: The moderating role of technology management

name: Radical Innovation Outcomes
define: The proportion of sales from products or services that are technologically new to the market.
source: Alliance portfolio diversity, radical and incremental innovation: The moderating role of technology management

name: Use of Codified Knowledge Sources
define: The extent to which firms use patents, electronic databases, and professional literature for innovation activities.
source: Alliance portfolio diversity, radical and incremental innovation: The moderating role of technology management

name: R&D Intensity
define: The percentage of personnel of a firm involved in R&D activities.
source: Alliance portfolio diversity, radical and incremental innovation: The moderating role of technology management

name: Innovation Bottlenecks
define: The number of different types of bottlenecks to innovation that a firm has experienced.
source: Alliance portfolio diversity, radical and incremental innovation: The moderating role of technology management

name: Firm Size
define: The natural logarithm of the amount of full-time employees that a firm has.
source: Alliance portfolio diversity, radical and incremental innovation: The moderating role of technology management

name: Foreign Owned Firm
define: A dummy variable indicating whether the firm is owned by a foreign partner.
source: Alliance portfolio diversity, radical and incremental innovation: The moderating role of technology management

name: Exporting Firm
define: A dummy variable indicating whether the firm had generated sales from products and services sold outside South Africa.
source: Alliance portfolio diversity, radical and incremental innovation: The moderating role of technology management

name: Firm Diversification
define: A count variable that captures the number of two-digit NACE-sectors in which a firm is active.
source: Alliance portfolio diversity, radical and incremental innovation: The moderating role of technology management

name: Pavitt Sectors
define: Dummy variables for different Pavitt-sectors to control for differences between sectors.
source: Alliance portfolio diversity, radical and incremental innovation: The moderating role of technology management

name: Technological Diversity
define: A niche-level property given by the 'disparity' of the technological subclasses that compose the niche.
source: Technological entry in new niches: Diversity, crowding and generalism

name: Technological Crowding
define: A measure of the overlap of patent portfolios in terms of common backward patent citations within a niche.
source: Technological entry in new niches: Diversity, crowding and generalism

name: Firm's Knowledge Generalism
define: A firm-level characteristic referring to the scope of innovative competences and the distinction between specialist and generalist organizations.
source: Technological entry in new niches: Diversity, crowding and generalism

name: Entry
define: A firm’s entry in a technological niche that is new-to-the-firm and features a slow, post-entry, reaction time.
source: Technological entry in new niches: Diversity, crowding and generalism

name: Exploration
define: A firm’s further exploration of a new niche, conditional on having entered.
source: Technological entry in new niches: Diversity, crowding and generalism

name: Firm R&D
define: Research and development expenses over total assets.
source: Technological entry in new niches: Diversity, crowding and generalism

name: Firm Sales
define: Sales over total assets.
source: Technological entry in new niches: Diversity, crowding and generalism

name: Firm Age
define: The number of years that the firm has been active in patenting.
source: Technological entry in new niches: Diversity, crowding and generalism

name: Firm Size
define: The logarithm of the number of employees.
source: Technological entry in new niches: Diversity, crowding and generalism

name: Number of Previous Niches
define: The number of niches in which the firm was active before the focal year.
source: Technological entry in new niches: Diversity, crowding and generalism

name: General Speed of Patenting
define: The firm’s average reaction time between patents measured before the focal year.
source: Technological entry in new niches: Diversity, crowding and generalism

name: Collaborative Ph.D. Projects
define: A binary variable indicating whether a Ph.D. project was conducted in collaboration with industry or a Public Research Organisation (PRO).
source: Does working with industry come at a price? A study of doctoral candidates’ performance in collaborative vs. non-collaborative Ph.D. projects

name: Non-Collaborative Ph.D. Projects
define: A binary variable indicating whether a Ph.D. project was conducted without any collaboration.
source: Does working with industry come at a price? A study of doctoral candidates’ performance in collaborative vs. non-collaborative Ph.D. projects

name: Academic Performance
define: A composite variable measured by the number of publications and publication citations.
source: Does working with industry come at a price? A study of doctoral candidates’ performance in collaborative vs. non-collaborative Ph.D. projects

name: Industrial Performance
define: A composite variable measured by the number of patents and patent citations.
source: Does working with industry come at a price? A study of doctoral candidates’ performance in collaborative vs. non-collaborative Ph.D. projects

name: Collaboration with Philips
define: A binary variable indicating whether a Ph.D. project was conducted in collaboration with Philips.
source: Does working with industry come at a price? A study of doctoral candidates’ performance in collaborative vs. non-collaborative Ph.D. projects

name: Collaboration with Other Firms
define: A binary variable indicating whether a Ph.D. project was conducted in collaboration with firms other than Philips.
source: Does working with industry come at a price? A study of doctoral candidates’ performance in collaborative vs. non-collaborative Ph.D. projects
