name: Collaboration with PROs
define: A binary variable indicating whether a Ph.D. project was conducted in collaboration with Public Research Organisations.
source: Does working with industry come at a price? A study of doctoral candidates’ performance in collaborative vs. non-collaborative Ph.D. projects

name: Disciplinary Nature
define: A categorical variable representing the department in which the project was executed.
source: Does working with industry come at a price? A study of doctoral candidates’ performance in collaborative vs. non-collaborative Ph.D. projects

name: Nationality of Doctoral Candidate
define: A categorical variable representing the nationality of the doctoral candidate.
source: Does working with industry come at a price? A study of doctoral candidates’ performance in collaborative vs. non-collaborative Ph.D. projects

name: Gender of Doctoral Candidate
define: A binary variable indicating the gender of the doctoral candidate.
source: Does working with industry come at a price? A study of doctoral candidates’ performance in collaborative vs. non-collaborative Ph.D. projects

name: University Supervisor is Star Scientist
define: A binary variable indicating whether the doctoral candidate was supervised by a 'star scientist'.
source: Does working with industry come at a price? A study of doctoral candidates’ performance in collaborative vs. non-collaborative Ph.D. projects

name: University Technology Commercialisation
define: The process of exploiting academic knowledge through mechanisms such as licensing patents or launching university spin-offs.
source: Multi-dimensional time and university technology commercialisation as opportunity praxis: A realist synthesis of the accumulated literature

name: Opportunity Praxis
define: The identification of a source of demand for the exploitation of knowledge that shapes future products and markets.
source: Multi-dimensional time and university technology commercialisation as opportunity praxis: A realist synthesis of the accumulated literature

name: Temporal Framework
define: A novel framework developed to understand the opportunity praxis of university technology commercialisation.
source: Multi-dimensional time and university technology commercialisation as opportunity praxis: A realist synthesis of the accumulated literature

name: Critical Realism
define: A paradigmatic foundation used to build the temporal framework and understand the underlying structures of society.
source: Multi-dimensional time and university technology commercialisation as opportunity praxis: A realist synthesis of the accumulated literature

name: User-Entrepreneurs
define: Individuals who are involved in the commercialisation process and make choices from a variety of alternatives.
source: Multi-dimensional time and university technology commercialisation as opportunity praxis: A realist synthesis of the accumulated literature

name: Organisations
define: Entities that participate in the commercialisation of university-held patents and are influenced by temporality.
source: Multi-dimensional time and university technology commercialisation as opportunity praxis: A realist synthesis of the accumulated literature

name: Innovation
define: The extension of commercialisation boundaries towards the creation of new products and markets.
source: Multi-dimensional time and university technology commercialisation as opportunity praxis: A realist synthesis of the accumulated literature

name: Path Dependence
define: The influence of past actions on the present, affecting the exploitation of protected knowledge.
source: Multi-dimensional time and university technology commercialisation as opportunity praxis: A realist synthesis of the accumulated literature

name: Transformational Change
define: The potential for change inherent in opportunity praxis, influenced by the constraining influence of path dependence.
source: Multi-dimensional time and university technology commercialisation as opportunity praxis: A realist synthesis of the accumulated literature

name: Licensing
define: A mechanism for university technology commercialisation where existing user-organisations license university-generated knowledge.
source: Multi-dimensional time and university technology commercialisation as opportunity praxis: A realist synthesis of the accumulated literature

name: Spin-Offs
define: A mechanism for university technology commercialisation where academics drive the process, often resulting in new company creation.
source: Multi-dimensional time and university technology commercialisation as opportunity praxis: A realist synthesis of the accumulated literature

name: Experience of Abandoning Innovation Projects (ABANDON)
define: A binary variable indicating whether a firm's innovation activities had been abandoned during the three years preceding the survey period.
source: Technovation 114 (2022) 102435

name: Number of Patent Applications (PATENT)
define: A variable measured by taking the natural logarithms of the number of patent applications, representing the efforts made by a firm to protect its intellectual property.
source: Technovation 114 (2022) 102435

name: Foreign Direct Investment in R&D (FOREIGN)
define: A variable measured by taking the natural logarithms of internal R&D expenses from foreign organizations.
source: Technovation 114 (2022) 102435

name: Internal R&D Expense Intensity (INTRD)
define: A variable measured using the natural logarithm of the fraction of in-house R&D investment.
source: Technovation 114 (2022) 102435

name: External R&D Expense Intensity (EXTRD)
define: A variable measured by the fraction of external R&D expenditure out of total R&D expenditure.
source: Technovation 114 (2022) 102435

name: Employment Size (EMPLOYMENT)
define: A variable measured by the natural logarithm of the number of employees.
source: Technovation 114 (2022) 102435

name: Firms’ Turnover per Employee (LABOR)
define: A variable measured using the natural logarithms of the ratio of turnover to the number of employees.
source: Technovation 114 (2022) 102435

name: Firm Type (FIRMTYPE)
define: A categorical variable indicating the type of firm, such as public, private national, or private multinational firms with varying degrees of foreign capital.
source: Technovation 114 (2022) 102435

name: Industry
define: A variable represented by a two-digit Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) code to classify 43 manufacturing industries.
source: Technovation 114 (2022) 102435

name: Year
define: A variable represented by dummy variables from 2008 to 2015 to account for unobserved across-time endogeneity.
source: Technovation 114 (2022) 102435

name: Imported ESTs
define: A variable representing the value of imported environmentally sound technologies by firms.
source: Crowding in or crowding out? The effect of imported environmentally sound technologies on indigenous green innovation

name: Green Innovation
define: A variable measured by the number of green patent applications filed by firms.
source: Crowding in or crowding out? The effect of imported environmentally sound technologies on indigenous green innovation

name: Technological Proximity
define: A variable measured by the natural logarithm of firms' total factor productivity, indicating the level of technological proximity to the global green technology frontier.
source: Crowding in or crowding out? The effect of imported environmentally sound technologies on indigenous green innovation

name: Learning Ability
define: A variable measured by the natural logarithm of the current value of the accumulated count of patent applicants, representing the firm's absorptive capacity.
source: Crowding in or crowding out? The effect of imported environmentally sound technologies on indigenous green innovation

name: Government Subsidies
define: A variable measured by the logarithm of the amount of government subsidies received by firms.
source: Crowding in or crowding out? The effect of imported environmentally sound technologies on indigenous green innovation

name: Export Status
define: A dummy variable indicating whether a firm engages in exporting activities.
source: Crowding in or crowding out? The effect of imported environmentally sound technologies on indigenous green innovation

name: Firm Size
define: A variable calculated as the natural logarithm of a firm's total assets.
source: Crowding in or crowding out? The effect of imported environmentally sound technologies on indigenous green innovation

name: Firm Age
define: A variable calculated as the natural logarithm of the number of years since a firm was established.
source: Crowding in or crowding out? The effect of imported environmentally sound technologies on indigenous green innovation

name: Capital-Labor Ratio
define: A variable calculated as the natural logarithm of total assets divided by the number of employees.
source: Crowding in or crowding out? The effect of imported environmentally sound technologies on indigenous green innovation

name: Ownership Structure
define: A variable measured as the ratio of shares owned by the state or state-owned legal entity.
source: Crowding in or crowding out? The effect of imported environmentally sound technologies on indigenous green innovation

name: Return on Assets
define: A variable calculated as net income divided by stockholders' equity, indicative of firm profitability.
source: Crowding in or crowding out? The effect of imported environmentally sound technologies on indigenous green innovation

name: Hierarchical Semantic Network
define: A network constructed based on SAO structures extracted from patents, consisting of three layers representing subject, action, and object.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Dual Link Prediction
define: A methodology combining probabilistic-based and similarity-based link prediction to identify and evaluate technology opportunities.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Probabilistic-based Link Prediction
define: A Bayesian probabilistic-based GTM method applied to identify patent vacuums, representing potential semantic technology opportunities.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Similarity-based Link Prediction
define: A method using cosine similarity to evaluate the novelty of technology opportunities generated by GTM.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Technology Opportunities
define: Potential areas for technological advancement identified through the analysis of hierarchical semantic networks and link prediction.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: SAO Structures
define: Subject-Action-Object structures extracted from patent documents, serving as the basis for constructing the hierarchical semantic network.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA)
define: A topic modeling method used to reduce the dimensionality of SAO structures and address data sparsity issues.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Generative Topographic Mapping (GTM)
define: A probabilistic model used for mapping multi-dimensional data to low-dimensional potential spaces, employed in link prediction.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Cosine Similarity
define: A metric used to calculate the similarity between vectors, employed to evaluate the novelty of technology opportunities.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Novelty
define: A measure of the unusual or unexpected aspects of an idea, used to evaluate the creativity of predicted technology opportunities.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Feasibility
define: A measure of how feasible or marketable an idea is, used to assess the practicality of technology opportunities.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Usefulness
define: A measure of the practical application value of an idea, used to evaluate the utility of technology opportunities.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Resident Patent Applications
define: A proxy for innovation, measured by the number of patent applications by residents.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Nonresident Patent Applications
define: A proxy for innovation, measured by the number of patent applications by non-residents.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Scientific and Technical Journal Articles
define: A proxy for innovation, measured by the number of publications in scientific and technical journals.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Research and Development Expenditures
define: A proxy for innovation, measured by R&D expenditures as a percentage of GDP.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Trade Openness
define: The degree of trade openness, measured by (Exports + Imports/GDP) * 100.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: GDP per Capita
define: A control variable, measured in real terms, used to capture the size of the market.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Foreign Direct Investment
define: A control variable, measured by net FDI inflows as a percent of GDP.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Inflation Rate
define: A control variable, approximated by the growth of the consumer price index.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Domestic Investment
define: A control variable, measured by gross fixed capital formation as a percentage of GDP.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Employment Level
define: A control variable, measured by the number of people engaged.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Alliance Portfolio Partner Diversity (APPD)
define: A measure of the variety of partner types in a firm's alliance portfolio, calculated by dividing the number of different types of partners by the maximum possible amount of different partners and squaring the result.
source: Alliance portfolio diversity, radical and incremental innovation: The moderating role of technology management

name: Technology Management Tools (TM-tools)
define: Managerial routines used for identifying, selecting, and leveraging technological knowledge and skills for developing new products, processes, and improving existing technology.
