source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA)
define: A topic modeling method used to reduce the dimensionality of SAO structures and address data sparsity issues.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Generative Topographic Mapping (GTM)
define: A probabilistic model used for mapping multi-dimensional data to low-dimensional potential spaces, employed in link prediction.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Cosine Similarity
define: A metric used to calculate the similarity between vectors, employed to evaluate the novelty of technology opportunities.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Novelty
define: A measure of the unusual or unexpected aspects of an idea, used to evaluate the creativity of predicted technology opportunities.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Feasibility
define: A measure of how feasible or marketable an idea is, used to assess the practicality of technology opportunities.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Usefulness
define: A measure of the practical application value of an idea, used to evaluate the utility of technology opportunities.
source: Technology opportunity analysis using hierarchical semantic networks and dual link prediction

name: Resident Patent Applications
define: A proxy for innovation, measured by the number of patent applications by residents.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Nonresident Patent Applications
define: A proxy for innovation, measured by the number of patent applications by nonresidents.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Scientific and Technical Journal Articles
define: A proxy for innovation, measured by the number of publications in scientific and technical journals.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Research and Development Expenditures
define: A proxy for innovation, measured by R&D expenditures as a percentage of GDP.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Trade Openness
define: The degree of trade openness, measured by (Exports + Imports/GDP) * 100.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: GDP per Capita
define: A control variable, measured in real terms, used to capture the size of the market.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Foreign Direct Investment
define: A control variable, measured by net FDI inflows as a percent of GDP.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Inflation Rate
define: A control variable, approximated by the growth of the consumer price index.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Domestic Investment
define: A control variable, measured by gross fixed capital formation as a percentage of GDP.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Employment Level
define: A control variable, measured by the number of people engaged.
source: Do domestic innovations promote trade openness? Empirical evidence from emerging economies

name: Patent
define: The natural log of the total number of patent applications, an indicator of national innovation performance.
source: Technovation 119 (2023) 102634

name: Trademark
define: The natural log of the total number of trademark applications, another indicator of national innovation performance.
source: Technovation 119 (2023) 102634

name: Affected
define: The natural log of the total number of people affected by epidemics, a measure of epidemic severity.
source: Technovation 119 (2023) 102634

name: Deaths
define: The natural log of the total number of people that died as a result of epidemics, a measure of epidemic severity.
source: Technovation 119 (2023) 102634

name: GDP
define: The natural log of gross domestic product, a measure of a country's economic development.
source: Technovation 119 (2023) 102634

name: Industry
define: The natural log of the industrial value added (% of GDP), indicating the country's industrial productivity.
source: Technovation 119 (2023) 102634

name: Density
define: The natural log of people per square km of land area, a measure of population density.
source: Technovation 119 (2023) 102634

name: Labor
define: The natural log of the total size of the labor force, indicating the workforce available for innovation.
source: Technovation 119 (2023) 102634

name: Education
define: The natural log of government expenditure on education (% of GDP), reflecting the emphasis on education.
source: Technovation 119 (2023) 102634

name: FDI
define: The natural log of the net inflows of foreign direct investment (% of GDP), indicating foreign investment in the country.
source: Technovation 119 (2023) 102634

name: R&D
define: The natural log of research and development expenditure (% of GDP), a direct driver of innovation.
source: Technovation 119 (2023) 102634

name: IPE
define: The natural log of the total number of international personnel exchange, reflecting the level of a country's openness.
source: Technovation 119 (2023) 102634

name: Novel Technology Convergence (NTC)
define: A variable representing the convergence of different technological fields that have never been converged before.
source: Quantity or quality: The roles of technology and science convergence on firm innovation performance

name: Reinforced Technology Convergence (RTC)
define: A variable representing the systematic reconfiguration of resources and refinement of known convergence methods to exploit and enhance existing technologies.
source: Quantity or quality: The roles of technology and science convergence on firm innovation performance

name: Science Convergence
define: A variable representing the blending of scientific knowledge from different scientific disciplines.
source: Quantity or quality: The roles of technology and science convergence on firm innovation performance

name: Innovation Quantity
define: A variable measured by the count of invention patent applications.
source: Quantity or quality: The roles of technology and science convergence on firm innovation performance

name: Innovation Quality
define: A variable measured by patent family size, forward citations, and patent claims.
source: Quantity or quality: The roles of technology and science convergence on firm innovation performance

name: Firm Age
define: A control variable representing the number of years since the firm's establishment.
source: Quantity or quality: The roles of technology and science convergence on firm innovation performance

name: State-owned Firm
define: A control variable indicating whether the firm has state-owned shares.
source: Quantity or quality: The roles of technology and science convergence on firm innovation performance

name: Foreign-owned Firm
define: A control variable indicating whether the firm has foreign-owned shares.
source: Quantity or quality: The roles of technology and science convergence on firm innovation performance

name: Public Firm
define: A control variable indicating whether the firm is listed on Chinese exchanges.
source: Quantity or quality: The roles of technology and science convergence on firm innovation performance

name: R&D Team Size
define: A control variable measured by the average number of inventors on each patent.
source: Quantity or quality: The roles of technology and science convergence on firm innovation performance

name: Patent Stock
define: A control variable calculated as the natural logarithm of the count of all invention patents applied for by the firm in the last five years.
source: Quantity or quality: The roles of technology and science convergence on firm innovation performance

name: Paper Stock
define: A control variable calculated as the natural logarithm of the count of all papers published in the organic chemistry discipline by the firm in the last five years.
source: Quantity or quality: The roles of technology and science convergence on firm innovation performance

name: Technology Strength (TSt)
define: A set of indexes reflecting a partner's technological capabilities, including technology share, technology leadership, technological impact, and technology marketability.
source: Identifying and evaluating strategic partners for collaborative R&D: Index-based approach using patents and publications

name: R&D Openness (RdO)
define: Indexes indicating a firm's tendency to collaborate and communicate with other partners, including organisational openness, field openness, and technology openness.
source: Identifying and evaluating strategic partners for collaborative R&D: Index-based approach using patents and publications

name: R&D Linkage (RdL)
define: Indexes measuring the level of prior R&D collaborations, including joint ownership, joint development, and joint operation.
source: Identifying and evaluating strategic partners for collaborative R&D: Index-based approach using patents and publications

name: Collaboration Effect (CoE)
define: Indexes predicting the synergy effects from collaboration, including knowledge inflow, knowledge criticality, and knowledge similarity.
source: Identifying and evaluating strategic partners for collaborative R&D: Index-based approach using patents and publications

name: Patents
define: A data source used for analyzing technology strength, R&D openness, and R&D linkage.
source: Identifying and evaluating strategic partners for collaborative R&D: Index-based approach using patents and publications

name: Publications
define: A data source used for analyzing technology strength, R&D openness, and R&D linkage, with a focus on basic technologies and applied research.
source: Identifying and evaluating strategic partners for collaborative R&D: Index-based approach using patents and publications

name: Strategic Partner
define: An outside organisation or nation that can help enhance a firm's internal technological power via R&D collaboration.
source: Identifying and evaluating strategic partners for collaborative R&D: Index-based approach using patents and publications

name: Index Values
define: Quantitative values assigned to each index, reflecting the characteristics of potential collaborators.
source: Identifying and evaluating strategic partners for collaborative R&D: Index-based approach using patents and publications

name: Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP)
define: A multi-criteria decision-making method used to determine the weights for each criteria of partner selection and the weights for each database.
source: Identifying and evaluating strategic partners for collaborative R&D: Index-based approach using patents and publications

name: Normalised Index Values
define: Rescaled index values ranging from 0 to 1, used for integrating different indexes into a single value for prioritising potential candidates.
source: Identifying and evaluating strategic partners for collaborative R&D: Index-based approach using patents and publications

name: Nurse Staffing
define: Refers to the number of nurses and their skill mix in a given patient care unit.
source: Twenty years of staffing, practice environment, and outcomes research in military nursing

name: Patient Outcomes
define: Includes various measures such as patient mortality, falls, medication errors, and hospital-acquired pressure injuries.
source: Twenty years of staffing, practice environment, and outcomes research in military nursing

name: Practice Environment
define: Conditions under which nurses work, including leadership, resource availability, and collaboration with physicians.
source: Twenty years of staffing, practice environment, and outcomes research in military nursing

name: Nurse Job Satisfaction
define: Evaluated through surveys and may influence nurse turnover and patient care quality.
source: Twenty years of staffing, practice environment, and outcomes research in military nursing

name: Nurse Education and Experience
define: Nurses' qualifications and experience that can impact the quality of care provided.
source: Twenty years of staffing, practice environment, and outcomes research in military nursing

name: Patient Turnover
define: The rate at which patients are admitted, discharged, or transferred, affecting nursing workload.
source: Twenty years of staffing, practice environment, and outcomes research in military nursing

name: Patient Acuity
define: The level of care required by patients, influencing the demand for nursing resources.
source: Twenty years of staffing, practice environment, and outcomes research in military nursing

name: Nursing Workload
define: The amount of work required by nursing staff, which can be influenced by patient turnover and acuity.
source: Twenty years of staffing, practice environment, and outcomes research in military nursing

name: Nurse-Committed Medication Errors
define: Errors made by nursing staff in medication administration.
source: Twenty years of staffing, practice environment, and outcomes research in military nursing

name: Needlestick Injuries
define: Injuries to nursing staff from accidental needle pricks, an occupational safety concern.
source: Twenty years of staffing, practice environment, and outcomes research in military nursing

name: Green Patent Applications
define: A proxy variable for green innovation, representing the number of green patent applications in a region.
source: Spatial-temporal heterogeneity of green innovation in China

name: Population Scale
define: The population size of a region, which may influence the level of green innovation.
source: Spatial-temporal heterogeneity of green innovation in China

name: Economic Development
define: Measured by the ratio of GDP to population scale (per capita GDP), representing the economic development level of a region.
source: Spatial-temporal heterogeneity of green innovation in China

name: Environmental Regulation
define: Measured by the ratio of environmental pollution control investment to GDP, indicating the intensity of environmental regulation.
source: Spatial-temporal heterogeneity of green innovation in China

name: R&D Reaction
define: The ratio of R&D expenditure to environmental pollution control investment, reflecting the innovation intensity and technological content of a region.
source: Spatial-temporal heterogeneity of green innovation in China

name: R&D Efficiency
define: The ratio of green patent applications to R&D expenditure, indicating the efficiency of R&D in generating green innovation.
source: Spatial-temporal heterogeneity of green innovation in China

name: Trademark Registration
define: A dummy variable indicating whether a social startup registered a trademark within the first three years of its existence.
source: Trademarks and how they relate to the sustainability and economic outcomes of social startups

name: Trademark Breadth
define: A set of dummy variables indicating the number of Nice classes covered by the trademark portfolio within the first three years of the social startup’s founding.
source: Trademarks and how they relate to the sustainability and economic outcomes of social startups

name: Geographical Scope
define: A set of dummy variables indicating the geographical scope of trademark protection, such as national or international.
source: Trademarks and how they relate to the sustainability and economic outcomes of social startups

name: Economic Outcome Measure
define: A binary variable indicating whether a social startup has created more than ten jobs.
source: Trademarks and how they relate to the sustainability and economic outcomes of social startups

name: Sustainability Outcome Measure
define: A binary variable indicating high sustainability outcomes, defined by receiving investments from social venture capitalists, Phineo Impact or B Corp certification, or membership in the Ashoka support network.
source: Trademarks and how they relate to the sustainability and economic outcomes of social startups

name: Metropolis
define: A dummy variable indicating whether the social startup was established in a major German city.
source: Trademarks and how they relate to the sustainability and economic outcomes of social startups

name: Team
define: A dummy variable indicating whether the social startup was founded by a team.
source: Trademarks and how they relate to the sustainability and economic outcomes of social startups

name: Patent Dummy
define: A dummy variable indicating whether a patent was registered by the social startup within its first three years.
source: Trademarks and how they relate to the sustainability and economic outcomes of social startups

name: Female
define: The proportion of women in the founding team.
source: Trademarks and how they relate to the sustainability and economic outcomes of social startups

name: Founding Year Dummies
define: A set of dummy variables capturing the year in which a social startup was founded.
source: Trademarks and how they relate to the sustainability and economic outcomes of social startups

name: SDG Dummies
define: A set of dummy variables capturing which of the 17 SDGs a social startup addresses.
source: Trademarks and how they relate to the sustainability and economic outcomes of social startups

name: Green Technologies (GT)
define: Measured by the count of patent applications in 'Environmentally Sound' technology fields from 2005 to 2007.
source: Beyond inducement in climate change: Does environmental performance spur environmental technologies? A regional analysis of cross-sectoral differences

name: Emission Intensity (EMij)
define: Measures the emission efficiency of a Region and Sector in terms of the value added.
source: Beyond inducement in climate change: Does environmental performance spur environmental technologies? A regional analysis of cross-sectoral differences

name: Related Emission Intensity (Wjl ∗ EMil ≠ j)
define: Measures the emission efficiency of vertically related sectors.
source: Beyond inducement in climate change: Does environmental performance spur environmental technologies? A regional analysis of cross-sectoral differences

name: Value Added (VA)
define: The average real value added of a Region and Sector from 2003 to 2005.
source: Beyond inducement in climate change: Does environmental performance spur environmental technologies? A regional analysis of cross-sectoral differences

name: Public R&D (PURD)
define: The share of public R&D over the total R&D.
source: Beyond inducement in climate change: Does environmental performance spur environmental technologies? A regional analysis of cross-sectoral differences

name: Export Oriented Activities (EXPORT_UE)
define: The effect of export oriented activities within the European Union from 2003 to 2005.
source: Beyond inducement in climate change: Does environmental performance spur environmental technologies? A regional analysis of cross-sectoral differences

name: Density (DENSITY)
define: The ratio between the Population and the Area of a Region.
source: Beyond inducement in climate change: Does environmental performance spur environmental technologies? A regional analysis of cross-sectoral differences

name: Dirty Sectors (DIRTY)
define: A binary variable indicating the most polluting sectors.
source: Beyond inducement in climate change: Does environmental performance spur environmental technologies? A regional analysis of cross-sectoral differences

name: Environmental Protection Expenditure (POL)
define: The natural logarithm of the ratio between average regional expenditure for environmental protection and the value added.
source: Beyond inducement in climate change: Does environmental performance spur environmental technologies? A regional analysis of cross-sectoral differences

name: Metropolitan Areas (METRO)
define: A binary variable indicating the presence of metropolitan areas.
source: Beyond inducement in climate change: Does environmental performance spur environmental technologies? A regional analysis of cross-sectoral differences

name: Climate Policy Uncertainty (CPU)
define: A measure of uncertainty in climate policies, used as an index in the study.
source: How does climate policy uncertainty affect green technology innovation at the corporate level? New evidence from China

name: Green Technology Innovation (GTI)
define: Measured by the number of green patent applications, indicating corporate green technology development.
source: How does climate policy uncertainty affect green technology innovation at the corporate level? New evidence from China

name: R&D Investment (RD)
define: The amount of funds used by a company to develop new technologies or new products.
source: How does climate policy uncertainty affect green technology innovation at the corporate level? New evidence from China

name: Risk Tolerance (ROA)
define: Measured by Return on Total Assets, indicating a company’s risk tolerance.
source: How does climate policy uncertainty affect green technology innovation at the corporate level? New evidence from China

name: Government Subsidies (SUB)
define: The sum of money received by corporations from the government each year.
source: How does climate policy uncertainty affect green technology innovation at the corporate level? New evidence from China

name: Environmental Regulations (REGUL)
define: The share of completed investment in industrial pollution control as a percentage of industrial value added in the province where the corporate is located.
source: How does climate policy uncertainty affect green technology innovation at the corporate level? New evidence from China

name: Company Size (SIZE)
define: The logarithm of the corporate’s total assets.
source: How does climate policy uncertainty affect green technology innovation at the corporate level? New evidence from China

name: Financial Leverage Ratio (LEV)
define: The ratio of equity capital to total assets in the balance sheet.
source: How does climate policy uncertainty affect green technology innovation at the corporate level? New evidence from China

name: Revenue Growth Rate (GROW)
define: The revenue growth rate of the company.
source: How does climate policy uncertainty affect green technology innovation at the corporate level? New evidence from China

name: Equity Concentration (EC)
define: The share of the first largest shareholder’s shareholding in the total shares of the company.
source: How does climate policy uncertainty affect green technology innovation at the corporate level? New evidence from China

name: Institutional Shareholding Ratio (INS)
define: The ratio of the total number of shares held by institutional investors to the total number of shares.
source: How does climate policy uncertainty affect green technology innovation at the corporate level? New evidence from China

name: Lithium Air Battery
define: A type of metal-air battery with lithium metal as an anode and oxygen as a cathode reactant.
source: Tracing the technological development trajectory in post-lithium-ion battery technologies: A patent-based approach

name: Lithium Sulfur Battery
define: A battery consisting of a lithium metal anode, a sulfur composite cathode, and an organic electrolyte.
source: Tracing the technological development trajectory in post-lithium-ion battery technologies: A patent-based approach

name: Sodium-ion Battery
define: A battery with similar architecture to lithium-ion batteries, using carbonaceous anode materials and layered transition metal oxides cathode.
source: Tracing the technological development trajectory in post-lithium-ion battery technologies: A patent-based approach

name: Patent Applications
define: The number of patents related to post-lithium-ion battery technologies.
source: Tracing the technological development trajectory in post-lithium-ion battery technologies: A patent-based approach

name: Country of Origin
define: The country where the patent was first filed.
source: Tracing the technological development trajectory in post-lithium-ion battery technologies: A patent-based approach

name: Patent Assignees
define: The organizations or individuals to whom the patents were granted.
source: Tracing the technological development trajectory in post-lithium-ion battery technologies: A patent-based approach

name: Derwent Class Codes
define: Classification codes assigned to patents based on their technical subject of invention.
source: Tracing the technological development trajectory in post-lithium-ion battery technologies: A patent-based approach

name: Knowledge Interaction
define: The interconnectedness of knowledge areas within a technology domain as indicated by co-occurring patent classification codes.
source: Tracing the technological development trajectory in post-lithium-ion battery technologies: A patent-based approach

name: Link Prediction
define: A method for estimating the likelihood of new emerging links in a network, predicting potential future interactions between knowledge areas.
source: Tracing the technological development trajectory in post-lithium-ion battery technologies: A patent-based approach

name: Application Fields
define: The areas of use for the patented battery technologies, derived from text mining of patent documents.
source: Tracing the technological development trajectory in post-lithium-ion battery technologies: A patent-based approach

name: External Knowledge Usage (EKU)
define: The extent to which a firm uses external knowledge in its innovations, measured by the ratio of external citations to total citations in a firm's patents.
source: Connecting external knowledge usage and firm performance: An empirical analysis

name: Performance
define: Firm's performance, measured by normalized semiconductor sales level in a given year.
source: Connecting external knowledge usage and firm performance: An empirical analysis

name: New Product Market Entry
define: A dummy variable indicating whether a firm entered a new product market where it did not previously participate.
source: Connecting external knowledge usage and firm performance: An empirical analysis

name: Absorptive Capacity (ACAP)
define: The number of countries in which a firm maintained R&D facilities, serving as a proxy for the firm's ability to acquire and apply external knowledge.
source: Connecting external knowledge usage and firm performance: An empirical analysis

name: Previous Performance
define: The sales revenue of a firm in the previous year.
source: Connecting external knowledge usage and firm performance: An empirical analysis

name: Firm Size
define: The natural logarithm of the total number of employees in a firm.
source: Connecting external knowledge usage and firm performance: An empirical analysis

name: Firm Age
define: The number of years since the founding of the firm.
source: Connecting external knowledge usage and firm performance: An empirical analysis

name: Technological Diversification
define: A strategy of expanding a firm's technology base into a wide range of technologies.
source: Technology development strategies and policy support for the solar energy industry under technological turbulence

name: R&D Collaboration
define: An approach that explores broad technological opportunities and quickly responds to environmental changes by accessing external resources.
source: Technology development strategies and policy support for the solar energy industry under technological turbulence

name: Technological Turbulence
define: The degree of volatility, change, and unpredictability related to the technology.
source: Technology development strategies and policy support for the solar energy industry under technological turbulence

name: Firm Performance
define: A measure of how well a firm is performing, often linked to profitability and market share.
source: Technology development strategies and policy support for the solar energy industry under technological turbulence

name: Firm Size
define: The scale of operations of a firm, often measured by total assets or revenue.
source: Technology development strategies and policy support for the solar energy industry under technological turbulence

name: R&D Intensity
define: The proportion of a firm's budget allocated to research and development activities.
source: Technology development strategies and policy support for the solar energy industry under technological turbulence

name: Country of Origin
define: The country where the firm is based, which may influence its technology strategy and performance due to different national innovation systems and policies.
source: Technology development strategies and policy support for the solar energy industry under technological turbulence

name: Enterprise GTFP
define: Green total factor productivity of enterprises, calculated using Super-SBM and GML index methods.
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: Green Innovation
define: Measured by the natural logarithm of the matched green patent grant plus one, including total green patents (Greenpat), green invention patents (Greenpatfm), and green utility patents (Greenpatsy).
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: Technical Gap
define: The gap between the enterprise and state–industry technology frontier, indicating the degree of deviation from potential technological frontiers.
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: Enterprise Characteristics
define: Includes ownership types (state-owned and nonstate-owned) and industry types (heavy-polluting and nonheavy-polluting).
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: GTEC
define: Green technology efficiency, a component of GTFP representing the efficiency changes due to improved production systems, economies of scale, and experience accumulation.
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: GTC
define: Green technology progress, another component of GTFP resulting from efficiency changes because of improved production technology and process innovation.
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: Lncapital
define: Natural logarithm of the total assets of the enterprise.
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: Lnzyyw
define: Natural logarithm of the main business income of the enterprise.
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: Lnzjtr
define: Natural logarithm of intermediate input of the enterprise.
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: Lnage
define: Natural logarithm of the age of the enterprise.
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: Lninnov
define: Natural logarithm of the scientific research of the enterprise.
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: Lnnumbers
define: Natural logarithm of the number of employees of the listed enterprise.
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: Lnzf
define: Natural logarithm of the number of environmental legislations of the city.
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: Lnlf
define: Natural logarithm of the number of environmental administrative law enforcement cases.
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: Lnrdrate
define: Natural logarithm of the ratio of R&D input and total assets.
source: Green innovation and enterprise green total factor productivity at a micro level: A perspective of technical distance

name: Dual Carbon Policy
define: A policy implemented by the Chinese government aiming to achieve carbon peaking and neutrality.
source: The impacts of China’s dual carbon policy on green innovation: Evidence from Chinese heavy-polluting enterprises

name: Green Innovation
define: Innovations that have a positive impact on the sustainability of the environment, including clean production and energy productivity.
source: The impacts of China’s dual carbon policy on green innovation: Evidence from Chinese heavy-polluting enterprises

name: Environmental Tax
define: A tax levied on pollution emissions, which can be a market-based policy instrument to influence corporate behavior.
source: The impacts of China’s dual carbon policy on green innovation: Evidence from Chinese heavy-polluting enterprises

name: Government Subsidies
define: Financial support provided by the government to encourage certain activities, such as green innovation.
source: The impacts of China’s dual carbon policy on green innovation: Evidence from Chinese heavy-polluting enterprises

name: Enterprise Costs
define: The operational costs incurred by enterprises, which can influence their decision to invest in green innovation.
source: The impacts of China’s dual carbon policy on green innovation: Evidence from Chinese heavy-polluting enterprises

name: Carbon Emissions
define: The amount of carbon dioxide released by enterprises, which can be affected by the dual carbon policy and influence green innovation behavior.
source: The impacts of China’s dual carbon policy on green innovation: Evidence from Chinese heavy-polluting enterprises

name: Enterprise Ownership Structure
define: The ownership type of the enterprise, such as state-owned enterprises (SOEs), which may respond differently to policies.
source: The impacts of China’s dual carbon policy on green innovation: Evidence from Chinese heavy-polluting enterprises

name: ESG Ratings
define: Environmental, Social, and Governance ratings that reflect a company's commitment to environmental and social responsibilities.
source: The impacts of China’s dual carbon policy on green innovation: Evidence from Chinese heavy-polluting enterprises

name: Green Patent Type
define: The category of green patents, such as utility or invention patents, which can indicate the level of innovation.
source: The impacts of China’s dual carbon policy on green innovation: Evidence from Chinese heavy-polluting enterprises

name: Electric Vehicles (EVs)
define: A technology that is considered to have the potential to overcome environmental challenges related to conventional automobiles.
source: Strategic intentions to the diffusion of electric mobility paradigm: The case of internal combustion engine vehicle

name: Internal Combustion Engine Vehicles (ICEVs)
define: Conventional vehicles that are currently dominant in the market but face substitution risk from electric vehicles.
source: Strategic intentions to the diffusion of electric mobility paradigm: The case of internal combustion engine vehicle

name: Technological Maturity Status
define: The development stage of a technology, determined through growth curve analysis.
source: Strategic intentions to the diffusion of electric mobility paradigm: The case of internal combustion engine vehicle

name: Strategic Intentions
define: The strategic responses of incumbent firms to the threat of technological substitution, such as 'exit', 'switch', and 'Sailing Ship Effect' (SSE).
source: Strategic intentions to the diffusion of electric mobility paradigm: The case of internal combustion engine vehicle

name: Patent-Based Analysis
define: A method used to examine the pace of technology development and its evolutionary path.
source: Strategic intentions to the diffusion of electric mobility paradigm: The case of internal combustion engine vehicle

name: Mimicry Strategy
define: An alternative strategic response where incumbent firms imitate properties of more successful or new technologies to survive evolutionary pressure.
source: Strategic intentions to the diffusion of electric mobility paradigm: The case of internal combustion engine vehicle

name: Technology Knowledge Stock (TKS)
define: A composite of associated technological knowledge areas, used to analyze changes in strategic reactions.
source: Strategic intentions to the diffusion of electric mobility paradigm: The case of internal combustion engine vehicle

name: Growth Curve Model
define: A model used to forecast technology evolution and determine the technological maturity status and remaining life of patents.
source: Strategic intentions to the diffusion of electric mobility paradigm: The case of internal combustion engine vehicle

name: Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
define: A statistical technique used for dimensionality reduction and to capture the latent technological knowledge stock.
source: Strategic intentions to the diffusion of electric mobility paradigm: The case of internal combustion engine vehicle

name: Hybrid Electric Vehicles (HEVs)
define: Vehicles that integrate an additional electric drivetrain system to power the vehicle, minimizing the use of combustion engine.
source: Strategic intentions to the diffusion of electric mobility paradigm: The case of internal combustion engine vehicle

name: Social Media Engagement
define: A measure of audience interaction, amplification, appreciation, and validation on social media platforms like Twitter.
source: Consumers’ reaction to sci-fi as a source of information for technological development: An empirical analysis

name: Technological Themes
define: The futuristic technological advancements portrayed in sci-fi creative products, such as those in the Black Mirror series.
source: Consumers’ reaction to sci-fi as a source of information for technological development: An empirical analysis

name: Patents Filed
define: The mean number of patents filed per day related to the technological themes presented in sci-fi series.
source: Consumers’ reaction to sci-fi as a source of information for technological development: An empirical analysis

name: Market Uncertainty
define: The uncertainty surrounding market demand, product appeal, and company legitimacy in the context of new and emerging technologies.
source: Consumers’ reaction to sci-fi as a source of information for technological development: An empirical analysis

name: Information Asymmetries
define: The imbalance of information between market participants, particularly regarding the potential and risks of new technologies.
source: Consumers’ reaction to sci-fi as a source of information for technological development: An empirical analysis

name: Generality
define: An index measuring the degree to which a patent has been cited by patents in different technological areas, indicating the breadth of impact of a technology.
source: The role of scientific knowledge within inventing teams and the moderating effects of team internationalization and team experience: Empirical tests into the aerospace sector

name: Scientists
define: The number of inventors within a team that have published at least one scientific article before the patent development, indicating the presence of scientific knowledge within the team.
source: The role of scientific knowledge within inventing teams and the moderating effects of team internationalization and team experience: Empirical tests into the aerospace sector

name: Team Internationalization
define: The number of different countries identified among the inventors of a given patent, reflecting the internationalization of the team.
source: The role of scientific knowledge within inventing teams and the moderating effects of team internationalization and team experience: Empirical tests into the aerospace sector

name: Team Experience
define: The extent to which team members have already worked together, measured by the number of times each pairing of inventors has worked together on a patent prior to the patent under analysis.
source: The role of scientific knowledge within inventing teams and the moderating effects of team internationalization and team experience: Empirical tests into the aerospace sector

name: Team Size
define: The total number of inventors of a single patent.
source: The role of scientific knowledge within inventing teams and the moderating effects of team internationalization and team experience: Empirical tests into the aerospace sector

name: Country Diversity
define: A dummy variable indicating whether the first inventor resides outside the country where the respective company is established.
source: The role of scientific knowledge within inventing teams and the moderating effects of team internationalization and team experience: Empirical tests into the aerospace sector

name: Claims
define: The number of patent claims.
source: The role of scientific knowledge within inventing teams and the moderating effects of team internationalization and team experience: Empirical tests into the aerospace sector

name: Search Span
define: A measure of the diversity of knowledge upon which a patent is based, using the Trajtenberg et al. originality index.
source: The role of scientific knowledge within inventing teams and the moderating effects of team internationalization and team experience: Empirical tests into the aerospace sector

name: Scope
define: The number of different three-digit US classes a patent is assigned to.
source: The role of scientific knowledge within inventing teams and the moderating effects of team internationalization and team experience: Empirical tests into the aerospace sector

name: Cited
define: The number of backward citations a patent has, as a measure of patent novelty.
source: The role of scientific knowledge within inventing teams and the moderating effects of team internationalization and team experience: Empirical tests into the aerospace sector

name: Annual Number of Publications
define: The count of publications, including patents, in a specific year.
source: Empirical analysis of recent temporal dynamics of research fields: Annual publications in chemistry and related areas as an example

name: Chemistry-Related Areas
define: Fields that are related to chemistry and are included in the study.
source: Empirical analysis of recent temporal dynamics of research fields: Annual publications in chemistry and related areas as an example

name: CAplus Database
define: A mono-disciplinary literature database used for the study of publication trends.
source: Empirical analysis of recent temporal dynamics of research fields: Annual publications in chemistry and related areas as an example

name: Optical Phenomena
define: A research area within the field of chemistry that has shown significant growth in publication counts.
source: Empirical analysis of recent temporal dynamics of research fields: Annual publications in chemistry and related areas as an example

name: Electrochemical Technologies
define: Another research area within chemistry that has shown significant growth in publication counts.
source: Empirical analysis of recent temporal dynamics of research fields: Annual publications in chemistry and related areas as an example

name: Publication Trends
define: The identified patterns of increase or decrease in publication counts over the years.
source: Empirical analysis of recent temporal dynamics of research fields: Annual publications in chemistry and related areas as an example

name: Research Fields
define: Specific areas within chemistry that are analyzed for their publication dynamics.
source: Empirical analysis of recent temporal dynamics of research fields: Annual publications in chemistry and related areas as an example

name: Controlled Terms (CTs)
define: Specific terms used in the CAplus database for more detailed classifications within CA sections.
source: Empirical analysis of recent temporal dynamics of research fields: Annual publications in chemistry and related areas as an example

name: Photoluminescence
define: A specific topic within optical phenomena that has shown a dynamic trend in publication counts.
source: Empirical analysis of recent temporal dynamics of research fields: Annual publications in chemistry and related areas as an example

name: Lithium-Ion Secondary Batteries
define: A specific topic within electrochemical technologies that has shown a dynamic trend in publication counts.
source: Empirical analysis of recent temporal dynamics of research fields: Annual publications in chemistry and related areas as an example

name: Environmental Innovation
define: A measure of innovation activities focused on environmental technologies, such as land fertilizers and waste recycling patents.
source: Is green innovation an opportunity or a threat to employment? An empirical analysis of three main industrialized areas: The USA, Japan and Europe

name: Employment
define: The number of employees for the firm i and year t.
source: Is green innovation an opportunity or a threat to employment? An empirical analysis of three main industrialized areas: The USA, Japan and Europe

name: Firm Size
define: A measure of the dimension of the firm, often represented by the number of employees or net sales.
source: Is green innovation an opportunity or a threat to employment? An empirical analysis of three main industrialized areas: The USA, Japan and Europe

name: Net Sales
define: A measure of the firm's market performance and a proxy for the firm's dimension.
source: Is green innovation an opportunity or a threat to employment? An empirical analysis of three main industrialized areas: The USA, Japan and Europe

name: Physical Capital Stock
define: A measure of the firm's physical capital investments.
source: Is green innovation an opportunity or a threat to employment? An empirical analysis of three main industrialized areas: The USA, Japan and Europe

name: Operating Profit
define: A measure of the firm's profitability.
source: Is green innovation an opportunity or a threat to employment? An empirical analysis of three main industrialized areas: The USA, Japan and Europe

name: R&D Capital Stock
define: A measure of the firm's investment in research and development.
source: Is green innovation an opportunity or a threat to employment? An empirical analysis of three main industrialized areas: The USA, Japan and Europe

name: Age of the Firm
define: A measure of the firm's age, calculated as the difference between the foundation year and the current year.
source: Is green innovation an opportunity or a threat to employment? An empirical analysis of three main industrialized areas: The USA, Japan and Europe

name: Environmental Spillovers
define: A measure of the indirect effects of environmental innovation through knowledge spillovers from other firms.
source: Is green innovation an opportunity or a threat to employment? An empirical analysis of three main industrialized areas: The USA, Japan and Europe

name: Firm-specific Uncertainty
define: A measure of unexplained variation in firm-level sales, used as a proxy for firm-specific uncertainty.
source: How to leverage the impact of firm-specific uncertainty on innovation performance? Moderating effects of alliance stage and partner type in the pharmaceutical industry

name: Innovation Performance
define: Assessed through the number of PCT patent applications and new products approved by the FDA.
source: How to leverage the impact of firm-specific uncertainty on innovation performance? Moderating effects of alliance stage and partner type in the pharmaceutical industry

name: Alliance Stage
define: Categorized into 'preclinical research' and 'drug development' stages.
source: How to leverage the impact of firm-specific uncertainty on innovation performance? Moderating effects of alliance stage and partner type in the pharmaceutical industry

name: Partner Type
define: Differentiated between alliances with public organizations and private firms.
source: How to leverage the impact of firm-specific uncertainty on innovation performance? Moderating effects of alliance stage and partner type in the pharmaceutical industry

name: Alliance Activity
define: Measured by the number of new alliances formed in each stage with public and private organizations.
source: How to leverage the impact of firm-specific uncertainty on innovation performance? Moderating effects of alliance stage and partner type in the pharmaceutical industry

name: R&D Intensity
define: Defined as firms’ R&D expenditures as a proportion of total sales.
source: How to leverage the impact of firm-specific uncertainty on innovation performance? Moderating effects of alliance stage and partner type in the pharmaceutical industry

name: Investment
define: The natural logarithm of total investment by the firm.
source: How to leverage the impact of firm-specific uncertainty on innovation performance? Moderating effects of alliance stage and partner type in the pharmaceutical industry

name: Alliance Experience
define: A proxy for transaction costs, measured by the number of prior alliances.
source: How to leverage the impact of firm-specific uncertainty on innovation performance? Moderating effects of alliance stage and partner type in the pharmaceutical industry

name: Non-technological Alliances
define: A control variable representing the number of new non-technological alliances with public and private organizations.
source: How to leverage the impact of firm-specific uncertainty on innovation performance? Moderating effects of alliance stage and partner type in the pharmaceutical industry

name: Expert Disagreement
define: The extent of divergence in the perceptions and opinions of experts which may result from their professional and personal experiences.
source: Improve performance and robustness of knowledge-based FUZZY LOGIC habitat models

name: Fuzzy Sets
define: Linguistic variables with gradual (fuzzy) boundaries rather than discrete (crisp) numeric ones, used as model inputs.
source: Improve performance and robustness of knowledge-based FUZZY LOGIC habitat models

name: Defuzzification Methods
define: Techniques used to transform fuzzy sets into a crisp single numerical output, such as center of gravity or bisector of area.
source: Improve performance and robustness of knowledge-based FUZZY LOGIC habitat models

name: Model Complexity
define: The level of intricacy in the fuzzy logic model, influenced by the number of variables, sets, and rules.
source: Improve performance and robustness of knowledge-based FUZZY LOGIC habitat models

name: Input Variables
define: Variables used in the fuzzy logic model, such as environmental factors or ecological conditions.
source: Improve performance and robustness of knowledge-based FUZZY LOGIC habitat models

name: Model Performance
define: The effectiveness of the fuzzy logic model in accurately predicting or simulating the outcomes.
source: Improve performance and robustness of knowledge-based FUZZY LOGIC habitat models

name: Robustness
define: The ability of the model to provide reliable and consistent results under different conditions or variations.
source: Improve performance and robustness of knowledge-based FUZZY LOGIC habitat models

name: Uncertainty
define: The degree of unpredictability or lack of certainty in the model outputs, influenced by factors like expert disagreement and model complexity.
source: Improve performance and robustness of knowledge-based FUZZY LOGIC habitat models

name: Rule Development
define: The process of creating IF-THEN rules in the fuzzy logic model based on expert knowledge and fuzzy sets.
source: Improve performance and robustness of knowledge-based FUZZY LOGIC habitat models

name: Universe of Discourse
define: The range of possible values that an output variable can take in the fuzzy logic model.
source: Improve performance and robustness of knowledge-based FUZZY LOGIC habitat models

name: Economic Input
define: Indicators such as foreign investment and the number of new enterprises reflecting the economic environment.
source: Understanding Technological Input and Low-Carbon Innovation from Multiple Perspectives: Focusing on Sustainable Building Energy in China

name: Technological Input
define: Variables like the number of VCPE investments representing technological input in economic development.
source: Understanding Technological Input and Low-Carbon Innovation from Multiple Perspectives: Focusing on Sustainable Building Energy in China

name: Low-Carbon Technological Innovation
define: Measured by the number of low-carbon technology patents and the number of authorized trademarks.
source: Understanding Technological Input and Low-Carbon Innovation from Multiple Perspectives: Focusing on Sustainable Building Energy in China

name: Scale of Low-Carbon Technological Innovation
define: The size or extent of low-carbon technological innovation in a city or region.
source: Understanding Technological Input and Low-Carbon Innovation from Multiple Perspectives: Focusing on Sustainable Building Energy in China

name: Industrial Agglomeration
define: The degree of clustering of industries, measured by the number of enterprises in a city.
source: Understanding Technological Input and Low-Carbon Innovation from Multiple Perspectives: Focusing on Sustainable Building Energy in China

name: Building Energy Efficiency (BEE) Innovation
define: Innovations related to building energy efficiency, including patents in this field.
source: Understanding Technological Input and Low-Carbon Innovation from Multiple Perspectives: Focusing on Sustainable Building Energy in China

name: Spatial Evolution
define: The change in the spatial distribution of innovation points over time.
source: Understanding Technological Input and Low-Carbon Innovation from Multiple Perspectives: Focusing on Sustainable Building Energy in China

name: Green Productivity Factors
define: Indicators such as industrial soot emission, wastewater discharge, sulfur dioxide emissions, PM2.5 index, employment quantity, capital stocks, total power consumption, and constant-price GDP.
source: Understanding Technological Input and Low-Carbon Innovation from Multiple Perspectives: Focusing on Sustainable Building Energy in China

name: Moran’s I
define: A statistic used to measure the spatial autocorrelation of a variable.
source: Understanding Technological Input and Low-Carbon Innovation from Multiple Perspectives: Focusing on Sustainable Building Energy in China

name: Kernel Density
define: A nonparametric estimation method used to explore the time distribution trend of BEE innovation efficiency.
source: Understanding Technological Input and Low-Carbon Innovation from Multiple Perspectives: Focusing on Sustainable Building Energy in China

name: Geographic Concentration Index
define: An index used to calculate the spatial clustering degree of innovation points.
source: Understanding Technological Input and Low-Carbon Innovation from Multiple Perspectives: Focusing on Sustainable Building Energy in China

name: Social Status
define: A variable representing the prestige accorded to actors due to their social positions.
source: Outbound open innovation in bio-pharmaceutical out-licensing

name: Out-licensing Deals
define: A count variable representing the total number of out-licensing deals secured by each firm in a given year.
source: Outbound open innovation in bio-pharmaceutical out-licensing

name: Commercial Alliances
define: A variable representing the cumulative count of a firm's announced commercial alliances.
source: Outbound open innovation in bio-pharmaceutical out-licensing

name: Co-authoring Partners
define: A variable representing the cumulative total number of co-authoring institutions with which a firm publishes scientific papers each year.
source: Outbound open innovation in bio-pharmaceutical out-licensing

name: R&D Portfolio
define: A variable representing the number of R&D projects owned by a firm each year.
source: Outbound open innovation in bio-pharmaceutical out-licensing

name: Patents
define: A control variable representing the number of patents held by a firm.
source: Outbound open innovation in bio-pharmaceutical out-licensing

name: Patent Authors
define: A control variable representing the number of patent authors for a firm each year.
source: Outbound open innovation in bio-pharmaceutical out-licensing

name: Technological Breadth
define: A control variable representing the heterogeneity of a firm's patent portfolio.
source: Outbound open innovation in bio-pharmaceutical out-licensing

name: In-licensing Deals
define: A control variable representing the yearly non-cumulative number of in-licensing deals of a firm.
source: Outbound open innovation in bio-pharmaceutical out-licensing

name: Failed Projects
define: A control variable representing the cumulative number of ceased projects owned by a firm each year.
source: Outbound open innovation in bio-pharmaceutical out-licensing

name: Knowledge Stocks
define: Includes R&D, education levels, and agglomeration effects within a city.
source: Research on urban economic centrality in the perspectives of knowledge stocks and flows

name: Knowledge Flows
define: Inter-city knowledge flows measured by patent transfers.
source: Research on urban economic centrality in the perspectives of knowledge stocks and flows

name: Urban Economic Centrality
define: Includes dimensions of agglomeration centrality, diffusion centrality, power centrality, and integrated centrality.
source: Research on urban economic centrality in the perspectives of knowledge stocks and flows

name: Specialized Knowledge Structure
define: The degree of specialization within a city's knowledge structure.
source: Research on urban economic centrality in the perspectives of knowledge stocks and flows

name: Diversified Knowledge Structure
define: The degree of diversification within a city's knowledge structure.
source: Research on urban economic centrality in the perspectives of knowledge stocks and flows

name: Face-to-Face Communication
define: A communication channel that facilitates the exchange of diversified knowledge.
source: Research on urban economic centrality in the perspectives of knowledge stocks and flows

name: Telecommunication
define: A communication channel that facilitates the exchange of specialized knowledge.
source: Research on urban economic centrality in the perspectives of knowledge stocks and flows

name: Political Factor
define: A control variable representing the political status of a city.
source: Research on urban economic centrality in the perspectives of knowledge stocks and flows

name: Historical Factor
define: A control variable representing the historical economic status of a city, measured by GDP in 2007.
source: Research on urban economic centrality in the perspectives of knowledge stocks and flows

name: Feed-in Tariffs (FITs)
define: Market-based economic instruments that offer long-term contracts guaranteeing a price to renewable energy producers.
source: Energy Policy 172 (2023) 113319

name: Public R&D Stock and Flow
define: Government expenditure on solar R&D in million USD, representing both the stock and flow of public solar R&D spending.
source: Energy Policy 172 (2023) 113319

name: Environmental Tax
define: Tax revenue as a percent of GDP, intended to correct market imperfections and negative externalities such as emissions.
source: Energy Policy 172 (2023) 113319

name: Environmental Policy Stringency Index
define: An index combining quantitative and qualitative factors related to environmental laws and regulations, ranging from 0 (not stringent) to 6 (highest degree of stringency).
source: Energy Policy 172 (2023) 113319

name: Patents Granted
define: The number of granted PV patents, used as a proxy for inventions in the solar photovoltaic sector.
source: Energy Policy 172 (2023) 113319

name: Cumulative Capacity
define: Installed electricity production capacities for PV, representing the existing generation capacity in a country.
source: Energy Policy 172 (2023) 113319

name: Human Capital
define: Total researchers per thousand in employment, capturing human capital input in knowledge creation and technology diffusion.
source: Energy Policy 172 (2023) 113319

name: Polysilicon Price
define: The price of polysilicon, an important input in a PV cell, which affects invention and diffusion due to its influence on cost reduction efforts.
source: Energy Policy 172 (2023) 113319

name: Brent Oil Price
define: The price of Brent oil, an alternative energy source, which may influence the implementation of other energy sources including solar PV.
source: Energy Policy 172 (2023) 113319

name: GDP
define: Gross Domestic Product, which may influence the capacity of a country to invest in and support the development and diffusion of solar PV technology.
source: Energy Policy 172 (2023) 113319

name: Population
define: The total population of a country, which may affect the demand for energy and the potential for solar PV diffusion.
source: Energy Policy 172 (2023) 113319

name: Technology's Value
define: A variable representing the value of the patented technology, with more valuable technology being more likely to be upheld in court.
source: Licensing and information disclosure under asymmetric information

name: Information Disclosure
define: A variable representing the extent to which an innovator discloses private information about their technology.
source: Licensing and information disclosure under asymmetric information

name: Investment Timing
define: A variable representing when an innovator chooses to invest in R&D.
source: Licensing and information disclosure under asymmetric information

name: Bargaining Power
define: A variable representing the relative power in negotiations between the upstream and downstream firms.
source: Licensing and information disclosure under asymmetric information

name: Rival's Challenge
define: A variable representing the potential for a competitor to challenge the patented technology.
source: Licensing and information disclosure under asymmetric information

name: Royalties
define: A variable representing the payment made by the downstream firm to the upstream firm for the use of the technology.
source: Licensing and information disclosure under asymmetric information

name: Investment Costs
define: A variable representing the costs associated with making an R&D investment.
source: Licensing and information disclosure under asymmetric information

name: Demand Shock
define: A variable representing changes in market demand that can affect the value of the technology and the timing of investment decisions.
source: Licensing and information disclosure under asymmetric information

name: Legal Probability
define: A variable representing the probability that the patent holder wins a legal challenge, which is linked to the technology's true novelty.
source: Licensing and information disclosure under asymmetric information

name: Follower's Technology
define: A variable representing the technology developed by the follower, which can affect the leader's investment decision and licensing agreements.
source: Licensing and information disclosure under asymmetric information

name: Ecological Footprint
define: Measured in global hectares (gha) per person, indicating the biologically productive area required to support human activities.
source: Do natural resource dependence, economic growth and transport energy consumption accelerate ecological footprint in the most innovative countries? The moderating role of technological innovation

name: GDP per capita
define: Representing the economic output per person, adjusted for purchasing power parity.
source: Do natural resource dependence, economic growth and transport energy consumption accelerate ecological footprint in the most innovative countries? The moderating role of technological innovation

name: Transport Energy Consumption
define: Energy use for transport in gigajoule (GJ) per capita, representing the energy consumed by the transport sector.
source: Do natural resource dependence, economic growth and transport energy consumption accelerate ecological footprint in the most innovative countries? The moderating role of technological innovation

name: Natural Resource Dependence
define: Total natural resources rents as a percentage of GDP, indicating the reliance on natural resources for economic activity.
source: Do natural resource dependence, economic growth and transport energy consumption accelerate ecological footprint in the most innovative countries? The moderating role of technological innovation

name: Technological Innovation
define: Measured by patent applications and research, development, and demonstration budget as proxies for innovation activities.
source: Do natural resource dependence, economic growth and transport energy consumption accelerate ecological footprint in the most innovative countries? The moderating role of technological innovation

name: Technological Innovation
define: A variable representing the implementation of new or significantly improved products and processes in a firm.
source: New approach to the innovation process in emerging economies: The manufacturing sector case in Chile and Peru

name: Non-technological Innovation
define: A variable representing the implementation of new or significantly improved marketing and organizational innovations in a firm.

name: Innovation Resources
define: A variable representing the resources dedicated to innovation activities, such as R&D and human capital.

name: Cooperation
define: A variable representing the relationships with suppliers, customers, competitors, universities, and research institutes for innovation purposes.

name: Information Sources
define: A variable representing the use of external information sources like conferences, scientific magazines, and patent databases.

name: Institutional Factors
define: A variable representing the influence of public programs and support systems on innovation activities.

name: Industry Effect
define: A variable representing the impact of market structure and competition on innovation.
source: New approach to the innovation process in emerging economies: The manufacturing sector case in Chile and Peru

name: Financial Barriers
define: A variable representing the perception of financial constraints as obstacles to innovation.

name: Firm Size
define: A categorical variable representing the size of the firm, which can influence the innovation process.
source: New approach to the innovation process in emerging economies: The manufacturing sector case in Chile and Peru

name: Type of Industry
define: A categorical variable representing whether the firm belongs to the metallic or non-metallic sector.

name: PV_PAT
define: The number of PV patent applications, used as a proxy for PV technology innovation.

name: Environmental Policy Stringency
define: A composite index representing the strictness of a country's environmental policies, including both market-based and non-market-based instruments.

name: Green Innovation
define: Measured by the number of patents in renewable energy generation-related technologies.

name: Renewable Energy Types
define: Categorized into wind, solar, marine, geothermal, and hydro energy.

name: Innovation Capacity
define: A dummy variable indicating countries with stronger innovation capacity.

name: Environmental Pressure
define: Measured by CO2 emissions, representing the environmental pressure faced by countries.

name: Clean Energy Investment
define: Measured by the installed capacities for solar, wind, and geothermal energy.

name: Foreign Direct Investment
define: The ratio of net foreign direct investment to GDP.

name: Economic Development

name: Population Density
define: Measured by population per square kilometer of land area.

name: Education Level
define: Measured by the gross secondary school enrollment rate.

name: Trade
define: The proportion of trade activities to GDP.

name: Income Inequality
define: Measured by the income share of the top 10% people.

name: Renewable Energy Consumption
define: The share of renewable energy consumption in total energy consumption.

name: Technological Capability Accumulation
define: A measure of the levels of technological capability a firm has accumulated over time, including production and innovation capabilities.

name: External Learning Mechanisms
define: Actions taken by firms to identify and acquire knowledge and skills from external sources, such as partnerships with universities, suppliers, and competitors.
source: Intricacies of firm-level innovation performance: An empirical analysis of latecomer process industries

name: Internal Learning Mechanisms
define: Intra-firm efforts toward creating, sharing, integrating, and codifying knowledge, including knowledge creation, sharing, integration, and codification.

name: Innovative Activities
define: The range of activities undertaken by firms to innovate, including non-R&D and R&D-related activities, and their implementation.
source: Intricacies of firm-level innovation performance: An empirical analysis of latecomer process industries

name: Labour Productivity
define: A measure of the economic efficiency of labor in production, calculated as gross sales revenue divided by the number of direct workers.
source: Intricacies of firm-level innovation performance: An empirical analysis of latecomer process industries

name: Proportion of Exports to Revenue
define: The percentage of a firm's total revenue derived from exports.
source: Intricacies of firm-level innovation performance: An empirical analysis of latecomer process industries

name: Firm Size
define: The number of direct workers in a firm, used as a control variable.
source: Intricacies of firm-level innovation performance: An empirical analysis of latecomer process industries

name: Capital Origin
define: The origin of the firm's capital, whether national or international, used as a control variable.
source: Intricacies of firm-level innovation performance: An empirical analysis of latecomer process industries

name: Sector
define: The industry sector in which the firm operates, with dummies for petroleum, mining, steel, pulp and paper, and ethanol.
source: Intricacies of firm-level innovation performance: An empirical analysis of latecomer process industries

name: Time
define: Time dummies used as control variables in the study.
source: Intricacies of firm-level innovation performance: An empirical analysis of latecomer process industries

name: Innovative Capabilities
define: A scale of capability levels for a wide range of technological activities.
source: Beyond technological catch-up: An empirical investigation of further innovative capability accumulation outcomes in latecomer firms with evidence from Brazil

name: Technological Catch-up
define: The process of latecomer firms narrowing the gap with global industry leaders in technology.
source: Beyond technological catch-up: An empirical investigation of further innovative capability accumulation outcomes in latecomer firms with evidence from Brazil

name: Innovative Performance
define: Implemented inventive and innovative activities, measured by patents and innovative activities in forestry and pulp and paper production.
source: Beyond technological catch-up: An empirical investigation of further innovative capability accumulation outcomes in latecomer firms with evidence from Brazil

name: Operational and Environmental-related Performance Improvement
define: Technical performance parameters related to pulp and paper firms derived from forestry.
source: Beyond technological catch-up: An empirical investigation of further innovative capability accumulation outcomes in latecomer firms with evidence from Brazil

name: Corporate Growth Patterns
define: Patterns such as horizontal integration, vertical integration, merger/acquisition, and diversification.
source: Beyond technological catch-up: An empirical investigation of further innovative capability accumulation outcomes in latecomer firms with evidence from Brazil

name: R&D Expenditures
define: A measure often used to proxy a firm's innovative capabilities.
source: Beyond technological catch-up: An empirical investigation of further innovative capability accumulation outcomes in latecomer firms with evidence from Brazil

name: Patenting Activities
define: The act of securing patents, often associated with innovative capabilities.
source: Beyond technological catch-up: An empirical investigation of further innovative capability accumulation outcomes in latecomer firms with evidence from Brazil

name: Product Innovation
define: The development of new or significantly improved products.
source: Beyond technological catch-up: An empirical investigation of further innovative capability accumulation outcomes in latecomer firms with evidence from Brazil

name: Firm-specific Factors
define: Factors such as age, size, and leadership that may influence a firm's capabilities.
source: Beyond technological catch-up: An empirical investigation of further innovative capability accumulation outcomes in latecomer firms with evidence from Brazil

name: Industry-specific Factors
define: Factors related to the specific industry in which the firm operates.
source: Beyond technological catch-up: An empirical investigation of further innovative capability accumulation outcomes in latecomer firms with evidence from Brazil

name: Economy-wide Conditions
define: Macro-economic conditions that can affect a firm's performance and capabilities.
source: Beyond technological catch-up: An empirical investigation of further innovative capability accumulation outcomes in latecomer firms with evidence from Brazil

name: Public Funds
define: Financial investments from government sources aimed at promoting innovation in high-tech industries.
source: Public funds in high-tech industries: A blessing or a curse

name: Private Funds
define: Financial investments from non-government, private sources targeted towards high-tech industries.
source: Public funds in high-tech industries: A blessing or a curse

name: Innovation Performance
define: The effectiveness of innovative activities, measured through the development of patents and new products.
source: Public funds in high-tech industries: A blessing or a curse

name: Public_share
define: The proportion of public funds in the total financial investments in high-tech industries.
source: Public funds in high-tech industries: A blessing or a curse

name: Industry-specific Characteristics
define: Distinct features of mature and immature high-tech industries that may influence the interaction between public and private funds.
source: Public funds in high-tech industries: A blessing or a curse

name: Regional Heterogeneity
define: Diversity across regions in terms of economic development and innovation capacity.
source: Public funds in high-tech industries: A blessing or a curse

name: R&D Stage
define: The research and development phase of innovation where public and private funds may have complementary effects.
source: Public funds in high-tech industries: A blessing or a curse

name: Application Stage
define: The stage of applying and commercializing innovation outputs where public and private funds may conflict.
source: Public funds in high-tech industries: A blessing or a curse

name: Base
define: A control variable representing the pre-existing knowledge base and industrial capacity in a region.
source: Public funds in high-tech industries: A blessing or a curse

name: GDP
define: A control variable for regional economic development, which may influence a region's capability to innovate.
source: Public funds in high-tech industries: A blessing or a curse

name: Human Capital (HC)
define: A measure of the quality of human capital, such as the number of college graduates, which is important for innovation.
source: Public funds in high-tech industries: A blessing or a curse

name: Foreign Direct Investment (FDI)
define: A control variable indicating the amount of FDI in a region, which may contribute to R&D but have a minor role in new product development.
source: Public funds in high-tech industries: A blessing or a curse

name: Willingness to Pay (WTP)
define: A variable representing consumers' readiness to pay for new and remanufactured products.
source: Analysis for recycling and remanufacturing strategies in a supply chain considering consumers’ heterogeneous WTP

name: Remanufacturing Mode
define: A categorical variable representing different remanufacturing strategies such as single-agent remanufacturing, hybrid remanufacturing, and no remanufacturing.
source: Analysis for recycling and remanufacturing strategies in a supply chain considering consumers’ heterogeneous WTP

name: Recycling Rate
define: A variable representing the proportion of used products collected for remanufacturing.
source: Analysis for recycling and remanufacturing strategies in a supply chain considering consumers’ heterogeneous WTP

name: Sales Price
define: A variable representing the price at which new and remanufactured products are sold.
source: Analysis for recycling and remanufacturing strategies in a supply chain considering consumers’ heterogeneous WTP

name: Sales Quantities
define: Variables representing the number of new and remanufactured products sold.
source: Analysis for recycling and remanufacturing strategies in a supply chain considering consumers’ heterogeneous WTP

name: Wholesale Price
define: A variable representing the price at which new products are offered to distributors by the manufacturer.
source: Analysis for recycling and remanufacturing strategies in a supply chain considering consumers’ heterogeneous WTP

name: Production Cost
define: A variable representing the cost of producing new and remanufactured products.
source: Analysis for recycling and remanufacturing strategies in a supply chain considering consumers’ heterogeneous WTP

name: Licensing Fee
define: A variable representing the fee charged by the manufacturer for licensing distributors to remanufacture.
source: Analysis for recycling and remanufacturing strategies in a supply chain considering consumers’ heterogeneous WTP

name: Profits
define: Variables representing the profits of the manufacturer, distributor, and third-party remanufacturer.
source: Analysis for recycling and remanufacturing strategies in a supply chain considering consumers’ heterogeneous WTP

name: Consumer Surplus
define: A variable representing the benefit received by consumers from purchasing products.
