source: Analysis for recycling and remanufacturing strategies in a supply chain considering consumers’ heterogeneous WTP

name: Patent Licensing
define: A binary variable indicating whether a manufacturer uses patent licensing as a strategy in the remanufacturing supply chain.
source: Analysis for recycling and remanufacturing strategies in a supply chain considering consumers’ heterogeneous WTP

name: Co-patent Intensity
define: A measure of co-patenting as a percentage of total patenting, indicating the extent of collaboration in patenting activities.
source: Co-patent, financing constraints, and innovation in SMEs: An empirical analysis using market value panel data of listed firms

name: Firm Market Value
define: The value of the firm in the capital market, computed by dividing the market value of a firm's equity by the book value of its total assets.
source: Co-patent, financing constraints, and innovation in SMEs: An empirical analysis using market value panel data of listed firms

name: Government Subsidies
define: Financial support provided by the government, extracted from the annual report under the item government grants for technological development.
source: Co-patent, financing constraints, and innovation in SMEs: An empirical analysis using market value panel data of listed firms

name: Supplier's Trade Credit
define: A source of external financing for firms, collected under the item account payable in the annual balance sheet.
source: Co-patent, financing constraints, and innovation in SMEs: An empirical analysis using market value panel data of listed firms

name: R&D Intensity
define: A measure of a firm's investment in research and development, calculated as R&D expenditures divided by total assets.
source: Co-patent, financing constraints, and innovation in SMEs: An empirical analysis using market value panel data of listed firms

name: Resource Slack
define: A measure of a firm's current assets relative to current liabilities, indicating the availability of slack resources.
source: Co-patent, financing constraints, and innovation in SMEs: An empirical analysis using market value panel data of listed firms

name: Firm Size
define: The size of the firm, controlled using the number of employees (in log).
source: Co-patent, financing constraints, and innovation in SMEs: An empirical analysis using market value panel data of listed firms

name: Market Development
define: An index reflecting the extent to which provincial resources are allocated by markets rather than through the redistribution system of the Chinese government.
source: Co-patent, financing constraints, and innovation in SMEs: An empirical analysis using market value panel data of listed firms

name: R&D Investment (rdspend)
define: Measured by the proportion of R&D investment to business revenue, indicating the R&D investment of a firm.
source: The Impact of Financing Constraints and Uncertainty on Manufacturing Innovation Efficiency: An Empirical Analysis from Chinese Listed Firms

name: R&D Personnel Ratio (rdperson)
define: The percentage of R&D personnel in a firm, indicating the firm's inclination towards R&D activities.
source: The Impact of Financing Constraints and Uncertainty on Manufacturing Innovation Efficiency: An Empirical Analysis from Chinese Listed Firms

name: Internal Financing (cf)
define: Measured using cash flow, reflecting the firm's ability to finance from internal sources.
source: The Impact of Financing Constraints and Uncertainty on Manufacturing Innovation Efficiency: An Empirical Analysis from Chinese Listed Firms

name: Commercial Credit Financing (business)
define: Measured using net accounts receivable as a percentage of total assets, indicating the firm's reliance on commercial credit for financing.
source: The Impact of Financing Constraints and Uncertainty on Manufacturing Innovation Efficiency: An Empirical Analysis from Chinese Listed Firms

name: External Financing (onpm)
define: Measured using the increase in the sum of equity and capital stock as a percentage of total assets, reflecting the firm's external financing efforts.
source: The Impact of Financing Constraints and Uncertainty on Manufacturing Innovation Efficiency: An Empirical Analysis from Chinese Listed Firms

name: Firm Size (size)
define: Measured using the logarithm of total assets, indicating the scale of the firm which can affect its financing capabilities.
source: The Impact of Financing Constraints and Uncertainty on Manufacturing Innovation Efficiency: An Empirical Analysis from Chinese Listed Firms

name: Overall Innovation Efficiency (efficiency)
define: Measured using the total number of patents granted, reflecting the firm's overall innovation output.
source: The Impact of Financing Constraints and Uncertainty on Manufacturing Innovation Efficiency: An Empirical Analysis from Chinese Listed Firms

name: Innovation Quality Efficiency (efficiency1)
define: Measured using the number of invention patents granted, reflecting the quality of the firm's innovation activities.
source: The Impact of Financing Constraints and Uncertainty on Manufacturing Innovation Efficiency: An Empirical Analysis from Chinese Listed Firms

name: Innovation Quantity Efficiency (efficiency2, efficiency3)
define: Measured using the number of utility and design patents granted, reflecting the quantity of the firm's innovation activities.
source: The Impact of Financing Constraints and Uncertainty on Manufacturing Innovation Efficiency: An Empirical Analysis from Chinese Listed Firms

name: Competence Set
define: A group of skills and knowledge areas that can be adopted to solve a specific problem.
source: A Fuzzy-MOP-Based Competence Set Expansion Method for Technology Roadmap Definitions

name: Technology Roadmap
define: An overview of science and technology plans in the form of maps, linking technology and products with market opportunities.
source: A Fuzzy-MOP-Based Competence Set Expansion Method for Technology Roadmap Definitions

name: Fuzzy Multiple Objective Programming (FMOP)
define: A mathematical programming method used to solve problems with multiple objectives and uncertainties.
source: A Fuzzy-MOP-Based Competence Set Expansion Method for Technology Roadmap Definitions

name: Silicon Intellectual Properties (SIPs)
define: Intellectual properties related to silicon technology, used as an example in the empirical study.
source: A Fuzzy-MOP-Based Competence Set Expansion Method for Technology Roadmap Definitions

name: Research and Development (R&D)
define: Activities aimed at expanding the competence set and achieving strategic objectives.
source: A Fuzzy-MOP-Based Competence Set Expansion Method for Technology Roadmap Definitions

name: Membership Functions
define: Functions used in fuzzy set theory to define the degree of membership of an element in a set.
source: A Fuzzy-MOP-Based Competence Set Expansion Method for Technology Roadmap Definitions

name: Habitual Domains
define: A concept that influences people's behaviors and decision-making processes, consisting of potential domains, actual domains, activation propensity, and reachable domains.
source: A Fuzzy-MOP-Based Competence Set Expansion Method for Technology Roadmap Definitions

name: Modified Delphi Method
define: A method used to reach consensus among experts by reviewing and selecting questionnaires based on literature review or experts' opinions.
source: A Fuzzy-MOP-Based Competence Set Expansion Method for Technology Roadmap Definitions

name: Time Variant Competence Set
define: A competence set that changes over time due to the acquisition of new skills, resources, information, or situations.
source: A Fuzzy-MOP-Based Competence Set Expansion Method for Technology Roadmap Definitions

name: Changeable Space
define: A concept suggesting that parameters in real-world decision-making problems can be variable over time.
source: A Fuzzy-MOP-Based Competence Set Expansion Method for Technology Roadmap Definitions

name: Innovation Agents
define: A category that includes central enterprises, other domestic enterprises, universities and scientific research institutes, troops, individuals and other organizations, and foreign-funded enterprises.
source: Technology Spillovers among Innovation Agents from the Perspective of Network Connectedness

name: Technology Spillover Connectedness
define: A measure of the direction and intensity of technology spillover between different innovation agents.
source: Technology Spillovers among Innovation Agents from the Perspective of Network Connectedness

name: Economic Policy Uncertainty
define: A measure reflecting the uncertainty in economic policies, which may affect innovation and technology spillover.
source: Technology Spillovers among Innovation Agents from the Perspective of Network Connectedness

name: Invention Patents
define: A form of intellectual property rights used to measure the output of innovation.
source: Technology Spillovers among Innovation Agents from the Perspective of Network Connectedness

name: Foreign-Funded Enterprises
define: A subcategory of innovation agents that can be further divided based on their source countries or regions.
source: Technology Spillovers among Innovation Agents from the Perspective of Network Connectedness

name: Domestic Enterprises
define: Innovation agents that are not foreign-funded and can be further divided into central enterprises and other domestic enterprises.
source: Technology Spillovers among Innovation Agents from the Perspective of Network Connectedness

name: Universities and Scientific Research Institutes
define: Innovation agents that contribute to technology spillover through research and development activities.
source: Technology Spillovers among Innovation Agents from the Perspective of Network Connectedness

name: Troops
define: A specific category of innovation agents that may have a role in technology spillover.
source: Technology Spillovers among Innovation Agents from the Perspective of Network Connectedness

name: Individuals and Other Organizations
define: A category of innovation agents that includes individuals and organizations not classified elsewhere.
source: Technology Spillovers among Innovation Agents from the Perspective of Network Connectedness

name: R&D Investment
define: The investment made by innovation agents in research and development activities, which can influence technology spillover.
source: Technology Spillovers among Innovation Agents from the Perspective of Network Connectedness

name: Innovation Inputs
define: Includes Research and Development (R&D) expenditures and Human Capital.
source: Measuring efficiency of innovation using combined Data Envelopment Analysis and Structural Equation Modeling: empirical study in EU regions

name: Innovation Outputs
define: Includes PATTPS (knowledge transferred due to technological proximity) and PATGPS (knowledge transferred due to geographical proximity).
source: Measuring efficiency of innovation using combined Data Envelopment Analysis and Structural Equation Modeling: empirical study in EU regions

name: Innovation Efficiency
define: Derived by relating innovation inputs and innovation outputs, measured using Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA).
source: Measuring efficiency of innovation using combined Data Envelopment Analysis and Structural Equation Modeling: empirical study in EU regions

name: Patent Applications
define: A measure of regional innovative activity.
source: Measuring efficiency of innovation using combined Data Envelopment Analysis and Structural Equation Modeling: empirical study in EU regions

name: Employment Level
define: A measure of regional economic performance.
source: Measuring efficiency of innovation using combined Data Envelopment Analysis and Structural Equation Modeling: empirical study in EU regions

name: Development Level
define: A categorical variable representing the regional economic status in terms of per capita GDP.
source: Measuring efficiency of innovation using combined Data Envelopment Analysis and Structural Equation Modeling: empirical study in EU regions

name: Degree of Technological Diversity
define: Measured by the Normalized Shannon’s Entropy Index (NEI), indicating the diversity of regional innovative activity across technological fields.
source: Measuring efficiency of innovation using combined Data Envelopment Analysis and Structural Equation Modeling: empirical study in EU regions

name: Regional Effects
define: A latent variable formed by the regional level of patent applications and employment level.
source: Measuring efficiency of innovation using combined Data Envelopment Analysis and Structural Equation Modeling: empirical study in EU regions

name: Technology Complementarity
define: A measure of the overlap of patents in the same subcategory but in different classes, indicating the degree to which firms' technical problem-solving focuses on different narrowly defined technology fields within a broadly defined technology field.
source: Measuring Technology Complementarity Between Enterprises With an hLDA Topic Model

name: hLDA Topic Model
define: A hierarchical latent Dirichlet allocation topic model that mines different technological topics in a document and the hierarchical structures between topics.
source: Measuring Technology Complementarity Between Enterprises With an hLDA Topic Model

name: Patent Documents
define: Documents used as a carrier of enterprise innovations, from which salient information is explored and extracted through machine learning techniques.
source: Measuring Technology Complementarity Between Enterprises With an hLDA Topic Model

name: Technical Experts
define: Individuals who provided guidance on the credibility of the results and helped in determining the specific technology in each topic based on related terms.
source: Measuring Technology Complementarity Between Enterprises With an hLDA Topic Model

name: Innovation Activities
define: Activities that involve the integration of multidisciplinary technologies and are influenced by the technology complementarity between enterprises.
source: Measuring Technology Complementarity Between Enterprises With an hLDA Topic Model

name: Strategic Decisions
define: Decisions made by enterprises regarding which partners to collaborate with, which can be influenced by the measurement of technology complementarity.
source: Measuring Technology Complementarity Between Enterprises With an hLDA Topic Model

name: Patent Classification Codes
define: A method currently used to measure technology complementarity, which is based on patent classification systems but does not precisely reflect specific technologies.
source: Measuring Technology Complementarity Between Enterprises With an hLDA Topic Model

name: Enterprise–Topic Matrix
define: A matrix that shows the topics in each level that each enterprise covers, used to calculate the technology complementarity between enterprises.
source: Measuring Technology Complementarity Between Enterprises With an hLDA Topic Model

name: Technology Complementarity Matrix
define: A matrix derived from the enterprise–topic matrix, indicating the complementarity between enterprises in terms of their patent portfolios.
source: Measuring Technology Complementarity Between Enterprises With an hLDA Topic Model

name: Hyperparameters
define: Parameters in the hLDA model that determine the size and shape of the topic tree and influence the quality of the clustering results.
source: Measuring Technology Complementarity Between Enterprises With an hLDA Topic Model

name: Market Exclusivity Incentives
define: A policy tool used to promote drug development by providing a temporary monopoly for the developer.
source: An Empirical Review of Major Legislation Affecting Drug Development: Past Experiences, Effects, and Unintended Consequences

name: Legislative Programs
define: Specific laws and acts mentioned in the paper, including the Bayh-Dole Act, the Orphan Drug Act, the Hatch-Waxman Act, and the pediatric exclusivity provisions of the FDA Modernization Act.
source: An Empirical Review of Major Legislation Affecting Drug Development: Past Experiences, Effects, and Unintended Consequences

name: Public Health Outcomes
define: The impact of legislative programs on the health of the public, including the availability and affordability of drugs.
source: An Empirical Review of Major Legislation Affecting Drug Development: Past Experiences, Effects, and Unintended Consequences

name: Drug Development
define: The process of creating and testing new drugs, including the involvement of academic and private sector research.
source: An Empirical Review of Major Legislation Affecting Drug Development: Past Experiences, Effects, and Unintended Consequences

name: Innovation
define: The creation of new drugs or治疗方法, including those for rare diseases or tropical diseases.
source: An Empirical Review of Major Legislation Affecting Drug Development: Past Experiences, Effects, and Unintended Consequences

name: Patents
define: Legal protections granted for inventions, which can impact the development and commercialization of drugs.
source: An Empirical Review of Major Legislation Affecting Drug Development: Past Experiences, Effects, and Unintended Consequences

name: Generic Drugs
define: Non-brand name drugs that are marketed after the patent protection of the original drug has expired.
source: An Empirical Review of Major Legislation Affecting Drug Development: Past Experiences, Effects, and Unintended Consequences

name: Research and Development (R&D)
define: The process of creating new drugs, which requires substantial investment and can be influenced by legislative incentives.
source: An Empirical Review of Major Legislation Affecting Drug Development: Past Experiences, Effects, and Unintended Consequences

name: Regulatory Review
define: The process by which regulatory agencies like the FDA evaluate new drugs for safety and efficacy.
source: An Empirical Review of Major Legislation Affecting Drug Development: Past Experiences, Effects, and Unintended Consequences

name: Intellectual Property Rights
define: Rights granted to creators of new products, including drugs, which can affect the commercialization and diffusion of innovations.
source: An Empirical Review of Major Legislation Affecting Drug Development: Past Experiences, Effects, and Unintended Consequences

name: Green Innovation
define: A variable that measures the adoption of environmentally friendly processes and products.
source: Evaluating green innovation and performance of financial development: mediating concerns of environmental regulation

name: Financial Development
define: A variable that includes aspects such as the availability of credit, the size of the financial sector, and the performance of financial institutions.
source: Evaluating green innovation and performance of financial development: mediating concerns of environmental regulation

name: Environmental Regulation
define: A variable that encompasses policies and initiatives aimed at protecting the environment.
source: Evaluating green innovation and performance of financial development: mediating concerns of environmental regulation

name: Economic Growth
define: A variable that measures the increase in a region's economic output over time.
source: Evaluating green innovation and performance of financial development: mediating concerns of environmental regulation

name: Human Capital
define: A variable that represents the education and skill level of the workforce.
source: Evaluating green innovation and performance of financial development: mediating concerns of environmental regulation

name: Research and Development (R&D)
define: A variable that measures the investment in research and development activities.
source: Evaluating green innovation and performance of financial development: mediating concerns of environmental regulation

name: Green Financing
define: A variable that refers to financial services that support environmentally friendly projects and technologies.
source: Evaluating green innovation and performance of financial development: mediating concerns of environmental regulation

name: Renewable Energy Investment
define: A variable that measures the investment in renewable energy projects.
source: Evaluating green innovation and performance of financial development: mediating concerns of environmental regulation

name: Emissions
define: A variable that represents the release of pollutants, particularly greenhouse gases, into the environment.
source: Evaluating green innovation and performance of financial development: mediating concerns of environmental regulation

name: Technological Progress
define: A variable that measures the advancement in technology and its application in various sectors.
source: Evaluating green innovation and performance of financial development: mediating concerns of environmental regulation

name: Innovation Efficiency
define: A measure of how well countries perform in terms of innovation, taking into account their inputs and outputs.
source: The effect of national culture on countries’ innovation efficiency

name: Power Distance Index (PDI)
define: A cultural dimension representing the extent to which less powerful members of a society accept power is distributed unequally.
source: The effect of national culture on countries’ innovation efficiency

name: Individualism (IDV)
define: A cultural dimension representing the degree to which individuals are integrated into collective groups.
source: The effect of national culture on countries’ innovation efficiency

name: Masculinity (MAS)
define: A cultural dimension representing the distinction between traditional male and female roles in society.
source: The effect of national culture on countries’ innovation efficiency

name: Uncertainty Avoidance Index (UAI)
define: A cultural dimension representing the extent to which members of a culture feel threatened by uncertain or unknown situations.
source: The effect of national culture on countries’ innovation efficiency

name: Innovation Inputs
define: Composite indexes including innovation drivers, knowledge creation, and innovation & entrepreneurship.
source: The effect of national culture on countries’ innovation efficiency

name: Innovation Outputs
define: Composite indexes including applications and intellectual property.
source: The effect of national culture on countries’ innovation efficiency

name: Technology Roadmapping (TRM)
define: A method for long-range technological forecasting and strategic planning.
source: Multiple Science Data-Oriented Technology Roadmapping Method

name: Text Clustering
define: A technique used for feature extraction and topic identification from textual data.
source: Multiple Science Data-Oriented Technology Roadmapping Method

name: Fuzzy Set
define: A mathematical model used to handle vague concepts and combine expert knowledge with analytic results.
source: Multiple Science Data-Oriented Technology Roadmapping Method

name: Technology Commercialization Level (TCL)
define: A concept used to identify the phase of technology commercialization.
source: Multiple Science Data-Oriented Technology Roadmapping Method

name: National Science Foundation (NSF) Award Data
define: Innovative research ideas and proposals used as a data source for the study.
source: Multiple Science Data-Oriented Technology Roadmapping Method

name: Derwent Innovation Index (DII) Patent Data
define: Patents emphasizing technical products used as a data source for the study.
source: Multiple Science Data-Oriented Technology Roadmapping Method

name: Term Clumping
define: A process used to retrieve key terms from science textual data.
source: Multiple Science Data-Oriented Technology Roadmapping Method

name: K-Means-based Textual Clustering
define: An algorithm used for clustering and identifying emerging topics for technical intelligence studies.
source: Multiple Science Data-Oriented Technology Roadmapping Method

name: Expert Engagement
define: The involvement of experts in evaluating topics and identifying their technology commercialization levels.
source: Multiple Science Data-Oriented Technology Roadmapping Method

name: Technology Life Cycle
define: A concept used to understand the stages of technology development.
source: Multiple Science Data-Oriented Technology Roadmapping Method

name: Internal and External Environment
define: A factor representing the influence of both firm environment and external environment on decision making.
source: Designing a strategic framework for stimulating agri-biotech sector performance through productivity and competitive factors: an emerging economy case

name: Cost Efficiency
define: A factor accounting for the financial aspects of acquiring and using new technology.
source: Designing a strategic framework for stimulating agri-biotech sector performance through productivity and competitive factors: an emerging economy case

name: Production Planning and Control
define: A factor indicating the focus on planning and controlling production processes.
source: Designing a strategic framework for stimulating agri-biotech sector performance through productivity and competitive factors: an emerging economy case

name: Technological Advancement
define: A factor related to the adoption of new technology and its influence on productivity.
source: Designing a strategic framework for stimulating agri-biotech sector performance through productivity and competitive factors: an emerging economy case

name: Threat of New Competition
define: A competitive factor representing the potential entry of new firms in the market.
source: Designing a strategic framework for stimulating agri-biotech sector performance through productivity and competitive factors: an emerging economy case

name: Threat of Substitute Products or Services
define: A competitive factor representing the availability of alternative products or services.
source: Designing a strategic framework for stimulating agri-biotech sector performance through productivity and competitive factors: an emerging economy case

name: Bargaining Power of Suppliers
define: A competitive factor representing the influence of suppliers on the firm's costs and operations.
source: Designing a strategic framework for stimulating agri-biotech sector performance through productivity and competitive factors: an emerging economy case

name: Intensity of Competitive Rivalry
define: A competitive factor representing the level of competition among existing firms.
source: Designing a strategic framework for stimulating agri-biotech sector performance through productivity and competitive factors: an emerging economy case

name: Bargaining Power of Customers (Buyers)
define: A competitive factor representing the influence of customers on the firm's pricing and product offerings.
source: Designing a strategic framework for stimulating agri-biotech sector performance through productivity and competitive factors: an emerging economy case

name: Preparedness for Change
define: A competitive factor representing the firm's ability to adapt to market changes and new technologies.
source: Designing a strategic framework for stimulating agri-biotech sector performance through productivity and competitive factors: an emerging economy case

name: Market Share
define: A dependent variable representing the market competitiveness of a firm.
source: Designing a strategic framework for stimulating agri-biotech sector performance through productivity and competitive factors: an emerging economy case

name: Investment on Research and Development
define: A dependent variable representing the firm's expenditure on R&D activities.
source: Designing a strategic framework for stimulating agri-biotech sector performance through productivity and competitive factors: an emerging economy case

name: Degree of Openness
define: A measure that includes the breadth of external knowledge sources, the scope of interorganizational collaborations, and the extent of technology buy-in activities.
source: Openness and Appropriation: Empirical Evidence From Australian Businesses

name: IP Appropriability Regimes
define: A composite measure of formal and informal intellectual property protection methods used by firms.
source: Openness and Appropriation: Empirical Evidence From Australian Businesses

name: Formal IP Protection
define: Formal mechanisms such as patents, copyrights, trademarks, and other legal protections.
source: Openness and Appropriation: Empirical Evidence From Australian Businesses

name: Informal IP Protection
define: Informal methods such as secrecy, complexity of product design, and rapid changes to the good or service.
source: Openness and Appropriation: Empirical Evidence From Australian Businesses

name: External Knowledge Sources
define: The variety of sources from which firms draw knowledge, including customers, suppliers, consultants, and universities.
source: Openness and Appropriation: Empirical Evidence From Australian Businesses

name: Interorganizational Collaboration
define: The extent of collaboration with other organizations for innovation purposes.
source: Openness and Appropriation: Empirical Evidence From Australian Businesses

name: Technology Purchase
define: The proportion of externally acquired technology-related expenditure to total business expenditure.
source: Openness and Appropriation: Empirical Evidence From Australian Businesses

name: R&D Expenditure
define: The financial investment in internal research and development activities.
source: Openness and Appropriation: Empirical Evidence From Australian Businesses

name: Investment in Human Capital
define: The employment of new skilled staff, new graduates, and academic or research staff.
source: Openness and Appropriation: Empirical Evidence From Australian Businesses

name: Firm Size
define: The number of employees in a firm, categorized into small, medium, and large.
source: Openness and Appropriation: Empirical Evidence From Australian Businesses

name: Industry Type
define: A categorical variable indicating whether a business is in a manufacturing-focused industry or a service-focused industry.
source: Openness and Appropriation: Empirical Evidence From Australian Businesses

name: University-Enterprise Cooperation
define: A dimension reflecting the extent of utilizing internal and external resources through the number of cooperation projects and training bases.
source: Open Innovation in Chinese High-tech Enterprises: An Empirical Research Based on Zhejiang Province

name: Number of External R&D Institutions
define: A dimension indicating the development and use of external intellectual capital and innovation resources.
source: Open Innovation in Chinese High-tech Enterprises: An Empirical Research Based on Zhejiang Province

name: Outward Technology Transfer Income
define: An indicator of commercializing internal ideas through external channels.
source: Open Innovation in Chinese High-tech Enterprises: An Empirical Research Based on Zhejiang Province

name: Authorized Invention Patents
define: A key indicator of innovation performance measured by the number of invention patents owned by a firm.
source: Open Innovation in Chinese High-tech Enterprises: An Empirical Research Based on Zhejiang Province

name: Standards Made by a Firm
define: A key indicator of innovation performance measured by the number of standards made by a firm as the first institution.
source: Open Innovation in Chinese High-tech Enterprises: An Empirical Research Based on Zhejiang Province

name: Rate of New Product Sales
define: A key indicator of innovation performance measured by the sales of new products developed by a firm's R&D center.
source: Open Innovation in Chinese High-tech Enterprises: An Empirical Research Based on Zhejiang Province

name: Firm Size
define: A categorical variable representing the size of the firm based on its revenue in billion RMB.
source: Open Innovation in Chinese High-tech Enterprises: An Empirical Research Based on Zhejiang Province

name: Industrial Type
define: A categorical variable representing the industry type of the high-tech enterprise.
source: Open Innovation in Chinese High-tech Enterprises: An Empirical Research Based on Zhejiang Province

name: AR Technologies
define: Innovative tools used to enhance psychological and pedagogical support.
source: Features of implementation of modern AR technologies in the process of psychological and pedagogical support of children with autism spectrum disorders

name: Psycho-correctional Approaches
define: Traditional methods used for the psychological and pedagogical support of children with ASD.
source: Features of implementation of modern AR technologies in the process of psychological and pedagogical support of children with autism spectrum disorders

name: Psycho-diagnostic Approaches
define: Methods used for assessing and diagnosing ASD characteristics in children.
source: Features of implementation of modern AR technologies in the process of psychological and pedagogical support of children with autism spectrum disorders

name: Inclusive Environment
define: The setting in which AR technologies are implemented for children with ASD.
source: Features of implementation of modern AR technologies in the process of psychological and pedagogical support of children with autism spectrum disorders

name: Communicative Abilities
define: The capacity for communication developed in children with ASD through AR technologies.
source: Features of implementation of modern AR technologies in the process of psychological and pedagogical support of children with autism spectrum disorders

name: Cognitive Abilities
define: The cognitive functions enhanced in children with ASD through AR technologies.
source: Features of implementation of modern AR technologies in the process of psychological and pedagogical support of children with autism spectrum disorders

name: Emotional-volitional Abilities
define: The emotional and volitional capacities developed in children with ASD through AR technologies.
source: Features of implementation of modern AR technologies in the process of psychological and pedagogical support of children with autism spectrum disorders

name: Mnemonic Abilities
define: The memory-related skills improved in children with ASD through AR technologies.
source: Features of implementation of modern AR technologies in the process of psychological and pedagogical support of children with autism spectrum disorders

name: Adaptive Potential
define: The capacity for adaptation and socially accepted behaviors actualized in children with ASD through AR technologies.
source: Features of implementation of modern AR technologies in the process of psychological and pedagogical support of children with autism spectrum disorders

name: Adaptive Behaviors
define: Behaviors that are considered adaptive and socially acceptable, developed in children with ASD through AR technologies.
source: Features of implementation of modern AR technologies in the process of psychological and pedagogical support of children with autism spectrum disorders

name: Authorized Patent Quantity
define: The number of patents granted to a thousand researchers, used as an output index.
source: An Empirical Analysis on Inner Impact Factors of Independent Innovation of Innovative Pilot Enterprises in Fujian Province of China

name: R&D Input Intensity
define: The percentage of R&D investment in the total investment.
source: An Empirical Analysis on Inner Impact Factors of Independent Innovation of Innovative Pilot Enterprises in Fujian Province of China

name: R&D Personnel Proportion
define: The percentage of R&D personnel in the total number of employees.
source: An Empirical Analysis on Inner Impact Factors of Independent Innovation of Innovative Pilot Enterprises in Fujian Province of China

name: Staff Educational Expenditure Proportion
define: The proportion of staff education, training, and learning expenses in the main business income.
source: An Empirical Analysis on Inner Impact Factors of Independent Innovation of Innovative Pilot Enterprises in Fujian Province of China

name: Construction Condition of R&D Institution
define: A qualitative index representing the condition of the enterprise's technology R&D institution.
source: An Empirical Analysis on Inner Impact Factors of Independent Innovation of Innovative Pilot Enterprises in Fujian Province of China

name: Construction Condition of Intellectual Property Management System
define: A qualitative index representing the condition of the intellectual property management system.
source: An Empirical Analysis on Inner Impact Factors of Independent Innovation of Innovative Pilot Enterprises in Fujian Province of China

name: Construction Condition of Innovation Development Strategy
define: A qualitative index representing the condition of the innovation development strategy.
source: An Empirical Analysis on Inner Impact Factors of Independent Innovation of Innovative Pilot Enterprises in Fujian Province of China

name: Public Resource Trading Center
define: A dummy variable representing the establishment of public resource trading centers in the city where the enterprise is located.
source: Green Innovation Effect of Public Resource Trading Centers: An Empirical Study Based on China's A-share Listed Companies

name: Green Innovation
define: The level of green innovation, measured by the total number of green patent applications.
source: Green Innovation Effect of Public Resource Trading Centers: An Empirical Study Based on China's A-share Listed Companies

name: Firm Ownership
define: A categorical variable distinguishing between state-owned and non-state-owned enterprises.
source: Green Innovation Effect of Public Resource Trading Centers: An Empirical Study Based on China's A-share Listed Companies

name: Firm Scale
define: A categorical variable differentiating between large-scale and small-scale enterprises based on total assets.
source: Green Innovation Effect of Public Resource Trading Centers: An Empirical Study Based on China's A-share Listed Companies

name: Industry Attributes
define: A categorical variable classifying enterprises into heavily polluting and non-heavy polluting industries.
source: Green Innovation Effect of Public Resource Trading Centers: An Empirical Study Based on China's A-share Listed Companies

name: ESG Performance
define: A proxy variable for the degree of standardization and regularization of public resource transactions, measured by enterprise ESG disclosure.
source: Green Innovation Effect of Public Resource Trading Centers: An Empirical Study Based on China's A-share Listed Companies

name: Environmental Pollution Control Index (EPCI)
define: A measure of the environmental supervision and management responsibilities, used to assess the impact of public resource trading centers on green innovation.
source: Green Innovation Effect of Public Resource Trading Centers: An Empirical Study Based on China's A-share Listed Companies

name: Patents Number
define: The number of patents filed in a certain period of time.
source: Prediction Method and Empirical Study of Pharmaceutical Industry Technology Innovation Based on TRIZ Theory

name: Patent Level
define: The degree of innovation represented by the patents, divided into five classes.
source: Prediction Method and Empirical Study of Pharmaceutical Industry Technology Innovation Based on TRIZ Theory

name: Product Function
define: The functionality of the product that applied the technology.
source: Prediction Method and Empirical Study of Pharmaceutical Industry Technology Innovation Based on TRIZ Theory

name: Product Profitability
define: The profit generated by the product using the technology.
source: Prediction Method and Empirical Study of Pharmaceutical Industry Technology Innovation Based on TRIZ Theory

name: Technology Maturity
define: The evolutionary stage of the technology, determined by the analysis of patents and other variables.
source: Prediction Method and Empirical Study of Pharmaceutical Industry Technology Innovation Based on TRIZ Theory

name: Sales Volume
define: The volume of products sold in the market.
source: Prediction Method and Empirical Study of Pharmaceutical Industry Technology Innovation Based on TRIZ Theory

name: Production Value
define: The total value of products produced.
source: Prediction Method and Empirical Study of Pharmaceutical Industry Technology Innovation Based on TRIZ Theory

name: Innovation Strategy
define: The approach taken for innovation, which can be incremental or radical.
source: Prediction Method and Empirical Study of Pharmaceutical Industry Technology Innovation Based on TRIZ Theory

name: Research and Development (R&D) Input
define: The investment made in the development of new drugs and technologies.
source: Prediction Method and Empirical Study of Pharmaceutical Industry Technology Innovation Based on TRIZ Theory

name: Technology Innovation Direction
define: The predicted direction of technological evolution and innovation.
source: Prediction Method and Empirical Study of Pharmaceutical Industry Technology Innovation Based on TRIZ Theory

name: Research Quality
define: A measure of research quality aggregated at individual and institutional level, normalized by scientific field or sector averages.
source: The link between research quality and technology transfer in the Italian Evaluation of Research Quality VQR 2011-2014

name: Valorization of Research
define: The commercialization of research outputs, including patents, spin-offs, and third-party funding.
source: The link between research quality and technology transfer in the Italian Evaluation of Research Quality VQR 2011-2014

name: Disciplinary Differences
define: The impact of scientific output on the creation of new firms, which varies by discipline.
source: The link between research quality and technology transfer in the Italian Evaluation of Research Quality VQR 2011-2014

name: Regional Context
define: The influence of the geographic location of universities on their interaction with the business sector.
source: The link between research quality and technology transfer in the Italian Evaluation of Research Quality VQR 2011-2014

name: University Features
define: The institutional heterogeneity that affects the strategy and organization of the knowledge valorization process.
source: The link between research quality and technology transfer in the Italian Evaluation of Research Quality VQR 2011-2014

name: Funding
define: The volume of research funding, including third-party funding, and its impact on scientific production.
source: The link between research quality and technology transfer in the Italian Evaluation of Research Quality VQR 2011-2014

name: Technology Transfer Office
define: The internal organization of universities for the design and implementation of valorization.
source: The link between research quality and technology transfer in the Italian Evaluation of Research Quality VQR 2011-2014

name: Number of Patents per Capita
define: A measure of patenting activity normalized by the number of individuals.
source: The link between research quality and technology transfer in the Italian Evaluation of Research Quality VQR 2011-2014

name: Number of Spin-offs per Capita
define: A measure of the creation of spin-off companies normalized by the number of individuals.
source: The link between research quality and technology transfer in the Italian Evaluation of Research Quality VQR 2011-2014

name: Per Capita Funding
define: The amount of funding received per individual.
source: The link between research quality and technology transfer in the Italian Evaluation of Research Quality VQR 2011-2014

name: Product Innovation
define: The rate at which new products are developed and introduced in the biopharmaceutical industry.
source: Product and Process Innovation in the Development Cycle of Biopharmaceuticals

name: Process Innovation
define: The rate at which new processes are developed and implemented in the biopharmaceutical industry.
source: Product and Process Innovation in the Development Cycle of Biopharmaceuticals

name: Biopharmaceuticals
define: A class of therapeutic proteins produced by modern biotechnology techniques.
source: Product and Process Innovation in the Development Cycle of Biopharmaceuticals

name: Small-Molecule Drugs
define: Traditional pharmaceuticals that are small in molecular size and can be administered through a variety of routes.
source: Product and Process Innovation in the Development Cycle of Biopharmaceuticals

name: International Patent Classification (IPC) Codes
define: A standard taxonomy used for the classification of patents.
source: Product and Process Innovation in the Development Cycle of Biopharmaceuticals

name: Quality by Design (QbD)
define: A systematic approach to product development that begins with predefined objectives.
source: Product and Process Innovation in the Development Cycle of Biopharmaceuticals

name: Aseptic Processing
define: A process in the manufacture of biopharmaceuticals that maintains microbiological asepsis.
source: Product and Process Innovation in the Development Cycle of Biopharmaceuticals

name: Parenteral Medications
define: Biopharmaceuticals administered as parenteral medications, which require sterile formulations.
source: Product and Process Innovation in the Development Cycle of Biopharmaceuticals

name: Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP)
define: The minimum requirements that must be met in the manufacture of pharmaceutical products.
source: Product and Process Innovation in the Development Cycle of Biopharmaceuticals

name: Critical Quality Attributes (CQAs)
define: The physical, chemical, and biological properties of a product that should be within an appropriate limit, range, or distribution to ensure the desired product quality.
source: Product and Process Innovation in the Development Cycle of Biopharmaceuticals

name: Gross Ocean Product (GOP)
define: A measure of the total value of marine economic activities, used as a basic sequence in the study.
source: Research Article Relational Research between China’s Marine S&T and Economy Based on RPGRA Model

name: Marine Scientific Research Institutions
define: The number of institutions involved in marine scientific research.
source: Research Article Relational Research between China’s Marine S&T and Economy Based on RPGRA Model

name: Research Funds Receipts
define: The amount of funding received by marine scientific research institutions.
source: Research Article Relational Research between China’s Marine S&T and Economy Based on RPGRA Model

name: Marine Scientific and Technological Research Projects
define: The number of research projects conducted in the field of marine science and technology.
source: Research Article Relational Research between China’s Marine S&T and Economy Based on RPGRA Model

name: Marine Scientific Theses Published
define: The number of marine scientific theses published.
source: Research Article Relational Research between China’s Marine S&T and Economy Based on RPGRA Model

name: Marine Scientific and Technological Patents Granted
define: The number of patents granted in the field of marine science and technology.
source: Research Article Relational Research between China’s Marine S&T and Economy Based on RPGRA Model

name: R&D Expenditure
define: The total intramural expenditure spent on fundamental research, applied research, and experimental development.
source: Relative Efficiency of R&D Capabilities in China Based on DEA Approach

name: R&D Personnel
define: Staff fulltime engaged in fundamental research, applied research, and experimental development.
source: Relative Efficiency of R&D Capabilities in China Based on DEA Approach

name: Patents Granted
define: The number of patents granted by China.
source: Relative Efficiency of R&D Capabilities in China Based on DEA Approach

name: Academic Papers
define: The annual number of papers published in Science Citation Index (SCI), Engineering Index (EI), and Index to Scientific & Technical Proceedings (ISTP) international journals.
source: Relative Efficiency of R&D Capabilities in China Based on DEA Approach

name: CRS Efficiency
define: A measure of the relative efficiency of R&D capabilities using the CRS model in DEA.
source: Relative Efficiency of R&D Capabilities in China Based on DEA Approach

name: Technical Efficiency
define: A measure of the efficiency of provinces that are CRS-efficient plus additional ones that are technically efficient.
source: Relative Efficiency of R&D Capabilities in China Based on DEA Approach

name: Scale Economy
define: The concept of whether R&D investments demonstrate economies of scale.
source: Relative Efficiency of R&D Capabilities in China Based on DEA Approach

name: Increasing Returns to Scale
define: The occurrence of a few provinces showing increasing returns to scale in R&D investments.
source: Relative Efficiency of R&D Capabilities in China Based on DEA Approach

name: Economic Development Level
define: The categorization of provinces into high, medium, or low economic development levels.
source: Relative Efficiency of R&D Capabilities in China Based on DEA Approach

name: R&D Inputs
define: The combined input of R&D expenditure and R&D personnel.
source: Relative Efficiency of R&D Capabilities in China Based on DEA Approach

name: R&D Outputs
define: The combined output of patents granted and academic papers.
source: Relative Efficiency of R&D Capabilities in China Based on DEA Approach

name: Technological Maturity Assessment (TMA)
define: A process to evaluate the development stage of emerging technologies using patent indicators.
source: Research on Commercial Potential Evaluation of Newly & Emerging Technologies: A Case Study of Graphene

name: Technological Opportunities Identification (TOI)
define: A process that combines monitoring and bibliometric analyses to generate intelligence on emerging technologies.
source: Research on Commercial Potential Evaluation of Newly & Emerging Technologies: A Case Study of Graphene

name: Competitive Environment Analysis (CEA)
define: A process to identify the market competition environment through patent family size and leading patent assignee analysis.
source: Research on Commercial Potential Evaluation of Newly & Emerging Technologies: A Case Study of Graphene

name: Graphene Patents
define: Patents related to graphene technology collected from the Derwent World Patent Index database.
source: Research on Commercial Potential Evaluation of Newly & Emerging Technologies: A Case Study of Graphene

name: Patent Indicators
define: Multiple indicators such as International Patent Classification (IPC) counts, patent assignees, inventors, family member numbers, and cited patent numbers.
source: Research on Commercial Potential Evaluation of Newly & Emerging Technologies: A Case Study of Graphene

name: Cooperative Patent Classification (CPC)
define: A classification system used to analyze the technical evolution process of a certain technical field.
source: Research on Commercial Potential Evaluation of Newly & Emerging Technologies: A Case Study of Graphene

name: Patent Family Size
define: The number of countries in which a patent has been applied, indicating the perceived commercial potential.
source: Research on Commercial Potential Evaluation of Newly & Emerging Technologies: A Case Study of Graphene

name: Leading Patent Assignees
define: The main organizations filing for patents, indicating their role in technology development and market delivery.
source: Research on Commercial Potential Evaluation of Newly & Emerging Technologies: A Case Study of Graphene

name: Market Shift
define: The change in the distribution of target markets for graphene technology over time.
source: Research on Commercial Potential Evaluation of Newly & Emerging Technologies: A Case Study of Graphene

name: Academic and Corporate Patenting
define: The activity of academic institutions and companies in patent application related to graphene technology.
source: Research on Commercial Potential Evaluation of Newly & Emerging Technologies: A Case Study of Graphene

name: Innovation
define: The number of patents a firm has published, considered a meaningful measure for innovation.
source: Role of inter-organizational knowledge networks in innovation-driven collaborations of Biotechnology industry

name: Knowledge Heterogeneity
define: The diversity of knowledge areas (IPCs) shared by a firm, calculated using the Herfindahl index and Simpson's diversity index.
source: Role of inter-organizational knowledge networks in innovation-driven collaborations of Biotechnology industry

name: Firms' Network Centrality
define: A structural property that represents a firm's position within the whole network, calculated by the degree of a firm in a given network.
source: Role of inter-organizational knowledge networks in innovation-driven collaborations of Biotechnology industry

name: Firms' Ego-Network Density
define: A structural property that measures the sparseness or low density of a firm's ego-network, calculated using the number of existing triangles divided by all possible triangles.
source: Role of inter-organizational knowledge networks in innovation-driven collaborations of Biotechnology industry

name: Exploration Index
define: A measure that shows the degree of exploration vs. exploitation, calculated using the Herfindahl index and Simpson's diversity index.
source: Role of inter-organizational knowledge networks in innovation-driven collaborations of Biotechnology industry

name: Total Number of Products (T)
define: The total count of a scientist's publications or patents.
source: Investigating the quantity–quality relationship in scientific creativity: an empirical examination of expected residual variance and the tilted funnel hypothesis

name: Total Number of High-Quality Products (H)
define: The count of a scientist's publications or patents that are considered to be of high quality.
source: Investigating the quantity–quality relationship in scientific creativity: an empirical examination of expected residual variance and the tilted funnel hypothesis

name: Average Quality (H/T)
define: The ratio of high-quality products to total products, indicating the average quality of a scientist's work.
source: Investigating the quantity–quality relationship in scientific creativity: an empirical examination of expected residual variance and the tilted funnel hypothesis

name: Citations
define: The number of citations a scientist's work has received, used as a proxy for the quality of their work.
source: Investigating the quantity–quality relationship in scientific creativity: an empirical examination of expected residual variance and the tilted funnel hypothesis

name: Intellectual Property Rules
define: Legal requirements such as patents and data exclusivity that can affect access to medicines.
source: What is the impact of intellectual property rules on access to medicines? A systematic review

name: Access to Medicines
define: The availability, cost, or price of medicines.
source: What is the impact of intellectual property rules on access to medicines? A systematic review

name: TRIPS Agreement
define: The World Trade Organization’s Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights that requires Member States to implement minimum standards of intellectual property protection.
source: What is the impact of intellectual property rules on access to medicines? A systematic review

name: TRIPS-Plus Rules
define: Rules that go beyond what is required by TRIPS, often included in trade agreements.
source: What is the impact of intellectual property rules on access to medicines? A systematic review

name: Compulsory Licensing
define: The authorization of the production of a patented product or use of a patented process without the consent of the patent owner.
source: What is the impact of intellectual property rules on access to medicines? A systematic review

name: Parallel Importation
define: When a country imports an authorized patented product from another country without the permission of the patent owner.
source: What is the impact of intellectual property rules on access to medicines? A systematic review

name: Data Exclusivity
define: The protection of clinical drug trial data submitted to drug regulatory authorities for market approval, prohibiting generic drug companies from relying on existing drug trial data.
source: What is the impact of intellectual property rules on access to medicines? A systematic review

name: Patent Term Extensions
define: Extensions to the duration of a patent beyond the standard term.
source: What is the impact of intellectual property rules on access to medicines? A systematic review

name: Secondary Patenting
define: Patents on aspects other than the original active drug ingredient, such as chemical variants, new formulations, or methods of administration.
source: What is the impact of intellectual property rules on access to medicines? A systematic review

name: Generic Entry
define: The market entry of generic drugs after the patent expiry of the original drug.
source: What is the impact of intellectual property rules on access to medicines? A systematic review

name: Eco-patents
define: Patent applications related to environmental protection measures.
source: Technological innovations for environmental protection: role of intellectual property rights in the carbon mitigation efforts. Evidence from western and southern Europe

name: Trademarks
define: Trademark applications that may indicate new product launches.
source: Technological innovations for environmental protection: role of intellectual property rights in the carbon mitigation efforts. Evidence from western and southern Europe

name: Carbon Dioxide Emission
define: The amount of CO2 emissions produced.
source: Technological innovations for environmental protection: role of intellectual property rights in the carbon mitigation efforts. Evidence from western and southern Europe

name: Greenhouse Gas Emission
define: The total amount of greenhouse gas emissions, including CO2.
source: Technological innovations for environmental protection: role of intellectual property rights in the carbon mitigation efforts. Evidence from western and southern Europe

name: Environmental Policy Stringency
define: The strictness of environmental policies in place.
source: Technological innovations for environmental protection: role of intellectual property rights in the carbon mitigation efforts. Evidence from western and southern Europe

name: Energy Consumption
define: The total energy consumed, often a contributor to emissions.
source: Technological innovations for environmental protection: role of intellectual property rights in the carbon mitigation efforts. Evidence from western and southern Europe

name: Urbanization
define: The extent of urban development which can impact emissions.
source: Technological innovations for environmental protection: role of intellectual property rights in the carbon mitigation efforts. Evidence from western and southern Europe

name: Economic Growth
define: The growth of the economy, which can influence energy demand and emissions.
source: Technological innovations for environmental protection: role of intellectual property rights in the carbon mitigation efforts. Evidence from western and southern Europe

name: Environmental Taxes
define: Taxes levied on activities that impact the environment.
source: Technological innovations for environmental protection: role of intellectual property rights in the carbon mitigation efforts. Evidence from western and southern Europe

name: Trade Openness
define: A measure of a country's trade activity which can influence environmental policies and technologies.
source: Technological innovations for environmental protection: role of intellectual property rights in the carbon mitigation efforts. Evidence from western and southern Europe

name: Foreign MNEs' Innovative Background
define: A measure of the innovativeness of foreign MNEs based on their patent production.
source: Managing Innovation in Emerging Economies: Organizational Arrangements and Resources of Foreign MNEs in the Chinese Pharmaceutical Industry

name: Foreign MNEs' Investment Choices
define: The locations chosen by foreign MNEs for their R&D activities in China.
source: Managing Innovation in Emerging Economies: Organizational Arrangements and Resources of Foreign MNEs in the Chinese Pharmaceutical Industry

name: Organizational Arrangements for Local Knowledge Creation
define: The way foreign MNEs organize their innovative activities in China, including the composition of inventor teams and the use of co-assigned patents.
source: Managing Innovation in Emerging Economies: Organizational Arrangements and Resources of Foreign MNEs in the Chinese Pharmaceutical Industry

name: Local Innovative Performance
define: The performance of local innovative processes, measured by patent quality indicators such as citations to non-patent literature and the number of forward citations.
source: Managing Innovation in Emerging Economies: Organizational Arrangements and Resources of Foreign MNEs in the Chinese Pharmaceutical Industry

name: Absorptive Capacity
define: The ability of local firms to successfully internalize advanced technology or conduct joint research activities with MNEs from developed countries.
source: Managing Innovation in Emerging Economies: Organizational Arrangements and Resources of Foreign MNEs in the Chinese Pharmaceutical Industry

name: R&D Collaborations
define: Joint innovative activities between foreign MNEs and local firms or institutions, indicated by co-assigned patents.
source: Managing Innovation in Emerging Economies: Organizational Arrangements and Resources of Foreign MNEs in the Chinese Pharmaceutical Industry

name: Patent Quality
define: A measure of the technological importance and value of patents, reflected by the number of forward citations and references to non-patent literature.
source: Managing Innovation in Emerging Economies: Organizational Arrangements and Resources of Foreign MNEs in the Chinese Pharmaceutical Industry

name: Location Choices
define: The specific cities or regions where foreign MNEs decide to establish their R&D activities.
source: Managing Innovation in Emerging Economies: Organizational Arrangements and Resources of Foreign MNEs in the Chinese Pharmaceutical Industry

name: Inventor Team Composition
define: The distribution of inventors across different countries and their affiliation with foreign MNEs or local firms.
source: Managing Innovation in Emerging Economies: Organizational Arrangements and Resources of Foreign MNEs in the Chinese Pharmaceutical Industry

name: Global Technological Leader
define: A status assigned to assignees in the upper quartile of the global pharmaceutical industry in terms of patent production.
source: Managing Innovation in Emerging Economies: Organizational Arrangements and Resources of Foreign MNEs in the Chinese Pharmaceutical Industry

name: University Research Output
define: A collection of academic abstracts, open-source full-text publications, and publication metadata.
source: Tracing university–industry knowledge transfer through a text mining approach

name: Industry Knowledge
define: Information gathered from corporate company websites, focusing on commercial relevance and R&D successes.
source: Tracing university–industry knowledge transfer through a text mining approach

name: Text Mining Tools
define: Methods used for text analysis, including Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) and Term-Frequency, Inverse Document Frequency (TFIDF).
source: Tracing university–industry knowledge transfer through a text mining approach

name: Knowledge Transfer
define: The conveyance of knowledge from the university to the industry, detected through text mining.
source: Tracing university–industry knowledge transfer through a text mining approach

name: Formal and Informal Knowledge Transfer
define: Legal instrumentalities like patents, licenses, or informal communication resulting from collaborations.
source: Tracing university–industry knowledge transfer through a text mining approach

name: Commercial Value
define: The economic potential or actual commercial success of the knowledge transferred.
source: Tracing university–industry knowledge transfer through a text mining approach

name: Research Areas
define: Specific fields of study within the university that are the focus of the text mining analysis.
source: Tracing university–industry knowledge transfer through a text mining approach

name: Company Collaboration
define: Formal links between companies and the university, based on collaboration contracts.
source: Tracing university–industry knowledge transfer through a text mining approach

name: Digitalization and Data Availability
define: The level of digitization in the national context and the availability of data for text mining applications.
source: Tracing university–industry knowledge transfer through a text mining approach

name: English Language Usage
define: The prevalence of English as the language of publication and communication in both academic and industry contexts.
source: Tracing university–industry knowledge transfer through a text mining approach

name: Human Verification
define: The process of manual inspection and final verification of text mining results by human experts.
source: Tracing university–industry knowledge transfer through a text mining approach

name: Innovation Output
define: Measured using the number of patents per million inhabitants.
source: Spatial Spillovers of Regional Innovation: Evidence from Chinese Provinces

name: R&D Input
define: Intramural expenditure for R&D per million persons by region.
source: Spatial Spillovers of Regional Innovation: Evidence from Chinese Provinces

name: Absorptive Capacity
define: Average years of schooling for inhabitants by region, used as a proxy for the quality of human resources and technological capabilities.
source: Spatial Spillovers of Regional Innovation: Evidence from Chinese Provinces

name: FDI
define: Actual use of foreign direct investment per million persons by region.
source: Spatial Spillovers of Regional Innovation: Evidence from Chinese Provinces

name: Agglomeration Economies
define: Urban employment density, used as a proxy for the geographic concentration of economic activity.
source: Spatial Spillovers of Regional Innovation: Evidence from Chinese Provinces

name: Software Intensity
define: The ratio of software patent stock to total patent stock, used as a proxy for software-based innovation.
source: Soft but Strong: Software-Based Innovation and Product Differentiation in the IT Hardware Industry

name: Product Differentiation
define: Measured by the total similarity score and the number of firms within a firm's TNIC industry, as well as new product launches and their novelty.
source: Soft but Strong: Software-Based Innovation and Product Differentiation in the IT Hardware Industry

name: Total Similarity Score
define: The sum of a firm's pairwise similarity scores with all other firms within the same TNIC industry, indicating product similarity.
source: Soft but Strong: Software-Based Innovation and Product Differentiation in the IT Hardware Industry

name: Number of TNIC Firms
define: The total number of firms within a firm's TNIC industry, related to product market competition.
source: Soft but Strong: Software-Based Innovation and Product Differentiation in the IT Hardware Industry

name: Number of New Products
define: The count of new product launches by a firm, based on RavenPack data.
source: Soft but Strong: Software-Based Innovation and Product Differentiation in the IT Hardware Industry

name: Differentiated Product Launch
define: A dummy variable indicating whether a firm launched at least one new product that is distinctly different from other products in the same topic group.
source: Soft but Strong: Software-Based Innovation and Product Differentiation in the IT Hardware Industry

name: Novel Product Launch
define: A dummy variable indicating whether a firm launched at least one new product in a topic group where it had not launched any new product in the previous 5 years.
source: Soft but Strong: Software-Based Innovation and Product Differentiation in the IT Hardware Industry

name: Patent Stock/Asset
define: The ratio of patent stock to total assets, controlling for overall patenting intensity.
source: Soft but Strong: Software-Based Innovation and Product Differentiation in the IT Hardware Industry

name: R&D Stock/Asset
define: The ratio of R&D stock to total assets, controlling for R&D investment.
source: Soft but Strong: Software-Based Innovation and Product Differentiation in the IT Hardware Industry

name: Sales
define: A proxy for firm size, used as a control variable.
source: Soft but Strong: Software-Based Innovation and Product Differentiation in the IT Hardware Industry

name: Industry R&D Intensity
define: The sum of R&D investments in an industry divided by the total assets in the industry, used as a control variable.
source: Soft but Strong: Software-Based Innovation and Product Differentiation in the IT Hardware Industry

name: Basic Internet Adoption
define: A binary variable indicating whether a firm's locations have adopted basic Internet technology.
source: From wires to partners: How the Internet has fostered R&D collaborations within firms

name: Collaborative Patents
define: A binary variable indicating whether patents are co-invented by researchers across different firm locations.
source: From wires to partners: How the Internet has fostered R&D collaborations within firms

name: Geographically Dispersed Teams
define: A characteristic of research teams being located in different geographical locations.
source: From wires to partners: How the Internet has fostered R&D collaborations within firms

name: Within-Location Collaborative Patents
define: A binary variable indicating whether collaborative patents are invented by researchers within the same location.
source: From wires to partners: How the Internet has fostered R&D collaborations within firms

name: Single-Inventor Patents
define: A binary variable indicating whether patents are invented by a single inventor within a firm location.
source: From wires to partners: How the Internet has fostered R&D collaborations within firms

name: Firm R&D Spending
define: A continuous variable measured as the logarithm of per-establishment R&D spending.
source: From wires to partners: How the Internet has fostered R&D collaborations within firms

name: Establishment Employment
define: A continuous variable measured as the logarithm of the number of employees at the establishment.
source: From wires to partners: How the Internet has fostered R&D collaborations within firms

name: Share of Local Employment in Manufacturing
define: A continuous variable representing the percentage of local employment in the manufacturing sector.
source: From wires to partners: How the Internet has fostered R&D collaborations within firms

name: Local Average Weekly Wages
define: A continuous variable representing the average weekly wages in the local area.
source: From wires to partners: How the Internet has fostered R&D collaborations within firms

name: Log of Local Employment
define: A continuous variable measured as the logarithm of the total employment in the local area.
source: From wires to partners: How the Internet has fostered R&D collaborations within firms

name: Log of Number of Local Patents
define: A continuous variable measured as the logarithm of the total number of patents in the local area.
source: From wires to partners: How the Internet has fostered R&D collaborations within firms

name: Technological Proximity
define: A measure of technological relatedness between firms based on the frequency of patents in different classes.
source: The Role of Technology Spillovers in the Process of Water Pollution Abatement for Large International Firms

name: Environmental Technology Matrix
define: A matrix constructed using the Mahalanobis approach to evaluate the effects of environmental spillovers.
source: The Role of Technology Spillovers in the Process of Water Pollution Abatement for Large International Firms

name: Marshall-Arrow-Romer (MAR) Spillovers
define: Intra-industry or specialized externalities assumed to occur within the same technology class.
source: The Role of Technology Spillovers in the Process of Water Pollution Abatement for Large International Firms

name: Jacobian Spillovers
define: Inter-industry or diversified externalities assumed to occur between different technology classes.
source: The Role of Technology Spillovers in the Process of Water Pollution Abatement for Large International Firms

name: Productivity
define: Measured by net sales for a firm in a given year.
source: The Role of Technology Spillovers in the Process of Water Pollution Abatement for Large International Firms

name: Physical Capital Stock
define: The stock of physical capital for a firm in a given year.
source: The Role of Technology Spillovers in the Process of Water Pollution Abatement for Large International Firms

name: Employment
define: The number of employees for a firm in a given year.
source: The Role of Technology Spillovers in the Process of Water Pollution Abatement for Large International Firms

name: R&D Capital Stock
define: The stock of R&D capital for a firm in a given year.
source: The Role of Technology Spillovers in the Process of Water Pollution Abatement for Large International Firms

name: Environmental Performance
define: Evaluated through the ratio between productivity and CO2 emissions (SCO2).
source: The Role of Technology Spillovers in the Process of Water Pollution Abatement for Large International Firms

name: CO2 Emissions
define: Emission variables provided by the environmental accounts from the World Input Output Database.
source: The Role of Technology Spillovers in the Process of Water Pollution Abatement for Large International Firms

name: Technological Diversification (TD)
define: A measure of the extent of a firm's diversification across different technology fields.
source: Dynamic Technological Diversification and Its Impact on Firms’ Performance: An Empirical Analysis of Korean IT Firms

name: Unrelated Technological Diversification (UTD)
define: A measure of the extent of a firm's diversification among irrelevant technology fields.
source: Dynamic Technological Diversification and Its Impact on Firms’ Performance: An Empirical Analysis of Korean IT Firms

name: Related Technological Diversification (RTD)
define: A measure of the extent of a firm's diversification on relevant technology fields.
source: Dynamic Technological Diversification and Its Impact on Firms’ Performance: An Empirical Analysis of Korean IT Firms

name: Firm's Innovation Capabilities (PCAP)
define: A measure of a firm's growth rate during the period of R&D planning and project participation.
source: Dynamic Technological Diversification and Its Impact on Firms’ Performance: An Empirical Analysis of Korean IT Firms

name: Firm's Performance (FPER)
define: A measure of a firm's growth rate used to evaluate the benefits of technological diversification.
source: Dynamic Technological Diversification and Its Impact on Firms’ Performance: An Empirical Analysis of Korean IT Firms

name: Time Periods (TPCAP, TFPER)
define: The prior stage of patent application and the stage to have performance associated with technological diversification.
source: Dynamic Technological Diversification and Its Impact on Firms’ Performance: An Empirical Analysis of Korean IT Firms

name: Firm's Size
define: A categorical variable distinguishing between small and large firms.
source: Dynamic Technological Diversification and Its Impact on Firms’ Performance: An Empirical Analysis of Korean IT Firms

name: Return on Sales (ROS)
define: A financial metric used to calculate the moving average for growth rate analysis.
source: Dynamic Technological Diversification and Its Impact on Firms’ Performance: An Empirical Analysis of Korean IT Firms

name: International Patent Classification (IPC)
define: A system used to classify the technical attributes of a patent.
source: Dynamic Technological Diversification and Its Impact on Firms’ Performance: An Empirical Analysis of Korean IT Firms

name: International Technological Collaboration
define: A concept that refers to the cooperation among different nations or regions in the field of technology.
source: Exploring the Technological Collaboration Characteristics of the Global Integrated Circuit Manufacturing Industry

name: Collaboration Patterns
define: The distribution of research topics and the main technological collaboration subfields among countries or regions.
source: Exploring the Technological Collaboration Characteristics of the Global Integrated Circuit Manufacturing Industry

name: Collaboration Networks
define: The structure that represents the relationships among countries or regions in terms of technological cooperation.
source: Exploring the Technological Collaboration Characteristics of the Global Integrated Circuit Manufacturing Industry

name: Collaboration Institutions
define: The types of institutions involved in international technological cooperation, such as enterprises, research institutions, colleges, and universities.
source: Exploring the Technological Collaboration Characteristics of the Global Integrated Circuit Manufacturing Industry

name: Collaboration Impact
define: The influence of a country or region in the international technological cooperation network, measured by centrality metrics.
source: Exploring the Technological Collaboration Characteristics of the Global Integrated Circuit Manufacturing Industry

name: USA
define: A country that has the highest level of international technological collaboration in the ICM industry.
source: Exploring the Technological Collaboration Characteristics of the Global Integrated Circuit Manufacturing Industry

name: Germany
define: A country with great potential for future development in international technological collaboration.
source: Exploring the Technological Collaboration Characteristics of the Global Integrated Circuit Manufacturing Industry

name: Asia
define: A geographical region that has formed a cluster in the cooperative network.
source: Exploring the Technological Collaboration Characteristics of the Global Integrated Circuit Manufacturing Industry

name: Europe
define: A geographical region that has also formed a cluster in the cooperative network.
source: Exploring the Technological Collaboration Characteristics of the Global Integrated Circuit Manufacturing Industry

name: Patents
define: A form of intellectual property rights that serves as a basis for analyzing technological collaboration.
source: Exploring the Technological Collaboration Characteristics of the Global Integrated Circuit Manufacturing Industry

name: Institutions
define: Entities such as enterprises, research institutions, colleges, and universities that own patents and participate in international collaboration.
source: Exploring the Technological Collaboration Characteristics of the Global Integrated Circuit Manufacturing Industry

name: Net Sales
define: A variable representing the total sales of a firm.
