source: Green Economy and Sustainable Development: The Economic Impact of Innovation on Employment

name: Number of Employees
define: A variable representing the total workforce of a firm.
source: Green Economy and Sustainable Development: The Economic Impact of Innovation on Employment

name: Annual Capital Expenditures
define: A variable representing the total capital expenditures made by a firm in a year.
source: Green Economy and Sustainable Development: The Economic Impact of Innovation on Employment

name: Annual R&D Expenditures
define: A variable representing the total research and development expenditures made by a firm in a year.
source: Green Economy and Sustainable Development: The Economic Impact of Innovation on Employment

name: Annual Operating Profit
define: A variable representing the total operating profit of a firm in a year.
source: Green Economy and Sustainable Development: The Economic Impact of Innovation on Employment

name: R&D Capital Stock
define: A variable representing the accumulated R&D capital stock of a firm.
source: Green Economy and Sustainable Development: The Economic Impact of Innovation on Employment

name: Marshallian Spillovers
define: A variable representing the externalities stemming from firms belonging to the same sector.
source: Green Economy and Sustainable Development: The Economic Impact of Innovation on Employment

name: Environmental Innovations
define: A variable representing the adoption of new environmentally friendly technologies or practices.
source: Green Economy and Sustainable Development: The Economic Impact of Innovation on Employment

name: Firm's Fixed Effects
define: A variable controlling for unobserved heterogeneity between firms.
source: Green Economy and Sustainable Development: The Economic Impact of Innovation on Employment

name: Time Dummies
define: A variable controlling for time-specific effects.
source: Green Economy and Sustainable Development: The Economic Impact of Innovation on Employment

name: Industry Dummies
define: A variable controlling for industry-specific effects.
source: Green Economy and Sustainable Development: The Economic Impact of Innovation on Employment

name: Central Position
define: A measure of a node’s rights within the network, quantified by the degree of centrality, which is the number of other nodes directly connected to a given node.
source: Network Position Advantage and Technological Innovation of China’s New Energy Vehicle Based on the Perspective of Network Theory

name: Brokerage Position
define: A measure of the level of a node as a bridge in the network, quantified by the effective scale, which is the size of a single node in the network minus the overall network redundancy.
source: Network Position Advantage and Technological Innovation of China’s New Energy Vehicle Based on the Perspective of Network Theory

name: Tie Strength
define: Describes the closeness of cooperation between two nodes, measured by the ratio of the number of connections to the number of degrees, expressed by the number of patents for joint inventions.
source: Network Position Advantage and Technological Innovation of China’s New Energy Vehicle Based on the Perspective of Network Theory

name: Technological Niche’s Ecostate (TNS)
define: Measured by the number of approved patents in the node that year.
source: Network Position Advantage and Technological Innovation of China’s New Energy Vehicle Based on the Perspective of Network Theory

name: Technological Niche’s Ecorole (TNR)
define: Measured by the ratio of the number of authorized patents and base-period patents in a given year to the number of patents in the base period.
source: Network Position Advantage and Technological Innovation of China’s New Energy Vehicle Based on the Perspective of Network Theory

name: Technology Resource Category (TRC)
define: A control variable used to characterize the types of technological resources for innovation, based on the first four categories of patent classifications.
source: Network Position Advantage and Technological Innovation of China’s New Energy Vehicle Based on the Perspective of Network Theory

name: Firm Size
define: Measured by one time lagged log of sales.
source: Firm Growth and R&D in the Korean Pharmaceutical Industry

name: Firm Age
define: Established year of the firm and used the log of age.
source: Firm Growth and R&D in the Korean Pharmaceutical Industry

name: R&D Intensity
define: Calculated with R&D expenditure divided by one-period lag firm size and by one period lag asset, combined into a single composite index using principal component analysis (PCA).
source: Firm Growth and R&D in the Korean Pharmaceutical Industry

name: R&D Scale
define: A dummy variable which controls the effect of above-average R&D spending while controlling the effect of R&D intensity.
source: Firm Growth and R&D in the Korean Pharmaceutical Industry

name: Patent Persistence
define: A dummy variable to measure innovation activity, equals 1 if a company has a patent consecutively over the past 4 years.
source: Firm Growth and R&D in the Korean Pharmaceutical Industry

name: Growth Level
define: A dummy variable whose value is 1 if a firm growth rate is above industry median and 0 otherwise.
source: Firm Growth and R&D in the Korean Pharmaceutical Industry

name: Sales Growth Rate
define: Calculated using log difference of annual sales revenue.
source: Firm Growth and R&D in the Korean Pharmaceutical Industry

name: Collective Intelligence (CL)
define: A variable measured by co-invention, representing the intelligence of a group acting collectively.
source: Collective Intelligence: An Emerging World in Open Innovation

name: Open Innovation (OI)
define: A variable measured by the standardized multiple between the breadth of OI and the depth of OI, indicating technological collaboration in inventive activities.
source: Collective Intelligence: An Emerging World in Open Innovation

name: Firm Performance
define: A variable measured by three different dependent variables: the average number of sub-IPC, the ratio of disputed patents, and the ratio of transferred patents.
source: Collective Intelligence: An Emerging World in Open Innovation

name: Industry Type
define: A categorical variable distinguishing between the automotive industry and the pharmaceutical industry.
source: Collective Intelligence: An Emerging World in Open Innovation

name: Number of Patents
define: A control variable representing the size of the firm or the year of the firm.
source: Collective Intelligence: An Emerging World in Open Innovation

name: Product Development
define: A variable indicating whether a firm has a product development function.
source: Business Model Design for Latecomers in Biopharmaceutical Industry: The Case of Korean Firms

name: Business Diversification
define: The number of business areas a biopharmaceutical firm engaged in, serving as a proxy for the level of business diversification.
source: Business Model Design for Latecomers in Biopharmaceutical Industry: The Case of Korean Firms

name: R&D Alliances
define: The number of R&D alliances from 2005 to 2011, indicating the level of R&D collaboration.
source: Business Model Design for Latecomers in Biopharmaceutical Industry: The Case of Korean Firms

name: M&M Alliances
define: The number of manufacturing and marketing alliances from 2005 to 2011, indicating the level of strategic alliance in manufacturing and marketing.
source: Business Model Design for Latecomers in Biopharmaceutical Industry: The Case of Korean Firms

name: Firm Size
define: Defined as the number of employees, indicating the scale of the firm.
source: Business Model Design for Latecomers in Biopharmaceutical Industry: The Case of Korean Firms

name: Firm Age
define: Defined as the number of years since foundation, indicating the maturity of the firm.
source: Business Model Design for Latecomers in Biopharmaceutical Industry: The Case of Korean Firms

name: Government R&D Funding
define: Consists of both total government R&D fund and the total number of government R&D projects.
source: Business Model Design for Latecomers in Biopharmaceutical Industry: The Case of Korean Firms

name: R&D Intensity
define: Measured by the ratio of R&D expenditure to the number of employees.
source: Business Model Design for Latecomers in Biopharmaceutical Industry: The Case of Korean Firms

name: Technological Innovation Performance
define: Represented by the number of patents.
source: Business Model Design for Latecomers in Biopharmaceutical Industry: The Case of Korean Firms

name: Financial Performance
define: Measured by revenues, operating profit, and net profit.
source: Business Model Design for Latecomers in Biopharmaceutical Industry: The Case of Korean Firms

name: Technological Capability
define: A measure of the acquirer's R&D intensity prior to the M&A, used as a proxy for the firm's capability.
source: The Influence of a Firm’s Capability and Dyadic Relationship of the Knowledge Base on Ambidextrous Innovation in Biopharmaceutical M&As

name: Acquisition Experience
define: The number of M&As the acquirer firm went through before the year of the M&A, representing the firm's experience in M&As.
source: The Influence of a Firm’s Capability and Dyadic Relationship of the Knowledge Base on Ambidextrous Innovation in Biopharmaceutical M&As

name: Technological Commonness
define: The ratio of the same kinds of IPC codes shared by the acquirer and target out of the patents registered for the five years prior to the M&A.
source: The Influence of a Firm’s Capability and Dyadic Relationship of the Knowledge Base on Ambidextrous Innovation in Biopharmaceutical M&As

name: Technological Newness
define: The ratio of the kinds of IPC codes which existed only in the target out of the patents registered for the five years prior to the M&A.
source: The Influence of a Firm’s Capability and Dyadic Relationship of the Knowledge Base on Ambidextrous Innovation in Biopharmaceutical M&As

name: Firm Size
define: The natural logarithm of the number of employees, used as a control variable to account for the scale of the firm's operations.
source: The Influence of a Firm’s Capability and Dyadic Relationship of the Knowledge Base on Ambidextrous Innovation in Biopharmaceutical M&As

name: Firm Age
define: The number of years from the financial year on the relevant financial data to the year of the M&A, used as a control variable to account for the firm's longevity.
source: The Influence of a Firm’s Capability and Dyadic Relationship of the Knowledge Base on Ambidextrous Innovation in Biopharmaceutical M&As

name: M&A Period
define: A control variable indicating the time period of the M&A, with activities after the base point of 2007 set as 1 and before as 0.
source: The Influence of a Firm’s Capability and Dyadic Relationship of the Knowledge Base on Ambidextrous Innovation in Biopharmaceutical M&As

name: Exploitation Innovation Performance
define: A dependent variable measured by the number of patents after the M&A in the same areas as prior to the merger.
source: The Influence of a Firm’s Capability and Dyadic Relationship of the Knowledge Base on Ambidextrous Innovation in Biopharmaceutical M&As

name: Exploration Innovation Performance
define: A dependent variable measured by the number of patents after the M&A in areas which did not exist prior to the M&A.
source: The Influence of a Firm’s Capability and Dyadic Relationship of the Knowledge Base on Ambidextrous Innovation in Biopharmaceutical M&As

name: Innovation Ambidexterity
define: A measure based on the balance between exploitative and exploratory innovation activities, derived from patent data.
source: Alliance Network Diversity and Innovation Ambidexterity: The Differential Roles of Industrial Diversity, Geographical Diversity, and Functional Diversity

name: Industrial Diversity
define: Measured by the diversity of industries that a firm's alliance partners belong to, based on the four-digit SIC code.
source: Alliance Network Diversity and Innovation Ambidexterity: The Differential Roles of Industrial Diversity, Geographical Diversity, and Functional Diversity

name: Geographical Diversity
define: Measured by the diversity of countries that a firm's alliance partners are located in.
source: Alliance Network Diversity and Innovation Ambidexterity: The Differential Roles of Industrial Diversity, Geographical Diversity, and Functional Diversity

name: Functional Diversity
define: Measured by the diversity of functions or activities involved in a firm's alliances, such as R&D, marketing, manufacturing, etc.
source: Alliance Network Diversity and Innovation Ambidexterity: The Differential Roles of Industrial Diversity, Geographical Diversity, and Functional Diversity

name: Firm Size
define: Control variable, measured by the log-transformed total assets of a firm.
source: Alliance Network Diversity and Innovation Ambidexterity: The Differential Roles of Industrial Diversity, Geographical Diversity, and Functional Diversity

name: Firm Age
define: Control variable, representing the age of the firm.
source: Alliance Network Diversity and Innovation Ambidexterity: The Differential Roles of Industrial Diversity, Geographical Diversity, and Functional Diversity

name: Employee Number
define: Control variable, a binary indicator of whether the firm has 10,000 or more employees.
source: Alliance Network Diversity and Innovation Ambidexterity: The Differential Roles of Industrial Diversity, Geographical Diversity, and Functional Diversity

name: Biopharmaceutical
define: Control variable, a binary indicator for firms in the biopharmaceutical industry.
source: Alliance Network Diversity and Innovation Ambidexterity: The Differential Roles of Industrial Diversity, Geographical Diversity, and Functional Diversity

name: Europe
define: Control variable, a regional dummy for firms located in Europe.
source: Alliance Network Diversity and Innovation Ambidexterity: The Differential Roles of Industrial Diversity, Geographical Diversity, and Functional Diversity

name: North_America
define: Control variable, a regional dummy for firms located in North America.
source: Alliance Network Diversity and Innovation Ambidexterity: The Differential Roles of Industrial Diversity, Geographical Diversity, and Functional Diversity

name: Technology Cycle Time (TCT)
define: A measure of how fast an industry's or company's technology and knowledge domains become obsolete, calculated by averaging time lags between the publication years of citing and cited patents.
source: A Comparative Study of Sustainable Transition from Catch-up to Post Catch-up of South Korea and China

name: Self-Citation Ratio
define: The percentage of a country's patents that cite other patents from the same country, indicating the degree of localization of knowledge creation.
source: A Comparative Study of Sustainable Transition from Catch-up to Post Catch-up of South Korea and China

name: Basic Research Expenditure
define: The absolute expenditure on basic research activities and the gross domestic expenditure on basic research as a percentage (GDEB), indicating a country's investment in knowledge creation and technological advancement.
source: A Comparative Study of Sustainable Transition from Catch-up to Post Catch-up of South Korea and China

name: Gross Domestic Expenditure on Basic Research (GDEB)
define: The percentage of a country's GDP spent on basic research, reflecting the emphasis on foundational scientific development.
source: A Comparative Study of Sustainable Transition from Catch-up to Post Catch-up of South Korea and China

name: IPC Classification
define: International Patent Classification, used to categorize patents into different technology fields, indicating the focus areas of a country's innovation.
source: A Comparative Study of Sustainable Transition from Catch-up to Post Catch-up of South Korea and China

name: Firm Innovation
define: A composite measure of innovation quantity (IN_qn) and innovation quality (IN_ql) at the firm level.
source: Does Higher Education Promote Firm Innovation in China?

name: Higher Education
define: Measured by the number of colleges and universities (HigherEdu) and distinguished into elite higher education (Elite 1 and Elite 2) and non-elite higher education (nonElite1 and nonElite2).
source: Does Higher Education Promote Firm Innovation in China?

name: Firm Size
define: Measured by the sales of a firm (Size).
source: Does Higher Education Promote Firm Innovation in China?

name: Capital Intensity
define: Calculated by dividing the total assets of the firm by the number of employees (Intensity).
source: Does Higher Education Promote Firm Innovation in China?

name: Value of Firm Exports
define: Measured as the real value of exports (Export).
source: Does Higher Education Promote Firm Innovation in China?

name: Firm Age
define: Measured as the number of years since a firm had commenced operations (Age).
source: Does Higher Education Promote Firm Innovation in China?

name: Firm Ownership
define: Categorized into state-owned enterprises (SOEs), foreign-owned enterprises (FOEs), and privately owned enterprises (POEs) (Ownership).
source: Does Higher Education Promote Firm Innovation in China?

name: Elite Higher Education
define: Measured by the number of central universities (Elite 1) and universities in the '211 Project' (Elite 2).
source: Does Higher Education Promote Firm Innovation in China?

name: Non-Elite Higher Education
define: Measured by the number of colleges and universities not under the central government (nonElite1) and not in the '211 Project' (nonElite2).
source: Does Higher Education Promote Firm Innovation in China?

name: Industry Type
define: Distinguished into high-tech and non-high-tech enterprises.
source: Does Higher Education Promote Firm Innovation in China?

name: Technological Innovation
define: A broad category of developments that contribute to city innovation, including various technological fields.
source: Long-Term City Innovation Trajectories and Quality of Urban Life

name: Quality of Urban Life
define: A multi-dimensional concept that includes social, economic, and environmental perspectives affecting the well-being of city residents.
source: Long-Term City Innovation Trajectories and Quality of Urban Life

name: Urban Transformative Capacity
define: The ability of a city to absorb new knowledge and innovation, influencing its capacity to improve overall quality of life.
source: Long-Term City Innovation Trajectories and Quality of Urban Life

name: Path Dependence
define: A theory suggesting that technological developments evolve based on previous technological trajectories and choices.
source: Long-Term City Innovation Trajectories and Quality of Urban Life

name: Digital Technologies
define: Technologies related to information and communication, which have seen explosive growth and contribute to the transformation towards smart cities.
source: Long-Term City Innovation Trajectories and Quality of Urban Life

name: Environmental Sustainability
define: The consideration of environmental impacts in the development of new technologies, reflecting growing concerns for sustainability.
source: Long-Term City Innovation Trajectories and Quality of Urban Life

name: Institution Settings
define: The formal and informal rules that influence the direction and pace of technological innovation and city transformation.
source: Long-Term City Innovation Trajectories and Quality of Urban Life

name: ICT-related Technological Development
define: Technological advancements in the field of information and communication technologies, which are crucial for smart city development.
source: Long-Term City Innovation Trajectories and Quality of Urban Life

name: Non-ICT-related Technological Development
define: Technological advancements outside the ICT field that also contribute to city innovation and quality of life.
source: Long-Term City Innovation Trajectories and Quality of Urban Life

name: Patent Data
define: Data from the European Patent Office used to analyze the trajectories of technological developments over time.
source: Long-Term City Innovation Trajectories and Quality of Urban Life

name: Organizations’ Structural Holes
define: A measure indicating the extent of organizations’ disconnected network contacts in the scientific cooperation network.
source: How Does Inter-Organizational Cooperation Impact Organizations’ Scientific Knowledge Generation? Evidence from the Biomass Energy Field

name: Organizations’ Degree Centrality of Scientific Cooperation Network
define: A measure representing the amount of accessed external knowledge by the central position of the network.
source: How Does Inter-Organizational Cooperation Impact Organizations’ Scientific Knowledge Generation? Evidence from the Biomass Energy Field

name: Density of Industrial Scientific Cooperation Network
define: A measure indicating the average frequency of contacts among organizations in the industrial scientific cooperation network.
source: How Does Inter-Organizational Cooperation Impact Organizations’ Scientific Knowledge Generation? Evidence from the Biomass Energy Field

name: Organizations’ Degree Centrality of Technical Cooperation Network
define: A measure indicating the organizations’ network position of technical cooperation network.
source: How Does Inter-Organizational Cooperation Impact Organizations’ Scientific Knowledge Generation? Evidence from the Biomass Energy Field

name: Organizations’ Scientific Knowledge Generation
define: A measure represented by the number of published articles by organizations.
source: How Does Inter-Organizational Cooperation Impact Organizations’ Scientific Knowledge Generation? Evidence from the Biomass Energy Field

name: Absorptive Capacity
define: A firm’s ability to acquire and assimilate external knowledge, measured by the number of patent applications and in-licensing agreements.
source: Factors Affecting Outbound Open Innovation Performance in Bio-Pharmaceutical Industry-Focus on Out-Licensing Deals

name: Desorptive Capacity
define: A firm’s ability to externalize internal knowledge assets, measured by the number of forward citation patents and out-licensing agreements.
source: Factors Affecting Outbound Open Innovation Performance in Bio-Pharmaceutical Industry-Focus on Out-Licensing Deals

name: Connective Capacity
define: A firm’s ability to maintain knowledge in inter-firm relationships, measured by the number of same IPC codes and R&D collaborations.
source: Factors Affecting Outbound Open Innovation Performance in Bio-Pharmaceutical Industry-Focus on Out-Licensing Deals

name: R&D Intensity
define: The ratio of R&D expenditures to the firm’s total expenditures, indicating the relative importance of R&D within the firm.
source: Factors Affecting Outbound Open Innovation Performance in Bio-Pharmaceutical Industry-Focus on Out-Licensing Deals

name: Firm Size
define: The number of employees, used as a proxy for the size of the firm.
source: Factors Affecting Outbound Open Innovation Performance in Bio-Pharmaceutical Industry-Focus on Out-Licensing Deals

name: Financial Performance
define: The average sales over three years after licensing, used as a measure of the firm's economic performance.
source: Factors Affecting Outbound Open Innovation Performance in Bio-Pharmaceutical Industry-Focus on Out-Licensing Deals

name: Environmental Information Disclosure (EID)
define: A measure of how extensively a company discloses information related to its environmental impact and policies.
source: Does Environmental Information Disclosure Affect the Sustainable Development of Enterprises: The Role of Green Innovation

name: Green Innovation (GI)
define: The processes, technologies, and products that reduce the consumption of energy and raw materials, as well as environmental pollution, promoting sustainable development.
source: Does Environmental Information Disclosure Affect the Sustainable Development of Enterprises: The Role of Green Innovation

name: Government Subsidies for Energy-Saving Innovation
define: Financial incentives provided by the government to support energy-saving and environmental protection innovations.
source: Does Environmental Information Disclosure Affect the Sustainable Development of Enterprises: The Role of Green Innovation

name: Media Attention
define: The extent of coverage and attention given to a company's environmental performance by media outlets.
source: Does Environmental Information Disclosure Affect the Sustainable Development of Enterprises: The Role of Green Innovation

name: Debt Financing Costs
define: The costs associated with borrowing money, including interest expenses, for a company.
source: Does Environmental Information Disclosure Affect the Sustainable Development of Enterprises: The Role of Green Innovation

name: Enterprise Scale
define: The size of the enterprise, which can influence its ability to control resources and cultivate employees.
source: Does Environmental Information Disclosure Affect the Sustainable Development of Enterprises: The Role of Green Innovation

name: Age
define: The number of years the company has been listed, which may affect its innovation consciousness and structure.
source: Does Environmental Information Disclosure Affect the Sustainable Development of Enterprises: The Role of Green Innovation

name: Financial Leverage
define: The ratio of total liabilities to total assets, indicating the company's debt burden.
source: Does Environmental Information Disclosure Affect the Sustainable Development of Enterprises: The Role of Green Innovation

name: Capital Intensity
define: A measure of the company's fixed assets per capita, which can influence its innovation and environmental protection activities.
source: Does Environmental Information Disclosure Affect the Sustainable Development of Enterprises: The Role of Green Innovation

name: Competitiveness
define: The ratio of operating profit to main business income, reflecting the company's market competitiveness.
source: Does Environmental Information Disclosure Affect the Sustainable Development of Enterprises: The Role of Green Innovation

name: Tobin’s Q
define: A measure of a company's market value relative to the replacement value of its assets, indicating corporate performance.
source: Does Environmental Information Disclosure Affect the Sustainable Development of Enterprises: The Role of Green Innovation

name: Technology Innovation (PAT)
define: The number of patent applications authorized to characterize the level of technology innovation.
source: Technology Innovation, Economic Growth and Carbon Emissions in the Context of Carbon Neutrality: Evidence from BRICS

name: Economic Growth (EG)
define: Per capita GDP (in 2010 USD constant price) and its quadratic term to verify the EKC hypothesis.
source: Technology Innovation, Economic Growth and Carbon Emissions in the Context of Carbon Neutrality: Evidence from BRICS

name: Carbon Emissions (CE)
define: Per capita carbon emissions, measured in metric tons.
source: Technology Innovation, Economic Growth and Carbon Emissions in the Context of Carbon Neutrality: Evidence from BRICS

name: Urbanization (URB)
define: The percentage of urban population to total population.
source: Technology Innovation, Economic Growth and Carbon Emissions in the Context of Carbon Neutrality: Evidence from BRICS

name: Fixed Capital Formation (CAP)
define: An indicator of investment, which is an important driving force of energy consumption.
source: Technology Innovation, Economic Growth and Carbon Emissions in the Context of Carbon Neutrality: Evidence from BRICS

name: Industry Development (IND)
define: The ratio of industrial added value to regional GDP, reflecting the impact of industrial structure on carbon emission.
source: Technology Innovation, Economic Growth and Carbon Emissions in the Context of Carbon Neutrality: Evidence from BRICS

name: Network Centrality
define: A measure of the central position of an enterprise within the IUR network, indicating the ability to establish connections and use resources.
source: Research on the Performance of Knowledge Co-Creation of Science and Technology Enterprises Based on IUR Network

name: Absorptive Capacity
define: The ability of an enterprise to acquire, digest, convert, and apply external network knowledge.
source: Research on the Performance of Knowledge Co-Creation of Science and Technology Enterprises Based on IUR Network

name: Knowledge Co-Creation Performance
define: The new knowledge created by network members in the process of knowledge sharing and knowledge collision, such as jointly-developed new products, signed cooperative projects, and jointly-applied patents.
source: Research on the Performance of Knowledge Co-Creation of Science and Technology Enterprises Based on IUR Network

name: Age
define: The age of the enterprise, calculated as the year of data collection minus the year of establishment.
source: Research on the Performance of Knowledge Co-Creation of Science and Technology Enterprises Based on IUR Network

name: Size
define: The size of the company, calculated as the company’s registered capital.
source: Research on the Performance of Knowledge Co-Creation of Science and Technology Enterprises Based on IUR Network

name: Debt to Asset Ratio
define: A financial metric calculated as liabilities/total assets.
source: Research on the Performance of Knowledge Co-Creation of Science and Technology Enterprises Based on IUR Network

name: Technological Innovation System (TIS)
define: A system that involves various interacting actors and includes the development, application, and diffusion of a particular focal technology.
source: Mapping the Territorial Adaptation of Technological Innovation Systems—Trajectories of the Internal Combustion Engine

name: Technological Trajectory
define: The cumulative, path-dependent progress of a technology within a technological paradigm.
source: Mapping the Territorial Adaptation of Technological Innovation Systems—Trajectories of the Internal Combustion Engine

name: Internal Combustion Engine (ICE)
define: A type of engine that has been under increasing transformational pressure due to societal concerns about environmental pollution.
source: Mapping the Territorial Adaptation of Technological Innovation Systems—Trajectories of the Internal Combustion Engine

name: Patent Citation Networks
define: Networks used to measure the technological adaptation by identifying the most important knowledge search processes.
source: Mapping the Territorial Adaptation of Technological Innovation Systems—Trajectories of the Internal Combustion Engine

name: Transformational Pressures
define: Pressures initiated by developments in the TIS or its context, such as competing technologies, loss of policy support, and changing societal expectations.
source: Mapping the Territorial Adaptation of Technological Innovation Systems—Trajectories of the Internal Combustion Engine

name: Hybrid Powertrains
define: A type of powertrain that combines an internal combustion engine with an electric motor, becoming the dominant alternative powertrains in some markets.
source: Mapping the Territorial Adaptation of Technological Innovation Systems—Trajectories of the Internal Combustion Engine

name: Diesel Technology
define: A technology that has been the dominant focus in the EU territory, in contrast to the rise of hybrid powertrains in the USA and Japan.
source: Mapping the Territorial Adaptation of Technological Innovation Systems—Trajectories of the Internal Combustion Engine

name: Policy Regulation
define: A key difference in the territorial TIS structures, influencing the disparity in the adaptation process of the ICE-TIS.
source: Mapping the Territorial Adaptation of Technological Innovation Systems—Trajectories of the Internal Combustion Engine

name: Spatial Development
define: The development of TIS across different territories, influenced by territorial context conditions such as resources, regulations, and competition.
source: Mapping the Territorial Adaptation of Technological Innovation Systems—Trajectories of the Internal Combustion Engine

name: Knowledge Search Process
define: The process influenced by the dominant trajectory, which determines the direction of knowledge search and accumulation in the TIS.
source: Mapping the Territorial Adaptation of Technological Innovation Systems—Trajectories of the Internal Combustion Engine

name: Innovation Performance
define: Measured by the number of invention patents granted in the year following the innovation network period.
source: The Impact of a Multilevel Innovation Network and Government Support on Innovation Performance—An Empirical Study of the Chengdu–Chongqing City Cluster

name: Average Weighted Degree (AWD)
define: A measure of the average linkages of the network among all innovators, reflecting the contact intensity of the overall innovation network.
source: The Impact of a Multilevel Innovation Network and Government Support on Innovation Performance—An Empirical Study of the Chengdu–Chongqing City Cluster

name: Network Density (D)
define: Measured by the number of actual relationships between nodes in the network to the maximum possible number of relationships among nodes, reflecting the tightness of the overall network.
source: The Impact of a Multilevel Innovation Network and Government Support on Innovation Performance—An Empirical Study of the Chengdu–Chongqing City Cluster

name: Betweenness Centrality (BC)
define: A measure of the extent to which a node acts as an intermediary, the degree of access to resources, or the way it controls them.
source: The Impact of a Multilevel Innovation Network and Government Support on Innovation Performance—An Empirical Study of the Chengdu–Chongqing City Cluster

name: Cooperation Intensity (CI)
define: Refers to the average number of cooperation between a node and other nodes, reflecting its ability to obtain innovation resources.
source: The Impact of a Multilevel Innovation Network and Government Support on Innovation Performance—An Empirical Study of the Chengdu–Chongqing City Cluster

name: Government Support (GOV)
define: Measured by the proportion of government expenditures on science and technology in government fiscal expenditures.
source: The Impact of a Multilevel Innovation Network and Government Support on Innovation Performance—An Empirical Study of the Chengdu–Chongqing City Cluster

name: Economic Development Level (PGDP)
define: Reflects the economic development level of the city, measured by the per capita gross regional product.
source: The Impact of a Multilevel Innovation Network and Government Support on Innovation Performance—An Empirical Study of the Chengdu–Chongqing City Cluster

name: R&D Expenditure (RD)
define: Reflects the investment intensity of innovation, measured by the internal expenditure of R&D.
source: The Impact of a Multilevel Innovation Network and Government Support on Innovation Performance—An Empirical Study of the Chengdu–Chongqing City Cluster

name: Openness of the City (OP)
define: Measured by the total amount of foreign investment actually utilized.
source: The Impact of a Multilevel Innovation Network and Government Support on Innovation Performance—An Empirical Study of the Chengdu–Chongqing City Cluster

name: Government Intervention (GI)
define: Measured by the proportion of local general public budget expenditure in the gross regional product.
source: The Impact of a Multilevel Innovation Network and Government Support on Innovation Performance—An Empirical Study of the Chengdu–Chongqing City Cluster

name: Knowledge Accumulation in the City (CKB)
define: Measured by the number of city patents granted during the past five years.
source: The Impact of a Multilevel Innovation Network and Government Support on Innovation Performance—An Empirical Study of the Chengdu–Chongqing City Cluster

name: External Partnering
define: A variable measuring whether the firm had collaborated on innovation activities with external partners.
source: Open Innovation and Sustainable Innovation Performance: The Moderating Role of IP Strategic Planning and IP Operation

name: External Sourcing
define: A variable measuring the importance of external sources for innovation-related knowledge or information.
source: Open Innovation and Sustainable Innovation Performance: The Moderating Role of IP Strategic Planning and IP Operation

name: IP Strategic Planning
define: A binary variable measuring the presence of an IP strategic plan for intellectual property projects.
source: Open Innovation and Sustainable Innovation Performance: The Moderating Role of IP Strategic Planning and IP Operation

name: IP Operation
define: A binary variable measuring whether the firm has operationalized IP strategy using consistent IP tools.
source: Open Innovation and Sustainable Innovation Performance: The Moderating Role of IP Strategic Planning and IP Operation

name: Sustainable Innovation Performance
define: A variable measuring the outcome of the firm’s innovation activities with respect to economic, environmental, and social aspects.
source: Open Innovation and Sustainable Innovation Performance: The Moderating Role of IP Strategic Planning and IP Operation

name: R&D Intensity
define: A variable measured as the ratio of R&D expenditure to sales.
source: Open Innovation and Sustainable Innovation Performance: The Moderating Role of IP Strategic Planning and IP Operation

name: Firm Size
define: A categorical variable based on the number of employees.
source: Open Innovation and Sustainable Innovation Performance: The Moderating Role of IP Strategic Planning and IP Operation

name: Firm Age
define: A variable measured as years from the establishment of the firm.
source: Open Innovation and Sustainable Innovation Performance: The Moderating Role of IP Strategic Planning and IP Operation

name: Industry Dummies
define: Variables used to control for differences across industries in innovation behavior.
source: Open Innovation and Sustainable Innovation Performance: The Moderating Role of IP Strategic Planning and IP Operation

name: BGRM Centrality
define: A bipartite ranking algorithm that provides centrality estimates for nodes in a bipartite network, indicating the importance of a firm in the technology transfer network.
source: University–Industry Technology Transfer: Empirical Findings from Chinese Industrial Firms

name: BiRank Centrality
define: Another bipartite ranking algorithm similar to BGRM, used to measure the centrality of nodes in the bipartite network.
source: University–Industry Technology Transfer: Empirical Findings from Chinese Industrial Firms

name: Innovation Output
define: Measured by the number of patent applications, representing the innovative output of a firm.
source: University–Industry Technology Transfer: Empirical Findings from Chinese Industrial Firms

name: Firm History
define: The number of years elapsed since the firm was established, used as an explanatory variable.
source: University–Industry Technology Transfer: Empirical Findings from Chinese Industrial Firms

name: Number of Employees
define: The number of laborers at the firm, used as an explanatory variable.
source: University–Industry Technology Transfer: Empirical Findings from Chinese Industrial Firms

name: License Contracts
define: The number of contracts between a university and a firm, used as a weight in the network analysis.
source: University–Industry Technology Transfer: Empirical Findings from Chinese Industrial Firms

name: Geographical Location
define: The location of the universities and firms, which may influence the technology transfer and innovation output.
source: University–Industry Technology Transfer: Empirical Findings from Chinese Industrial Firms

name: Economic Development
define: The level of economic development in the region where the firm is located, which may affect the innovation output.
source: University–Industry Technology Transfer: Empirical Findings from Chinese Industrial Firms

name: Patent Licensing Networks
define: Networks that present small-world phenomena and are related to the technology transfer process.
source: University–Industry Technology Transfer: Empirical Findings from Chinese Industrial Firms

name: R&D Resources
define: Resources allocated for research and development, which may vary across different regions in China.
source: University–Industry Technology Transfer: Empirical Findings from Chinese Industrial Firms

name: Technology Transfer Performance
define: The performance of technology transfer, which is influenced by various factors including centrality.
source: University–Industry Technology Transfer: Empirical Findings from Chinese Industrial Firms

name: Green Finance Reform Initiative (GFRI)
define: A policy initiative by the Chinese government to develop a green economy.
source: How Does Green Finance Reform Affect Enterprise Green Technology Innovation? Evidence from China

name: Enterprise Green Technology Innovation
define: Innovations made by enterprises in green technology, measured by the number of green patent applications.
source: How Does Green Finance Reform Affect Enterprise Green Technology Innovation? Evidence from China

name: Internal Financing Constraint (IFC)
define: A measure of how much an enterprise relies on its internal resources for financing, calculated as (current assets - current liabilities)/total assets.
source: How Does Green Finance Reform Affect Enterprise Green Technology Innovation? Evidence from China

name: External Financing Constraint (EFC)
define: A measure of an enterprise's dependence on external resources for financing, calculated as interest expense/total assets.
source: How Does Green Finance Reform Affect Enterprise Green Technology Innovation? Evidence from China

name: Enterprise Size (Lnsize)
define: The natural logarithm of the total assets at the end of the year, representing the size of the enterprise.
source: How Does Green Finance Reform Affect Enterprise Green Technology Innovation? Evidence from China

name: Enterprise Age (Age)
define: The age of the enterprise, calculated as the statistical year minus the year of establishment plus one.
source: How Does Green Finance Reform Affect Enterprise Green Technology Innovation? Evidence from China

name: Tobin's Q Ratio (TobinQ)
define: The ratio of the market value of an enterprise to its replacement capital value, indicating the enterprise's wealth creation ability.
source: How Does Green Finance Reform Affect Enterprise Green Technology Innovation? Evidence from China

name: Gearing Ratio (Lev)
define: The ratio of end-of-period liabilities to end-of-period assets, representing the financial leverage of the enterprise.
source: How Does Green Finance Reform Affect Enterprise Green Technology Innovation? Evidence from China

name: Return on Assets (ROA)
define: The net profit of an enterprise divided by its total assets, indicating the enterprise's profitability.
source: How Does Green Finance Reform Affect Enterprise Green Technology Innovation? Evidence from China

name: Location of Enterprises
define: The geographical location of the enterprises, divided into eastern, central, and western regions of China.
source: How Does Green Finance Reform Affect Enterprise Green Technology Innovation? Evidence from China

name: Ownership of Enterprises
define: The ownership structure of the enterprises, categorized as state-owned and non-state-owned.
source: How Does Green Finance Reform Affect Enterprise Green Technology Innovation? Evidence from China

name: Environmental Regulation (ER)
define: The intensity of environmental regulation, measured by the proportion of industrial pollution control investment on the main business income for industrial enterprises.
source: Environmental Regulation, Environmental Knowledge Spillover, and Regional Economic Growth in China: An Empirical Test Based on the Spatial Durbin Model

name: Environmental Knowledge Spillover (EKS)
define: The green knowledge stock in a region, measured by the number of green patents using the perpetual inventory method.
source: Environmental Regulation, Environmental Knowledge Spillover, and Regional Economic Growth in China: An Empirical Test Based on the Spatial Durbin Model

name: Regional Economic Growth (PGDP)
define: The per capita GDP of each province and city, measured in actual per capita GDP data based on the year 2000.
source: Environmental Regulation, Environmental Knowledge Spillover, and Regional Economic Growth in China: An Empirical Test Based on the Spatial Durbin Model

name: Research and Development Investment Expenditure (RD)
define: The internal expenditure of R&D funds in each region.
source: Environmental Regulation, Environmental Knowledge Spillover, and Regional Economic Growth in China: An Empirical Test Based on the Spatial Durbin Model

name: Level of Human Capital (Edu)
define: The number of years of education per capita in each region.
source: Environmental Regulation, Environmental Knowledge Spillover, and Regional Economic Growth in China: An Empirical Test Based on the Spatial Durbin Model

name: Level of Science and Technology (Ti)
define: The proportion of science and technology expenditure versus the general government budget expenditure.
source: Environmental Regulation, Environmental Knowledge Spillover, and Regional Economic Growth in China: An Empirical Test Based on the Spatial Durbin Model

name: Level of Urbanization (Urb)
define: The proportion of the urban population.
source: Environmental Regulation, Environmental Knowledge Spillover, and Regional Economic Growth in China: An Empirical Test Based on the Spatial Durbin Model

name: Level of Government Intervention (Gov)
define: The general public budget revenue.
source: Environmental Regulation, Environmental Knowledge Spillover, and Regional Economic Growth in China: An Empirical Test Based on the Spatial Durbin Model

name: Level of Opening to the Outside World (Open)
define: The total import and export of goods in each region, adjusted to RMB based on the current exchange rate.
source: Environmental Regulation, Environmental Knowledge Spillover, and Regional Economic Growth in China: An Empirical Test Based on the Spatial Durbin Model

name: High-Speed Rail (HSR)
define: A binary variable indicating whether a city has High-Speed Rail.
source: The Inﬂuencing Mechanism of High-Speed Rail on Innovation: Firm-Level Evidence from China

name: Firm Innovation
define: Measured by the number of patents applied for and authorized patents.
source: The Inﬂuencing Mechanism of High-Speed Rail on Innovation: Firm-Level Evidence from China

name: Knowledge Spillover
define: The effect of knowledge diffusion and exchange between firms and regions.
source: The Inﬂuencing Mechanism of High-Speed Rail on Innovation: Firm-Level Evidence from China

name: Resource Allocation
define: The efficiency of firm resource allocation, including R&D investment and talent acquisition.
source: The Inﬂuencing Mechanism of High-Speed Rail on Innovation: Firm-Level Evidence from China

name: Market Size
define: The scale of the product market for firms, affected by HSR.
source: The Inﬂuencing Mechanism of High-Speed Rail on Innovation: Firm-Level Evidence from China

name: Firm Size
define: The size of the firm, including total assets and employment.
source: The Inﬂuencing Mechanism of High-Speed Rail on Innovation: Firm-Level Evidence from China

name: City Size
define: The population size of the city, used to determine the threshold effect.
source: The Inﬂuencing Mechanism of High-Speed Rail on Innovation: Firm-Level Evidence from China

name: Technological Updating Speed
define: The speed at which technology becomes obsolete, categorized as high or low velocity technologies.
source: The Inﬂuencing Mechanism of High-Speed Rail on Innovation: Firm-Level Evidence from China

name: Firm Innovation Capability
define: The innovation ability of firms, categorized by the number of patents.
source: The Inﬂuencing Mechanism of High-Speed Rail on Innovation: Firm-Level Evidence from China

name: HSR Operating Quality
define: The quality of HSR operation, measured by the number of stations and lines.
source: The Inﬂuencing Mechanism of High-Speed Rail on Innovation: Firm-Level Evidence from China

name: Cultural Industry Competitiveness Index (CI)
define: A composite index evaluating the competitiveness of the cultural industry in Chinese provinces.
source: Quantifying the Competitiveness of Cultural Industry and Its Impacts on Chinese Economic Growth

name: Gross Domestic Product (GDP) Growth Rate
define: The year-over-year change in a region’s economic output.
source: Quantifying the Competitiveness of Cultural Industry and Its Impacts on Chinese Economic Growth

name: Total Investment in Fixed Assets (Inv)
define: The purchase of newly produced fixed capital.
source: Quantifying the Competitiveness of Cultural Industry and Its Impacts on Chinese Economic Growth

name: Number of Employed Persons (EP)
define: The number of people engaged in productive activities in an economy.
source: Quantifying the Competitiveness of Cultural Industry and Its Impacts on Chinese Economic Growth

name: R&D Expenditure Input Intensity (RDE)
define: R&D expenditure as a percentage of gross domestic product.
source: Quantifying the Competitiveness of Cultural Industry and Its Impacts on Chinese Economic Growth

name: Fixed Asset Investment in Culture (X1)
define: Capital element of the cultural industry.
source: Quantifying the Competitiveness of Cultural Industry and Its Impacts on Chinese Economic Growth

name: Labor in Cultural Enterprises (X2)
define: Labor element of the cultural industry.
source: Quantifying the Competitiveness of Cultural Industry and Its Impacts on Chinese Economic Growth

name: Total Collections in Public Libraries (X4)
define: Cultural elements of the cultural industry.
source: Quantifying the Competitiveness of Cultural Industry and Its Impacts on Chinese Economic Growth

name: Proportion of Tertiary Industry in Gross Regional Product (X5)
define: Demand conditions of the cultural industry.
source: Quantifying the Competitiveness of Cultural Industry and Its Impacts on Chinese Economic Growth

name: Per Capita Consumption and Expenditure on Culture and Recreation of Nationwide Households (X6)
define: Consumer behavior related to the cultural industry.
source: Quantifying the Competitiveness of Cultural Industry and Its Impacts on Chinese Economic Growth

name: Users of Cable Radios and TVs (X8)
define: Operations and management related to the cultural industry.
source: Quantifying the Competitiveness of Cultural Industry and Its Impacts on Chinese Economic Growth

name: Renewable Energy Consumption (REC)
define: The share of renewable energy in total energy consumption.
source: Role of Innovations to Mitigate CO2e: Theory and Evidence for European Economies

name: Non-Renewable Energy Consumption (NREC)
define: The share of non-renewable energy in total final energy consumption.
source: Role of Innovations to Mitigate CO2e: Theory and Evidence for European Economies

name: Innovation (I)
define: Measured through Patent Resident and Patent Non-Resident.
source: Role of Innovations to Mitigate CO2e: Theory and Evidence for European Economies

name: Gross Domestic Product (GDP)
define: Represents economic growth, measured in constant 2010 dollars.
source: Role of Innovations to Mitigate CO2e: Theory and Evidence for European Economies

name: Urbanization (URB)
define: The urbanization rate in the respective countries.
source: Role of Innovations to Mitigate CO2e: Theory and Evidence for European Economies

name: Carbon Dioxide Emissions (CO2e)
define: The environmental indicator measured in metric tons.
source: Role of Innovations to Mitigate CO2e: Theory and Evidence for European Economies

name: Enterprise Innovation
define: A variable measured by R&D investment divided by total assets, and alternatively by the number of granted patents.
source: Intellectual Property Pledge Financing and Enterprise Innovation: Based on the Perspective of Signal Incentive

name: Intellectual Property Pledge Financing (IPPF)
define: A binary variable indicating whether a city implemented the IPPF policy in a given year.
source: Intellectual Property Pledge Financing and Enterprise Innovation: Based on the Perspective of Signal Incentive

name: Managerial Myopia
define: A variable measured indirectly through machine learning techniques for text analysis, based on the frequency of words related to the 'short-term horizon' stated by managers.
source: Intellectual Property Pledge Financing and Enterprise Innovation: Based on the Perspective of Signal Incentive

name: Manager Risk Preference
define: A variable measured by the ratio of the annual total amount invested in high-risk options to the current year’s total assets.
source: Intellectual Property Pledge Financing and Enterprise Innovation: Based on the Perspective of Signal Incentive

name: Bank Financing
define: A variable measured by long-term loans and the long-term loans ratio.
source: Intellectual Property Pledge Financing and Enterprise Innovation: Based on the Perspective of Signal Incentive

name: Investor Sentiment
define: A variable measured using the Rhodes-Kropf method, which involves the market valuation (Tobin q) of an enterprise.
source: Intellectual Property Pledge Financing and Enterprise Innovation: Based on the Perspective of Signal Incentive

name: Control Variables
define: Includes enterprise age, shareholder structure, the percentage of independent directors, return on assets, and the logarithmically transformed gross regional product.
source: Intellectual Property Pledge Financing and Enterprise Innovation: Based on the Perspective of Signal Incentive

name: Green Innovation Level
define: Measured by the volume of green innovation patent applications filed annually in the sample cities.
source: Exploring the Demand-Pull Effect on Green Innovation and Its Spatial Spillover Effects: Evidence from 261 Chinese Prefecture-Level Cities

name: Domestic Demand Level
define: Calculated using per capita disposable income of the population.
source: Exploring the Demand-Pull Effect on Green Innovation and Its Spatial Spillover Effects: Evidence from 261 Chinese Prefecture-Level Cities

name: Foreign Demand Level
define: Gauged by the sum of all regional exports.
source: Exploring the Demand-Pull Effect on Green Innovation and Its Spatial Spillover Effects: Evidence from 261 Chinese Prefecture-Level Cities

name: Demand Structure
define: Represented by the Theil index, indicating income distribution and demand structure.
source: Exploring the Demand-Pull Effect on Green Innovation and Its Spatial Spillover Effects: Evidence from 261 Chinese Prefecture-Level Cities

name: Market Segmentation
define: Assesses the degree of market segmentation and its potential moderating role on the influence of demand factors on green innovation.
source: Exploring the Demand-Pull Effect on Green Innovation and Its Spatial Spillover Effects: Evidence from 261 Chinese Prefecture-Level Cities

name: Regional Industrial Structure
define: The value contributed by the secondary industry in an area.
source: Exploring the Demand-Pull Effect on Green Innovation and Its Spatial Spillover Effects: Evidence from 261 Chinese Prefecture-Level Cities

name: Population
define: The number of permanent residents in the city.
source: Exploring the Demand-Pull Effect on Green Innovation and Its Spatial Spillover Effects: Evidence from 261 Chinese Prefecture-Level Cities

name: Government Influence on Innovation
define: The ratio of government spending on technology to fiscal spending.
source: Exploring the Demand-Pull Effect on Green Innovation and Its Spatial Spillover Effects: Evidence from 261 Chinese Prefecture-Level Cities

name: Educational Attainment of Residents
define: The ratio of education spending to fiscal expenditure.
source: Exploring the Demand-Pull Effect on Green Innovation and Its Spatial Spillover Effects: Evidence from 261 Chinese Prefecture-Level Cities

name: Degree of Foreign Openness
define: The ratio of foreign direct investment (FDI) to gross domestic product (GDP) per capita.
source: Exploring the Demand-Pull Effect on Green Innovation and Its Spatial Spillover Effects: Evidence from 261 Chinese Prefecture-Level Cities

name: Strategic Emerging Industry Support Program
define: A government initiative aimed at promoting industrial upgrading and facilitating industrial transformation in China.
source: Effect of the Strategic Emerging Industry Support Program on Corporate Innovation among Listed Companies in China

name: R&D Investment
define: The research and development expenditure of a firm, used as a measure of innovation input.
source: Effect of the Strategic Emerging Industry Support Program on Corporate Innovation among Listed Companies in China

name: Patent Output
define: The number of patents granted to a firm, used as a measure of innovation output.
source: Effect of the Strategic Emerging Industry Support Program on Corporate Innovation among Listed Companies in China

name: Innovation Efficiency
define: The ratio of the number of patents granted to R&D investment, indicating how efficiently a firm is innovating.
source: Effect of the Strategic Emerging Industry Support Program on Corporate Innovation among Listed Companies in China

name: Innovation Quality
define: The ratio of granted invention patents to the total number of granted patents, indicating the quality of innovation.
source: Effect of the Strategic Emerging Industry Support Program on Corporate Innovation among Listed Companies in China

name: Government Subsidies
define: Financial support provided by the government to firms in strategic emerging industries.
source: Effect of the Strategic Emerging Industry Support Program on Corporate Innovation among Listed Companies in China

name: Tax Benefits
define: Tax incentives provided by the government to encourage R&D and innovation.
source: Effect of the Strategic Emerging Industry Support Program on Corporate Innovation among Listed Companies in China

name: Credit
define: The difference between current long-term borrowings and prior period long-term borrowings as a percentage of total assets, indicating access to finance.
source: Effect of the Strategic Emerging Industry Support Program on Corporate Innovation among Listed Companies in China

name: Stock Liquidity
define: The annual average daily turnover index calculated by the Amihud measure, indicating the liquidity of a firm's stock.
source: Effect of the Strategic Emerging Industry Support Program on Corporate Innovation among Listed Companies in China

name: Firm Age
define: The current year time minus the company’s IPO time, used as a control variable.
source: Effect of the Strategic Emerging Industry Support Program on Corporate Innovation among Listed Companies in China

name: Firm Size
define: The logarithm of total assets at the end of the period, used as a control variable.
source: Effect of the Strategic Emerging Industry Support Program on Corporate Innovation among Listed Companies in China

name: National Innovative City Policy (NICP)
define: A dummy variable indicating the implementation of the National Innovative City Policy.
source: Impact of National Innovative City Policy on Enterprise Green Technology Innovation—Mediation Role of Innovation Environment and R&D Investment

name: Green Patents Granted (Pataut, Pataut-utility, Pataut-invention)
define: Dependent variables representing the total number of green patents, green utility patents, and green invention patents granted to an enterprise in a year.
source: Impact of National Innovative City Policy on Enterprise Green Technology Innovation—Mediation Role of Innovation Environment and R&D Investment

name: Firm Size (Size)
define: A control variable representing the logarithm of total assets at the year end.
source: Impact of National Innovative City Policy on Enterprise Green Technology Innovation—Mediation Role of Innovation Environment and R&D Investment

name: Cash Holdings (Cash)
define: A control variable representing the ratio of cash and cash equivalents to total assets at the year end.
source: Impact of National Innovative City Policy on Enterprise Green Technology Innovation—Mediation Role of Innovation Environment and R&D Investment

name: Capital Expenditure (lnoutcap)
define: A control variable representing the logarithm of capital expenditure.
source: Impact of National Innovative City Policy on Enterprise Green Technology Innovation—Mediation Role of Innovation Environment and R&D Investment

name: Return on Assets (Roa)
define: A control variable representing the net profit divided by average total assets.
source: Impact of National Innovative City Policy on Enterprise Green Technology Innovation—Mediation Role of Innovation Environment and R&D Investment

name: Capital Intensity (Density)
define: A control variable representing the ratio of total assets at the year end to sales.
source: Impact of National Innovative City Policy on Enterprise Green Technology Innovation—Mediation Role of Innovation Environment and R&D Investment

name: Proportion of Independent Directors (Ind)
define: A control variable representing the proportion of independent directors on the board.
source: Impact of National Innovative City Policy on Enterprise Green Technology Innovation—Mediation Role of Innovation Environment and R&D Investment

name: Board Size (Board)
define: A control variable representing the logarithm of the number of board members.
source: Impact of National Innovative City Policy on Enterprise Green Technology Innovation—Mediation Role of Innovation Environment and R&D Investment

name: Urban Innovation Index (UII)
define: A mediating variable representing the quality of the innovation environment in a city.
source: Impact of National Innovative City Policy on Enterprise Green Technology Innovation—Mediation Role of Innovation Environment and R&D Investment

name: R&D Investment (R&D)
define: A mediating variable representing the investment amount in research and development activities.
source: Impact of National Innovative City Policy on Enterprise Green Technology Innovation—Mediation Role of Innovation Environment and R&D Investment

name: Urban Credit Expansion
define: The abnormal level of new credit at the city level in 2009 as a proportion of the city’s GDP.
source: How Urban-Level Credit Expansion Affects the Quality of Green Innovation: Evidence from China

name: Green Patent Quality
define: The average number of citations to green patents within a 5-year period of public disclosure.
source: How Urban-Level Credit Expansion Affects the Quality of Green Innovation: Evidence from China

name: City Tier
define: The classification of cities into different tiers based on development levels, with first-tier cities being the most developed.
source: How Urban-Level Credit Expansion Affects the Quality of Green Innovation: Evidence from China

name: Firm Size
define: The size of a firm, with a focus on the difference between large and small-sized firms.
source: How Urban-Level Credit Expansion Affects the Quality of Green Innovation: Evidence from China

name: Economic Stimulus Package
define: The policy implemented in 2009 in response to the global financial crisis.
source: How Urban-Level Credit Expansion Affects the Quality of Green Innovation: Evidence from China

name: GDP per Capita
define: The city’s GDP per capita, measured using the natural logarithm.
source: How Urban-Level Credit Expansion Affects the Quality of Green Innovation: Evidence from China

name: Industry Share
define: The total share of secondary and tertiary industries in GDP.
source: How Urban-Level Credit Expansion Affects the Quality of Green Innovation: Evidence from China

name: Fixed Asset Investment
define: The share of total local fixed asset investment in GDP.
source: How Urban-Level Credit Expansion Affects the Quality of Green Innovation: Evidence from China

name: Foreign Investment
define: The share of total foreign investment in GDP.
source: How Urban-Level Credit Expansion Affects the Quality of Green Innovation: Evidence from China

name: Population Size
define: The population size at the end of the year, measured as the natural logarithm of the population.
source: How Urban-Level Credit Expansion Affects the Quality of Green Innovation: Evidence from China

name: Intellectual Property Protection
define: A policy variable focusing on the Chinese Intellectual Property Rights model cities as a quasi-natural experiment.
source: Patent Protection Policy and Firms’ Green Technology Innovation: Mediating Roles of Open Innovation and Human Capital

name: Green Technology Innovation
define: A dependent variable measured by the natural logarithm of the number of firms' green invention patent applications plus 1 (Ginvent).
source: Patent Protection Policy and Firms’ Green Technology Innovation: Mediating Roles of Open Innovation and Human Capital

name: Open Innovation
define: A mediating variable indicated by the dummy variable for R&D collaboration (Cooperate1) and the logarithm of the number of joint patent applications (Cooperate2).
source: Patent Protection Policy and Firms’ Green Technology Innovation: Mediating Roles of Open Innovation and Human Capital

name: Human Capital
define: A mediating variable measured by the share of scientific and technical workers in total employees (Tech).
source: Patent Protection Policy and Firms’ Green Technology Innovation: Mediating Roles of Open Innovation and Human Capital

name: Firm Size
define: A control variable measured by the natural logarithm of a firm’s total assets.
source: Patent Protection Policy and Firms’ Green Technology Innovation: Mediating Roles of Open Innovation and Human Capital

name: Firm Maturity
define: A control variable measured by firm age.
source: Patent Protection Policy and Firms’ Green Technology Innovation: Mediating Roles of Open Innovation and Human Capital

name: Corporate Leverage
define: A control variable measured by debts (Lev).
source: Patent Protection Policy and Firms’ Green Technology Innovation: Mediating Roles of Open Innovation and Human Capital

name: Equity Structure and Management Level
define: A control variable measured by the percentage shares held by the largest shareholder (Share) and the number of senior executives (lnManager).
source: Patent Protection Policy and Firms’ Green Technology Innovation: Mediating Roles of Open Innovation and Human Capital

name: Government Subsidies
define: A control variable measured by financial support from the government sector in energy and the environment (lnGov).
source: Patent Protection Policy and Firms’ Green Technology Innovation: Mediating Roles of Open Innovation and Human Capital

name: Fashion Symbol
define: A noun phrase consisting of multiple words related to fashion design, used to represent elements of a fashion collection.
source: Text-Generated Fashion Influence Model: An Empirical Study on Style.com

name: Fashion Collection
define: A set of fashion symbols adopted by a designer in a particular season.
source: Text-Generated Fashion Influence Model: An Empirical Study on Style.com

name: Fashion Designer
define: An individual or brand that creates fashion collections and can be an influencer or influencee.
source: Text-Generated Fashion Influence Model: An Empirical Study on Style.com

name: Fashion Season
define: A specific time period, typically Spring or Fall, during which fashion collections are released.
source: Text-Generated Fashion Influence Model: An Empirical Study on Style.com

name: Influence Link
define: A directed connection between two designers, indicating that one designer may have been influenced by another's fashion symbols.
source: Text-Generated Fashion Influence Model: An Empirical Study on Style.com

name: InDegree
define: A measure of the number of influence links pointing towards a designer, indicating their influence on others.
source: Text-Generated Fashion Influence Model: An Empirical Study on Style.com

name: Betweenness Centrality
define: A measure of a designer's centrality in the network, indicating their potential to control the adoption or discarding of fashion symbols.
source: Text-Generated Fashion Influence Model: An Empirical Study on Style.com

name: Average Path Length
define: The average number of intermediaries between any two designers in the network, indicating the spread of fashion influence.
source: Text-Generated Fashion Influence Model: An Empirical Study on Style.com

name: Fashion Taxonomy
define: A classification system of fashion-related words used to assist in the detection of fashion symbols.
source: Text-Generated Fashion Influence Model: An Empirical Study on Style.com

name: Textual Data
define: Unstructured fashion data from sources like Style.com, used to extract fashion information and construct the influence network.
source: Text-Generated Fashion Influence Model: An Empirical Study on Style.com

name: Demand-Pull Policies
define: Policies that emphasize business or market incentives, such as government procurement of new products and market preference.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Supply-Push Policies
define: Policies that focus on technology-driven investments, such as direct subsidies for R&D activities and tax credits for R&D investments.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Product Innovation
define: Innovations that typically represent new or improved goods or services, indicated by granted inventions.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Process Innovation
define: Innovations that involve enhanced performance in terms of production or existing goods, indicated by utility models.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: R&D Investments
define: Expenditures on research and development activities, which are expected to drive innovation.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Fixed Assets Investments
define: The growth rate of investments in fixed assets, which may contribute to innovation by renewing machinery and equipment.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Capital Deepening
define: The ratio of total assets to the total number of employees, indicating the level of capital available per worker.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Industrial Competitiveness
define: The competitiveness of the industry, measured by the natural logarithm of the number of firms.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Profitability
define: The profit margin, calculated as net income divided by sales revenue, which may influence the resources available for innovation.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Operational Risk
define: The ratio of debts to assets, reflecting the financial risk associated with business operations.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Innovation Input
define: Measured by R&D expenses, used to represent the input in the innovation process.
source: The Impact of Social Security Fund & Insurance Fund on Corporate Innovation

name: Innovation Output
define: Measured by the number of newly acquired patents, used to represent the output of the innovation process.
source: The Impact of Social Security Fund & Insurance Fund on Corporate Innovation

name: Social Security Fund
define: Shares of Social Security Fund divided by all tradable shares, representing the influence of Social Security Fund on a firm.
source: The Impact of Social Security Fund & Insurance Fund on Corporate Innovation

name: Insurance Fund
define: Shares of Insurance Fund divided by all tradable shares, representing the influence of Insurance Fund on a firm.
source: The Impact of Social Security Fund & Insurance Fund on Corporate Innovation

name: State-Owned Enterprises (SOE)
define: A dummy variable distinguishing state-owned companies from non-state-owned companies.
source: The Impact of Social Security Fund & Insurance Fund on Corporate Innovation

name: Non-State-Owned Enterprises (Non-SOE)
define: A category of firms that are not state-owned, used to differentiate the impact of funds on different types of ownership.
source: The Impact of Social Security Fund & Insurance Fund on Corporate Innovation

name: Market Value of Shares
define: Market value of the shares held by Social Security Fund (SSF_Mkt) and Insurance Fund (INS_Mkt).
source: The Impact of Social Security Fund & Insurance Fund on Corporate Innovation

name: Size of Firm
define: Total assets of a company, used as a control variable.
source: The Impact of Social Security Fund & Insurance Fund on Corporate Innovation

name: Debt-Asset Ratio
define: Total assets divided by total liabilities, used as a control variable.
source: The Impact of Social Security Fund & Insurance Fund on Corporate Innovation

name: Return on Assets (ROA)
define: A measure of company profitability, used as a control variable.
source: The Impact of Social Security Fund & Insurance Fund on Corporate Innovation

name: Demand-Pull Policies
define: Policies that emphasize business or market incentives, such as government procurement of new products and market preference.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Supply-Push Policies
define: Policies that focus on technology-driven investments, such as direct subsidies for R&D activities and tax credits for R&D investments.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Product Innovation
define: Innovations that typically represent new or improved goods or services, indicated by granted inventions.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Process Innovation
define: Innovations that involve enhanced performance in terms of production or existing goods, indicated by utility models.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: R&D Investments
define: Expenditures on research and development activities, which are expected to drive innovation.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Fixed Assets Investments
define: The growth rate of investments in fixed assets, which may contribute to innovation by renewing machinery and equipment.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Capital Deepening
define: The ratio of total assets to the total number of employees, indicating the level of capital available per worker.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Industrial Competitiveness
define: The competitiveness of the industry, measured by the natural logarithm of the number of firms.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Profitability
define: The profit margin, calculated as net income divided by sales revenue, which may influence the resources available for innovation.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Operational Risk
define: The ratio of debts to assets, reflecting the financial risk and potential impact on innovation investment.
source: The impact of demand-pull and supply-push policies on technological innovation: does the type of policy matter?

name: Cooperation Breadth
define: Measured by the number of partners in the enterprise’s egocentric network, indicating the extent of enterprise collaboration.
source: The Influence of the Evolution of the Innovative Network on Technical Innovation from the Perspective of Energy Transformation: Based on Analysis of the New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Structural Hole
define: Measured using the constraint, indicating the number of structural holes occupied by an enterprise.
source: The Influence of the Evolution of the Innovative Network on Technical Innovation from the Perspective of Energy Transformation: Based on Analysis of the New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Knowledge Diversity
define: Measured by the total number of IPC subcategories applied for, representing the diversity of knowledge of an enterprise.
source: The Influence of the Evolution of the Innovative Network on Technical Innovation from the Perspective of Energy Transformation: Based on Analysis of the New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Technical Value
define: Measured by the total patent value, indicating the expected economic benefits and sustainable competitiveness of an enterprise.
source: The Influence of the Evolution of the Innovative Network on Technical Innovation from the Perspective of Energy Transformation: Based on Analysis of the New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Technical Innovation (TI)
define: Measured by the number of licensed patents, serving as a proxy for the technical innovation capability of an enterprise.
source: The Influence of the Evolution of the Innovative Network on Technical Innovation from the Perspective of Energy Transformation: Based on Analysis of the New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Age
define: Measured over the period from the company’s inception to 2022.
source: The Influence of the Evolution of the Innovative Network on Technical Innovation from the Perspective of Energy Transformation: Based on Analysis of the New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Size
define: Measured as the total number of inventors owned by the enterprise.
source: The Influence of the Evolution of the Innovative Network on Technical Innovation from the Perspective of Energy Transformation: Based on Analysis of the New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: R&D
define: The proportion of the enterprise’s R&D investment in operating income.
source: The Influence of the Evolution of the Innovative Network on Technical Innovation from the Perspective of Energy Transformation: Based on Analysis of the New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Sales
define: Measured by the logarithm of operating income.
source: The Influence of the Evolution of the Innovative Network on Technical Innovation from the Perspective of Energy Transformation: Based on Analysis of the New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Property
define: A binary variable indicating whether the enterprise is a listed company.
