source: The Influence of the Evolution of the Innovative Network on Technical Innovation from the Perspective of Energy Transformation: Based on Analysis of the New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Year and Area
define: Dummy variables representing the year and the province where the enterprise is located.
source: The Influence of the Evolution of the Innovative Network on Technical Innovation from the Perspective of Energy Transformation: Based on Analysis of the New Energy Vehicle Industry in China

name: Inventor Mobility
define: A variable representing the movement of knowledge workers from one firm to another, particularly from Japan to China and Korea.
source: The Knowledge Spillover Resulting from the Mobility of Knowledge Workers

name: R&D Performance
define: A variable measured by patent citation counts, representing the innovation output and quality of a firm's R&D activities.
source: The Knowledge Spillover Resulting from the Mobility of Knowledge Workers

name: Inventors' Networks
define: A variable representing the social networks of inventors, including co-invention networks and centrality measures within these networks.
source: The Knowledge Spillover Resulting from the Mobility of Knowledge Workers

name: Tacit Knowledge
define: A variable representing the non-codified knowledge that is difficult to communicate and relies on face-to-face interaction.
source: The Knowledge Spillover Resulting from the Mobility of Knowledge Workers

name: Analytical Skills and Problem-Solving Capacity
define: A variable representing the abilities of knowledge workers that successful firms are looking for, rather than just 'star inventors'.
source: The Knowledge Spillover Resulting from the Mobility of Knowledge Workers

name: Firm Size
define: A control variable representing the size of the firm, categorized as large or small based on sales figures.
source: The Knowledge Spillover Resulting from the Mobility of Knowledge Workers

name: Artificial Personality
define: A construct that simulates human motivation and cognition based on a cybernetic model.
source: The design and validation of an artificial personality

name: Motivational Model
define: A four-dimensional model that classifies sentences according to their motivational and cognitive content.
source: The design and validation of an artificial personality

name: Age
define: A variable used to test the predictions of the model regarding age dependence of human behavior.
source: The design and validation of an artificial personality

name: Humor Appreciation
define: A measure used to validate the model, based on surveys of participants' appreciation of different types of humor.
source: The design and validation of an artificial personality

name: Cybernetic Concept of Requisite Variety
define: A foundational concept in the model that suggests a systematic variation with age.
source: The design and validation of an artificial personality

name: Information Theory
define: Used to explain the relationship between the speed of body needs and the variety of brain classifications.
source: The design and validation of an artificial personality

name: Homeostasis
define: A process of regulation in the model that involves the interaction between priming and homeostatic mechanisms.
source: The design and validation of an artificial personality

name: Multiplier Feedback Loop
define: A component of the model that represents the transmission of information from the body to the brain.
source: The design and validation of an artificial personality

name: Brain Processing Power
define: An assumed variable that declines with age and affects the processing of motivational needs.
source: The design and validation of an artificial personality

name: Types of Humor
define: Categories of humor classified according to the model's motivational dimensions.
source: The design and validation of an artificial personality

name: Venture Capital (VC)
define: A binary variable indicating whether a firm has received venture capital investment.
source: Can venture capital trigger innovation? New evidence from China

name: Innovation
define: A composite variable measured by patent counts and Total Factor Productivity (TFP) growth.
source: Can venture capital trigger innovation? New evidence from China

name: Patent Counts
define: A direct indicator of a firm's innovation output.
source: Can venture capital trigger innovation? New evidence from China

name: TFP Growth
define: A measure of efficiency and productivity growth, inferred from variables applied in calculating Total Factor Productivity.
source: Can venture capital trigger innovation? New evidence from China

name: Firm Age
define: The age of the firm, used as a control variable in the analysis.
source: Can venture capital trigger innovation? New evidence from China

name: Firm Size
define: Measured by total assets and employment, used as control variables.
source: Can venture capital trigger innovation? New evidence from China

name: Industry Dummy
define: A categorical variable indicating the industry sector of the firm.
source: Can venture capital trigger innovation? New evidence from China

name: State Dummy
define: A binary variable indicating government intervention or support for the firm.
source: Can venture capital trigger innovation? New evidence from China

name: Capital Intensity
define: Defined as the total capital per employee, used as a control variable.
source: Can venture capital trigger innovation? New evidence from China

name: Patent Dummy
define: A binary variable indicating whether the firm had registered at least one patent prior to the study period.
source: Can venture capital trigger innovation? New evidence from China

name: Malmquist Index
define: A measure of productivity growth, used as a control variable.
source: Can venture capital trigger innovation? New evidence from China

name: Recruit
define: An indicator variable for whether the given patent is a focal patent involving a move or a control patent.
source: NBER Working Paper 15869: Recruiting for Ideas: How Firms Exploit the Prior Inventions of New Hires

name: Post-Move
define: An indicator for whether the citing year falls after the estimated move date.
source: NBER Working Paper 15869: Recruiting for Ideas: How Firms Exploit the Prior Inventions of New Hires

name: All Cites
define: All citations to the focal patent from the destination firm in the given year.
source: NBER Working Paper 15869: Recruiting for Ideas: How Firms Exploit the Prior Inventions of New Hires

name: Cites Excluding Inventor Self-Cites
define: Destination firm citations coming from individuals other than the patent's inventor herself.
source: NBER Working Paper 15869: Recruiting for Ideas: How Firms Exploit the Prior Inventions of New Hires

name: Cites Excluding Inventor Self-Cites or Collaborator Cites
define: Destination firm citations coming from individuals other than the patent's inventor herself or any of her prior collaborators.
source: NBER Working Paper 15869: Recruiting for Ideas: How Firms Exploit the Prior Inventions of New Hires

name: Destination Firm Patents
define: Number of patents assigned to the destination firm in the five years preceding the inventor's move year.
source: NBER Working Paper 15869: Recruiting for Ideas: How Firms Exploit the Prior Inventions of New Hires

name: Destination Same-Class Patents
define: Number of destination firm patents that belong to the same 3-digit technology class as the focal patent.
source: NBER Working Paper 15869: Recruiting for Ideas: How Firms Exploit the Prior Inventions of New Hires

name: Claims
define: Number of claims made by the focal patent.
source: NBER Working Paper 15869: Recruiting for Ideas: How Firms Exploit the Prior Inventions of New Hires

name: Patent References
define: Number of backward citations that the focal patent makes to other patents.
source: NBER Working Paper 15869: Recruiting for Ideas: How Firms Exploit the Prior Inventions of New Hires

name: Inventor Patents
define: Number of previous patents successfully applied for by the same inventor.
source: NBER Working Paper 15869: Recruiting for Ideas: How Firms Exploit the Prior Inventions of New Hires

name: Direct Government Funding
define: A variable representing the extent of financial support from the government in the development of a drug.
source: What Are The Respective Roles Of The Public And Private Sectors In Pharmaceutical Innovation?

name: Priority-Review Drugs
define: A categorical variable for drugs that offer major advances in treatment or provide a treatment where no adequate therapy exists, and thus receive a faster review process from the FDA.
source: What Are The Respective Roles Of The Public And Private Sectors In Pharmaceutical Innovation?

name: Standard-Review Drugs
define: A categorical variable for drugs that proceed through the FDA’s normal review process.
source: What Are The Respective Roles Of The Public And Private Sectors In Pharmaceutical Innovation?

name: Public-Sector Patents
define: A variable indicating whether a drug's development had a patent assigned to a government agency or acknowledged government funding.
source: What Are The Respective Roles Of The Public And Private Sectors In Pharmaceutical Innovation?

name: Academic Patents
define: A variable indicating whether a drug's development involved patents held by a US college, university, or medical school.
source: What Are The Respective Roles Of The Public And Private Sectors In Pharmaceutical Innovation?

name: Patent Citations
define: A variable representing the number of times a drug's patent cited previous patents and scientific publications.
source: What Are The Respective Roles Of The Public And Private Sectors In Pharmaceutical Innovation?

name: Government Publications
define: A variable indicating whether a drug's patent cited articles in PubMed acknowledging support from a US government agency.
source: What Are The Respective Roles Of The Public And Private Sectors In Pharmaceutical Innovation?

name: Prescription Drug Sales
define: A variable representing the total sales value of the drugs in the year 2006.
source: What Are The Respective Roles Of The Public And Private Sectors In Pharmaceutical Innovation?

name: HIV/AIDS Drugs
define: A categorical variable for drugs used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS, which received special attention in the policy discussion.
source: What Are The Respective Roles Of The Public And Private Sectors In Pharmaceutical Innovation?

name: Orphan Drugs
define: A categorical variable for drugs that target rare diseases and may have different public-sector involvement.
source: What Are The Respective Roles Of The Public And Private Sectors In Pharmaceutical Innovation?

name: Inventor's Absorptive Capacity
define: The ability of an individual to value, assimilate, and apply external knowledge, measured by the percentage of past experience in the technology needed for the patent.
source: Who is Generating New Innovations? An Analysis of Blockchain Engineers

name: Knowledge Redundancy
define: The degree of overlap in knowledge bases, measured by the Herfindahl–Hirschman Index (HHI) for the first and all International Classifications (ICs) described in a patent that the inventor had been involved in.
source: Who is Generating New Innovations? An Analysis of Blockchain Engineers

name: Quality of Innovation Performance
define: The patent rights value, which comprises R&D results calculated using the YK3 method.
source: Who is Generating New Innovations? An Analysis of Blockchain Engineers

name: Number of Patents Worked on in the Past
define: The total number of patents the inventor has previously worked on.
source: Who is Generating New Innovations? An Analysis of Blockchain Engineers

name: Number of Inventors on the Patent
define: The total number of inventors credited with the patent.
source: Who is Generating New Innovations? An Analysis of Blockchain Engineers

name: Number of US Patents Referenced
define: The number of US patents that the patent references.
source: Who is Generating New Innovations? An Analysis of Blockchain Engineers

name: Number of Foreign Patents Referenced
define: The number of foreign patents that the patent references.
source: Who is Generating New Innovations? An Analysis of Blockchain Engineers

name: Percentage of Knowledgeable Team Member
define: The percentage of team members who have past collaboration experience.
source: Who is Generating New Innovations? An Analysis of Blockchain Engineers

name: Diversity of Team Members
define: The Herfindahl–Hirschman Index (HHI) where the countries' team members hail from.
source: Who is Generating New Innovations? An Analysis of Blockchain Engineers

name: Urban Environmental Legislation
define: A binary variable indicating whether a city has implemented local environmental laws.
source: Would the Urban Environmental Legislation Realize the Porter Hypothesis? Empirical Evidence Based on Panel Data of Chinese Prefecture Cities

name: Green Total Factor Productivity (Green TFP)
define: A measure of productivity growth considering energy and environmental factors.
source: Would the Urban Environmental Legislation Realize the Porter Hypothesis? Empirical Evidence Based on Panel Data of Chinese Prefecture Cities

name: Green Patents
define: The number of green patents granted, serving as a proxy for green innovation.
source: Would the Urban Environmental Legislation Realize the Porter Hypothesis? Empirical Evidence Based on Panel Data of Chinese Prefecture Cities

name: Government Expenditures
define: The ratio of local fiscal expenditure to local GDP.
source: Would the Urban Environmental Legislation Realize the Porter Hypothesis? Empirical Evidence Based on Panel Data of Chinese Prefecture Cities

name: Industrial Structure
define: The ratio of the output value of the secondary industry to regional GDP.
source: Would the Urban Environmental Legislation Realize the Porter Hypothesis? Empirical Evidence Based on Panel Data of Chinese Prefecture Cities

name: Foreign Capital Dependence
define: The proportion of foreign direct investment in regional GDP.
source: Would the Urban Environmental Legislation Realize the Porter Hypothesis? Empirical Evidence Based on Panel Data of Chinese Prefecture Cities

name: GDP per Capita
define: A measure of the level of economic development in the region.
source: Would the Urban Environmental Legislation Realize the Porter Hypothesis? Empirical Evidence Based on Panel Data of Chinese Prefecture Cities

name: National Environmental Law
define: The number of national environmental laws implemented in the year.
source: Would the Urban Environmental Legislation Realize the Porter Hypothesis? Empirical Evidence Based on Panel Data of Chinese Prefecture Cities

name: Provincial Environmental Law
define: The number of provincial environmental laws implemented in the year.
source: Would the Urban Environmental Legislation Realize the Porter Hypothesis? Empirical Evidence Based on Panel Data of Chinese Prefecture Cities
